TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to standing order 13, I advise the Senate that the President is unavoidably absent and the Deputy President will take the chair.

PARA.TAB: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Crichton-Browne) thereupon took the chair, and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I inform the Senate that the President will be absent from the sittings of the Senate today and tomorrow. Pursuant to standing order 13, the President has suggested that I be empowered to act as President during his absence.

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator Faulkner)—by leave—agreed to:

(1) That, during the absence of the President, the Deputy President shall, on each sitting day, take the Chair of the Senate and may, during such absence, perform the duties and exercise the authority of the President in relation to all proceedings of the Senate and proceedings of committees to which the President is appointed.
(2) That the President be granted leave of absence for 28 and 29 November 1994.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It is with deep regret that I inform the Senate of the death on 26 November 1994 of a former President of the Senate, the Hon. Sir Magnus Cameron Cormack KBE, President of the Senate from 1971 to 1974 and senator for the state of Victoria from 1951 to 1953 and from 1962 to 1978. I understand that it would accord with the wishes of the Senate that a condolence motion be moved after questions and taking note of answers today.
—Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Aerial Spraying
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

We the undersigned respectfully call upon the Federal Government to phase out aerial spraying in accordance with recommendation 89 of the report of the Senate Select Committee on Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals in Australia.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth
That the majority of Australians clearly stand united in satisfaction with their existing Australian National Flag which reflects their values, history and heritage.
And that they condemn unwarranted attacks on their historic Australian Flag, whenever or wherever made by any Australian citizens.

So therefore do we call upon the Senate to ensure that the Australian National Flag, as publicly acclaimed in 1901 and confirmed under the Flags Act (1953), is not changed, replaced or diminished at any time, or in any manner whatsoever, without such a proposal being first voted upon and approved by a majority of Australian citizens in a national referendum.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the order of the Senate of 17 November 1994 authorising the Select Committee on Superannuation to hold a public hearing during the sitting of the Senate on Monday, 28 November 1994 from 10 a.m. till 4.00 p.m. be amended by inserting the word `including' after the word `evidence'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is it sought to make this amendment to the original proposition formal? When it is, I will be refusing leave.
—Senator Watson is moving the motion by leave. Leave has been granted, so I propose to put the motion.
—I rise on a point of order, Mr Deputy President. Is the motion seeking to amend the order of the Senate?
—Yes, it is.
—I think it needs explanation. I have not heard about it.
—I am not in a position to persuade Senator Watson to convince you or otherwise. Senator Watson is entitled to speak to his motion if he so wishes.

—By way of explanation to satisfy Senator Harradine, the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation was given leave to sit between the hours of 10 o'clock and 4 o'clock for the purpose of taking evidence from the ACTU in relation to the superannuation guarantee charge. Because of the considerable amount of interest in this particular inquiry, Treasury officers and those from other departments will be appearing before the committee. In order to enable, for example, Treasury officers to offer explanations that the committee might require, that particular word was required to be added as an amendment to the motion.

PARA.TAB: All it will do is facilitate committee members being able to ask Treasury officers questions by way of clarification in relation to evidence that has been presented. This is a normal procedure within the committee process. I would think that the Senate's rejection of such an application would certainly diminish our ability to have issues clarified in an expedient and normal way. I seek the cooperation of the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Committees, of course, are able to examine the officers concerned. Committees are able to call anyone and, most particularly, are able to call before them the officers of various departments. That is what we are here for. I am a bit at a loss to know what extra is being sought. The Senate gave the committee leave to meet. We did this reluctantly. The Senate does not like to see committees of the Senate meeting whilst the Senate is in session.

PARA.TAB: There are a number of very important issues to come before the Senate today, not least of which is the message relating to the ATSIC Amendment (Indigenous Land Corporation and Land Fund) Bill that is about to be discussed. The other matters to be discussed today, which are on the red sheet and which are very important, include the Student Assistance (Budget Matters) Amendment Bill, the Higher Education Funding Legislation Amendment Bill, the Student Assistance (Youth Training Allowance) Amendment Bill, the Qantas Sale Amendment Bill and the ANL Guarantee Bill—and no doubt we will not get to the ANL Guarantee Bill and the Qantas bill. We also have to consider the important education bill. Meanwhile, the committee is somewhere in the other parts of the building having its meeting and does not know what is going on here.

I understand the pressure that is on committees at the present moment. I understand that we do not want to revisit the permission that was given to the committee. I had not heard, as I normally do, about this particular proposal and that is why I want it explained. As far as I am concerned, you can have leave. I make the point again that it is very important to avoid, as far as possible, committees of the Senate meeting whilst the Senate is in session.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to contingent notice of motion, I move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Chamarette moving a motion relating to the conduct of the business of the Senate, namely a motion to give precedence to general business notice of motion No. 1197 standing in her name for this day, relating to the consideration of legislation introduced in the current sittings.

SPEECH.PARA: I draw the attention of my colleagues to the content of the notice of motion. We are well aware that we have only a very short time left in the sitting hours of this Senate, and that is why it is urgent that this matter be debated. There is a principle at stake, which is the principle of whether this chamber determines its program, whether the government determines the program, whether the bureaucrats who write the legislation determine the priority of the program, or whether a whips' meeting, which has occurred, can determine the program.

PARA.TAB: While I have no objection whatsoever to the hard work that has been done by the government and by the representatives of all the parties in the Senate—although Senator Harradine was not able to participate—a program has been established which changes the principle that Senator Evans agreed to, which was that, wherever possible, bills that were introduced this session would be considered and debated next session. There have been about 23 exceptions to this. I have a list which I am prepared to circulate in the chamber for people's information, if they would like me to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, on a point of order: it would be very helpful to have that list so we can understand fully what Senator Chamarette is putting to the Senate.

—The list that will be circulated sets out the bills that have been introduced into the Senate this sitting. It has been agreed by the various parties in the Senate, in a meeting out of Senate time, that some of the bills will be debated in the next session and some will be debated in the remaining week or so of this session. I believe this chamber is the right and appropriate place to make that decision rather than to have it made for us. It may be a simple formality. I am asking that my motion be agreed to so that we can have a precedent and so that a vote can be taken on whether certain bills are debated in this session or adjourned to the following session.

PARA.TAB: My motion may require some amendment—I understand the opposition will be looking at this—to include the particular bills that have been circulated. We may have to go through them and vote on the elimination of some of those bills from my notice of motion and the inclusion of the ones which all parties in the Senate agree are of sufficient urgency and where the government has presented enough rationalisation and justification for them to be considered in this sitting. Those bills can then be dealt with this session and the remainder adjourned to the next session.

I am trying to point out to everybody why it is urgent to consider this. If we do not, on a de facto basis we would be agreeing that the program can be determined outside this chamber; that an exception can be made to a procedure that was accepted within this chamber as appropriate; and that our priority of business can be determined without any reference to this chamber. If we fail to consider the motion today, we will be accepting that whatever is organised in meetings in offices and outside this chamber is acceptable to this chamber. I urge my colleagues to support this motion that the matter be debated, because I think there is much more to be said about it than simply the matters I have raised.

If we do not consider the motion today, when are we going to? We are about to embark on an altered program which contains bills which have been introduced this session. We are giving de facto agreement to the violation of the principle Senator Evans announced he would adhere to that bills which were introduced in one session would be considered and debated in the next, unless we were convinced in the chamber that they were urgent and were special bills and the government had very good reason for considering them now. I see no problem with making that exception. This chamber should make the exceptions; it should not be done by a meeting of the parties or the whips outside the chamber.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not support the suspension of standing orders moved by Senator Chamarette. Senator Chamarette's motion purports to be about the orderly process of debating bills in the Senate. The actual effect of it would be to add very significantly to the amount of time required to debate legislation by having a procedural debate on the urgency of each bill in this category prior to consideration by the Senate and have each bill in this category determined by Senator Chamarette. That would mean, in addition to what we have on our program, 28 procedural debates.

PARA.TAB: The government has provided the Senate with reasons for the urgency of bills that are being introduced in this session of parliament. Details of those reasons were tabled in the chamber on 31 August for bills that were introduced prior to that time and for subsequent bills reasons have also been provided to non-government senators. Senator Chamarette now wants a debate on those reasons and by implication, I think, for the Senate to go beyond its scrutiny role and tell the executive what its priorities should and should not be.

When Senator Evans gave a commitment, which he did, and put forward the objective of introduction of bills one session for debate in the next, he made several qualifications very clear at the time. One of those qualifications was the understanding that there would be a need for urgent legislation, that there were urgent bills and that many of these bills were related to measures that the government had brought down in the budget. Every senator in the chamber knows that there is always going to be a need for urgent bills and budget related bills to be introduced in one session for passage in that session. It will always be impossible to anticipate the urgent legislation that will be required in certain sessions.

The government did introduce new arrangements to inform senators about urgent legislation and the reasons for that urgency. I think that is an entirely reasonable and proper approach for the government to take. It has been fully consultative in the way we have dealt with this issue and an entirely reasonable approach in these circumstances. There have been suggestions with the opposition, the Democrats, the Green senators and Senator Harradine about innovative ways we can maximise the amount of time we have remaining. As a result, I do not believe an extra sitting week will be necessary this year. So we have further prioritised the remaining bills that are on the legislative program. By sitting some extra hours over the next two weeks, I believe we can achieve the objectives of more orderly business management in the Senate and the passage of urgent legislation. I do believe that debate on this motion is unnecessary. We should be getting on with the business instead of having an enormous number of unnecessary and time wasting procedural debates.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —This should be a matter of great embarrassment for the government because it has failed to meet its undertakings to provide the chamber with an orderly program. The commitment it gave, of course, was that now that we have three separate sessions in parliament during the year it would give proper notice of its legislative program and it would do that by giving notice of bills in the session previous to that in which it intended to have the bills debated.

PARA.TAB: In so many instances it has failed to live up to that undertaking, which is one of the reasons why we have got to the end of this session with such a massive workload that cannot be processed to the standard we regard as desirable within the time available. Therefore, we believe Senator Chamarette's motion in principle has merit. If the government is going to breach its undertaking to the chamber, then in each instance it should make its case.

We accept that there will be exceptional circumstances in which it would require debate of a piece of legislation without giving the sort of notice which I just mentioned and which it has undertaken to give. It may be in relation to matters of benefits to the less well off in our community; it might be a variation to pensions or some instance arising out of the issue of long-term unemployment for which the government has proposals. We have doubts about some of those proposals; but we regard it as in the interests of the nation for the matters to be debated during the session in which the changes were proposed rather than for them to be delayed.

There is no procedure at the moment that requires the government to make that case in the chamber. Therefore, we see merit within the spirit of what Senator Chamarette is proposing and, certainly, we agree to such a change to our orders so that in the future, if the government seeks to have any piece of legislation debated without having given notice in the previous session, it will have to argue the urgency of it in this place. Whether the legislation gets debated will depend on whether it can achieve the numbers necessary for that purpose.

We now have to deal with the current program. As we know, a large number of bills fall into this category. On this side of the chamber we have, as has been said, privately—not in the chamber, but in accordance with past and usual practice—sat down with other parties and the individual Independent senator and discussed what the government was intending in its program. We on this side of the chamber have made an assessment as to which bills we regard as urgent and requiring debate in this session without prior notice having been given and we have indicated to the government and to other minority parties what those bills are.

As I understand it, Senator Chamarette is saying that she does not want 28 separate procedural debates on the 28 bills that fall within that category, but she wishes to have the reasons why that package of bills should be treated as urgent on the public record rather than simply on the private record. I do not have any objection to that. I cannot see why history should not record the circumstances in which we agreed to waive the breach by the government of its undertaking. But the motion before us does not adequately achieve what she now says she is prepared to accept—that is, one debate rather than 28 procedural debates. She said that she understood there would be further amendments to clarify that matter. I am prepared to look at a form of words that would achieve that objective.

It does not seem to me to be an efficient use of time for us to debate the whole issue in principle and then come back tomorrow to debate the substance of the motion and proposed amendments. Therefore, we do not agree with the suspension of standing orders, but we undertake by tomorrow to prepare an amendment. If she brings this matter on tomorrow we are prepared to have a substantive debate rather than another procedural debate.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats do not support this motion for the suspension of standing orders. I agree with Senator Hill in some respects regarding the government's management of its program. I suggest to some ministers that they go back and speak to their departments, because it is my impression that some departments still have not caught up with the fact that we have a May budget. Having had a May budget, it is unacceptable that we are still receiving legislation emanating from that budget with important start-up dates—from 1 January next year and beyond that. So I think some ministerial direction needs to be given to some departments. If we are here this time next year, we would expect to see an improvement in that regard.

PARA.TAB: Notwithstanding what Senator Hill said that he can accept by way of an amendment, I would say that Senator Chamarette is being a little disingenuous. The government did organise meetings for party leaders and whips in this chamber. We all attended the first meeting. Senator Chamarette chose not to attend the second one where we heard the government's arguments as to why particular bills were considered urgent. We agreed or disagreed and put our own arguments—as Senator Hill did, ably—regarding what we believed was urgent or not urgent. The list that has been devised is as a result of that cooperative discussion. It is not just the government's priorities that are reflected there; it is as a result of the discussion which was held by everyone present at that meeting. I do not think the debate has reflected that yet. I do not believe it is necessary to do this today. I will wait and hear what occurs in the debate tomorrow.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to assure the Manager of Government Business in the Senate, Senator Faulkner, that there is no intention on my part, and I am sure no intention on the part of Senator Chamarette, who moved this motion, to hijack the agenda of the government. What is being sought is to entrench in a procedural way the ideal that Senator Gareth Evans outlined to the Senate last June—that it was the government's intention to introduce legislation in one session and debate it in the next. The reason for that was part of this accountability issue. The importance of that is obvious. If the people of Australia are to be confident that this parliament is dealing with legislation in a proper and orderly manner, then something needs to be done, because the impression out there at present is that this place is a shemozzle. That is partly true and partly untrue. Nevertheless, I think it is important that when legislation is introduced it be laid on the table so that not only interest groups—very often they know beforehand what is going to be introduced; sometimes before we do—but also ordinary members of the public will know what is contained in government legislation so that they can then make representations to members of parliament about it.

PARA.TAB: What is wrong with that? A very important part of our function is the representative function. What I am concerned about—I am sure Senator Chamarette and those supporting the motion are also concerned about it—and what Senator Evans, presumably, has in mind is to ensure that there is an opportunity for the public to know what is in the legislation well prior to it being debated in substance in this chamber.

It is all right for the whips and others to get together—and of course I am invited to those meetings—to make arrangements as they see fit. But when it comes to the question of having some bills as exceptions to the rule, I believe that is a matter that ought to be quite open and public. I agree with what Senator Chamarette said: the government does owe it to the public to have its reasons for the urgency of bills put on the public record.

This is an important matter. I was delighted when I heard Senator Evans say that we should introduce it in one session and debate it in the next. As far as I am concerned, that is great because, additionally, it gives independent senators and others who have to get over a whole range of legislation time to consider, time to consult and so on. Any procedure that is likely to entrench that principle into being I am in favour of. That is why I am in favour of the motion to suspend.

I assure the government that, from my point of view, it is certainly not an attempt to hijack the agenda of the government. The government has an agenda. It is entitled to pursue that agenda as it sees fit. In the interests of good government, in the interests of this parliament—and particularly this chamber to properly review the legislation—and in the interests of freedom of information and the ability of the public to be able to express its views on the specifics of legislation, all we are saying is that at least this particular motion is going along that particular path, and I support it.
Question resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table a revised explanatory memorandum and move:

PARA.TAB: That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: On 30 June 1994 a draft of this bill was introduced into the House of Representatives to enable exposure for public comment and consultation on the principles and policies with major institutions involved in family law namely the Family Court of Australia, the Family Court of Western Australia, the Family Law Council and the Family Law Section of the Law Council of Australia.

Those consultations were most productive in identifying some weaknesses with the original bill. The government thanks those who gave of their time and expertise to advance the quality of this legislation. Although there was broad agreement with the significant change of approach in dealing with matrimonial breakdown there remain some differences of view with the detail of the provisions.

Every member and senator of this parliament receives more representations on dissatisfaction with, and perceived inequities arising out of, the operation of the Family Law Act 1975 and its companion child support legislation than any other issue. People suffering significant emotional trauma and anguish as a result of the family breakdown naturally turn to their local member for help to reopen the matter to achieve "justice". Those approaches often raise feelings of despair in us when the opportunities to assist are inevitably limited.

Most of those who seek our assistance believe that their partner has been responsible for their traumatic situation. Further, most of them believe that the law and the legal system is assisting that partner to exploit the breakdown to their own advantage. The report of the recent Joint Select Committee on Family Law found that that view was erroneous.

To the contrary, the committee found that, as a general rule, the act itself was an effective vehicle for the administration of family law matters in Australia. Nevertheless, the committee made 120 recommendations for reform of that law within the existing framework of the act.

Family law is the field in which more citizens will have direct contact with the law than any other aspect of the law. It is for this reason that this government announced, on its election, that family law reform was a major priority. The government's initiatives in mediation and other ADR mechanisms in family law are a strategic aspect of its efforts to reduce the need for court action.

The Family Law Act 1975 was one of the great social and legislative reforms of the Whitlam government and is not yet 20 years old. Despite this, it has been the subject of two broad ranging parliamentary joint select committee inquiries resulting in a very large number of recommendations for reform. As well, particular aspects of the act have been examined and recommendations for reform made by bodies such as the Family Law Council and the Australian Law Reform Commission. Many of the recommendations for reform by those non-parliamentary inquiries have been given effect to in recent years. The government's response to the recent joint select committee report accepted the major thrust of its recommendations. By implementing those recommendations which the government accepts the parliament should go a long way in providing a simpler, fairer and speedier family law justice system for all Australians.

The purpose of this bill is to give effect to those recommendations relating to Part VII of the Family Law Act dealing with children and to clarify and extend the alternative dispute resolution mechanisms available in family law. The government also intends to introduce into the House of Representatives this sitting a further bill dealing with recommendations of the joint select committee on matrimonial property, pre-nuptial financial agreements and some other miscellaneous issues. The government anticipate that this further bill will be passed by the parliament early next year to enable the commencement of all the amendments together in the second half of 1995.

Once amended by this bill the act will emphasise the importance the government places on methods of dispute resolution other than litigation by categorising counselling and mediation as primary dispute resolution. Couples whose relationships have broken down will thus be encouraged to seek a settlement of their differences through these mechanisms.

The government is already committed to significant funding of a range of programs for marriage and family skills—marriage counselling, family mediation and family skills and breakdown prevention—marriage education. In 1993/94 grants for these purposes totalled $20.7 million. In addition to the funding already provided, a large number of the joint select committee recommendations had budgetary implications either for additional funding of existing programs or the establishment of new programs.

A modest start to implementation of these recommendations was made in the recent budget. Further consideration will be given to implementation of the remaining recommendations in future budgets. As family law is one of the main areas where Australians come into contact with Commonwealth laws particular consideration will be given to the level and priority of family law funding in the context of a justice statement that the Prime Minister proposes to make early next year.

I am particularly pleased that a start was made on the provision of funding for mediation. This is favoured as a means of enabling separating parties to solve their differences for themselves rather than leaving the problem in the hands of lawyers and judges. Community-based mediation services have been funded for some years and this is continuing.

The additional funding in this year's budget is a seeding allocation to enable mediation services to be provided in a number of alternative ways and evaluated on a consistent basis to ensure that the services being provided are both effective and appropriate. This funding follows the completion of a successful pilot of mediation in the family court. It provides funding to both court annexed and community based mediation. This will enable government to access a range of options as to where the emphasis for the delivery of mediation services should be placed.

Counselling provided for by the act has been extended to recognise and make provision for mediation services in family law to be delivered by community based organisations and approved individuals possessing the necessary qualifications for delivering mediation services.
This bill makes significant changes to the existing provisions relating to counselling.
It provides a wider scope for community based counselling than has been available in the past.

The bill also extends the ambit of counselling. The limitations in the current definition of marriage counselling prevented counselling of some family issues or concerns being handled by these community based bodies. The bill now includes a definition of family and child counselling which will enable community based bodies to engage in a much broader range of counselling than before, in particular counselling in relation to children whether the parties are married or not.

A significant departure in this bill from the approach recommended by the joint select committee is in the relationship between children and their parents. The committee recommended that the existing terminology of guardianship, custody and access should be retained. That terminology suffers from connotations of proprietorial rights in children delivering them as the spoils of victory to the parent gaining custody.

The government was not convinced of the select committee's view that a change in terminology and approach was unnecessary and sought from the Family Law Council a report on the operation of the Children Act 1989 (UK). This act has moved away from the existing approach in Australia. I thank the council for its prompt and incisive report which was tabled on 3 May 1994.

It is over a century since legislators removed the notion of husbands having `property or ownership' in married women. Surprisingly, some adults still adhere to this `property' notion in respect of their offspring, particularly as a basis of power vis-a-vis the other parent. Dr Don Browning, Professor of Ethics and Psychological Studies at the University of Chicago, in May of this year whilst addressing an International Year of the Family seminar in Melbourne, said "parents had become too selfish and tended to put their own needs ahead of those of their children". Many of the representations that senators receive seem to bear out that view.
This bill seeks to redress that proprietorial attitude in a number of important ways.

In December 1990 Australia ratified the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child. That convention contains a number of basic rights in the raising and development of children toward adulthood. The objects clause to the new Part VII of this bill gives recognition to such rights by specifying a number of such rights that should be observed in any agreements or decisions concerning children.

Further, the bill clarifies a general community misconception that parents have rights in respect of children. The bill gives legislative recognition to the common law principle, enunciated in the UK case of Gillick v West Norfolk and Wisbech A.H.A. and adopted by the majority of the High Court in Secretary, Department of Health and Community Services v JWB and SMB (Marion's case), that `the principle of law is that parental rights are derived from parental duty and exist only so long as they are needed for the protection of the person and property of the child.'

The bill is drafted on the basis of parental responsibilities for the care, welfare and development of children. Also the provisions are drafted to enable parties to understand the legislative approach and feel confident in negotiating and agreeing between themselves a proper basis for discharging all those responsibilities in an atmosphere where the child feels love from the parents and is free from the traumatic circumstances that seem to characterise many marital breakdowns at present.

It is consistent with the government's aim to encourage the use of ADR mechanisms. The bill aims to assist parents to agree arrangements for their children rather than having solutions imposed on them. Division 4 of Part VII of the bill contains provisions for parenting plans and encourages their use. Such plans are registerable and enforceable.

Where agreement is unable to be achieved Division 5 of Part VII now provides for a significantly changed range of court orders in respect of the relationship between the parents and the child. It provides for residence, contact and special purpose orders. Unless a special purpose order is made removing a parent's requirement to undertake some or all the responsibilities for the care welfare and development of a child those responsibilities are to be exercised jointly. This is a major departure from the present law under which the custodial parent exercises daily care and control of the child.

Division 7 of Part VII repeats, with only minor modification, a number of the existing maintenance provisions and the location and recovery of children provisions, to reflect these changes in terminology.

Division 11 of Part VII introduces into the act new provisions for dealing with family violence. It also addresses inconsistency between state and territory restraining orders and contact orders under this act. These provisions give effect to the agreement that has been reached in the Standing Committee of Attorney's-General on this issue.
The bill re-enacts a number of other provisions of the present act without modification to make the changes in terminology complete for that part of the act dealing with children.
I commend the bill to the Senate and present the explanatory memorandum.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: Next year will mark the 20th anniversary of the passage of the Racial Discrimination Act.

The Act was the first specific Commonwealth law on human rights. It was based on the fundamental belief that all Australians irrespective of race, colour or national or ethnic origin are entitled to fair treatment.

In this country, we take pride in the community's consensus that everyone should be able to advance through life on their own efforts and abilities; that it is wrong to judge anyone on the colour of their skin or the sound of their accent.

Be it under a law, or in employment, or the provision of services, or access to facilities and accommodation, discrimination based on racial prejudice and intolerance is addressed by the Racial Discrimination Act.
The law provides a remedy to those who have experienced discrimination. It exists because, even with general community tolerance, we know racism exists. And racism leads to discrimination.

The Racial Discrimination Act does not eliminate racist attitudes. It does not try to, for a law cannot change what people think. But it does target behaviour—behaviour that causes an individual to suffer discrimination.
The parliament is now being asked to pass a new law dealing with racism in Australia. It too targets behaviour—behaviour which affects not only the individual but the community as a whole.

The Racial Hatred Bill is about the protection of groups and individuals from threats of violence and the incitement of racial hatred, which leads inevitably to violence. It enables the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission to conciliate complaints of racial abuse.
This bill is controversial. It has generated much comment and raises difficult issues for the parliament to consider. It calls for a careful decision on principle.
I wish to address the issues most consistently raised in the public debate and then examine the provisions of the bill in detail.

The bill is intended to close a gap in the legal protection available to the victims of extreme racist behaviour. No Australian should live in fear because of his or her race, colour or national or ethnic origin.
The legislation will provide a safety net for racial harmony in Australia, as both a warning to those who might attack the principle of tolerance and an assurance to their potential victims.

Three major inquiries have found gaps in the protection provided by the Racial Discrimination Act. The National Inquiry into Racist Violence, the Australian Law Reform Commission Report into Multiculturalism and the Law, and the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody all argued in favour of an extension of Australia's human rights regime to explicitly protect the victims of extreme racism.

The 1992 report of the National Inquiry into Racist Violence found that while state and territory criminal law punishes the perpetrators of violence, it largely is inadequate to deal with conduct that is a pre-condition of racial violence.
The report documented 60 such incidents. The Law Reform Commission report and the Royal Commission also dealt extensively with examples of extreme racist behaviour.

Since then there has been an upsurge in the activities of extremist racist groups which have resulted in harassment and intimidation of individuals. As well, public gatherings of ethnic communities have been disrupted, sometimes violently. In Sydney, police are investigating seven arson attacks on synagogues in less than four years. In Melbourne there have been reports of teenage gangs targeting Australians of Asian background.
While these incidents are not everyday occurrences, they tear at the fabric of our society and cause immense concern to many of our citizens.

Racism is often a by-product of ignorance and education is an essential part of any response. The Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission has a number of programs which target racism in schools, reinforced by a variety of programs run by educational authorities. The Commission also provides resources to help employers deal with racism in the workplace. The Commission will also be conducting a public education program to promote this legislation upon its passage.

Racism should be responded to by education and by confronting the expression of racist ideas. But legislation is not mutually exclusive of these responses. It is not a choice between legislation or education. Rather, it is in the government's view, a case of using both.

There is no doubt that the Racial Discrimination Act has been a powerful influence on the rejection of racist attitudes over the past two decades. It has forced many people to confront racist views and have them debunked. It can be compared to the contribution of the Sex Discrimination Act over the past 10 years to improving the way women are treated in our society.
This bill has been mainly criticised on the grounds that it limits free expression and that to enact such legislation undermines one of the most fundamental principles of our democratic society.
Yet few of these critics would argue that free expression should be absolute and unfettered.
Throughout Australia, at all levels of government, free expression has had some limits placed on it when there is a countervailing public interest.
Laws dealing with defamation, copyright, obscenity, incitement, official secrecy, contempt of court and parliament, censorship and consumer protection all qualify what can be expressed.
These laws recognise the need to legislate where words can cause serious economic damage, prejudice a fair trial or unfairly damage a person's reputation.
In this bill, free speech has been balanced against the rights of Australians to live free of fear and racial harassment.
Surely the promotion of racial hatred and its inevitable link to violence is as damaging to our community as issuing a misleading prospectus, or breaching the Trade Practices Act.

The bill places no new limits on genuine public debate. Australians must be free to speak their minds, to criticise actions and policies of others and to share a joke. The bill does not prohibit people from expressing ideas or having beliefs, no matter how unpopular the views may be to many other people. The law has no application to private conversations.

Nothing which is said or done reasonably and in good faith in the course of any statement, publication, discussion or debate made or held for an academic, artist, or scientific purpose, or any other purpose in the public interest will be prohibited by the law.

It is worthy of note that New South Wales has had similar legislation for five years and yet no one has seriously argued that free speech has been curtailed there. Nor has it been unduly limited in other Australian jurisdictions where similar legislation exists.

But perhaps most noteworthy are the experiences in other liberal democracies throughout the world that ban racial hatred and violence. Free speech is a constitutional right in Canada and many European countries, yet the highest courts in these countries have held provisions which ban racist hatred and violence in public to be reasonable and necessary. In fact, in 1989 the Canadian Supreme Court upheld Canada's anti-hate legislation.

Recently the Australian High Court has established the existence within the Constitution of an implied guarantee of free expression. The High Court decisions have been closely examined and the government is fully convinced that the bill does not infringe on the principles developed by the Court.

Clearly then, while these are important issues, the Commonwealth parliament is not the first Australian legislature to grapple with them. Criminal laws dealing with the incitement of racial hatred operate in New South Wales, Western Australia, Queensland and the Australian Capital Territory. Civil provisions are also in place in each of these jurisdictions except Western Australia.
New Zealand has had laws of this nature since 1971. Along with Canada, Great Britain and a number of the States of the United States also have specific laws on racial hatred.
The principle of legislating to deal with racial hatred has for sometime enjoyed the support of the leadership of the Federal Liberal Party.
The former Leader of the Opposition, Dr Hewson, in a address to the Zionist Federation in May 1992, said national anti-vilification legislation would be a worthwhile initiative in Australia.

The Federal Coalition's commitment to such legislation was reconfirmed with the release of the Liberal and National Parties 1993 Fightback! Law and Justice Policy by the then-Shadow Attorney-General and now the Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party, the Member for Higgins.
The Fightback! policy document stated unequivocally that:
Inciting fear or damage to people or their property on racial grounds should be prohibited
Mr Costello reaffirmed this commitment in a letter dated 8 February 1993 to Mr Mark Leibler which said of the 1992 draft legislation:
We accept the principles underlying the first part of the bill, which is designed to prevent intentionally stirring up racial hatred fear of violence or injury to person or property.
As recently as May this year the Coalition again publicly endorsed the need for such legislation when its then spokesperson on these matters, the Member for Tangney, Daryl Williams, said:
The Opposition recognises the need for the legislation and, in principle, we accept that legislation should provide criminal sanctions for racial violence and hatred.

The current Leader of the Opposition has also publicly recognised the need for racial hatred legislation and committed himself to supporting such action by this parliament. Only four months ago, in a wide ranging interview reported in the Australian Jewish News, Mr Downer said:

Where there is incitement to violence or to damaging property on the basis of race, then there is no question that should be a criminal offence. You obviously have to find a balance between free speech, on one hand, and ensuring that there isn't incitement to racial vilification in our society.

However the Opposition is not supporting this bill. It has been advanced that the bill restricts freedom of speech and that a model based on the NSW Anti-Discrimination Act 1977 would allay Opposition concerns.

Mr President, let me now detail the provisions of the bill and where appropriate make comparisons with the NSW legislation. I believe that a fair assessment is that while the NSW law is a perfectly workable model, the bill overcomes some deficiencies in the NSW Act and is consistent with the Commonwealth's own human rights regime.
In outline, the bill amends the Crimes Act 1914 to provide for three criminal offences and amends the Racial Discrimination Act 1975 to provide for a civil prohibition.

The criminal provisions do not attempt to replicate the general criminal law which deals with physical violence and the damage to property. Rather the provisions centre on the precursors of actual violence; that is, the incitement of racial hatred and threats made to a person or persons or property because of race, colour or national or ethnic origin.

The bill seeks to close a gap in the operation of current laws by protecting people confronted by situations likely to lead to fear and racist violence. The three criminal provisions to be inserted in the Crimes Act 1914 are set out in clause 4 of the bill. The first 2 offences deal respectively with threats, done because of race, colour or national or ethnic origin, against people and property, while the third prohibits acts done, otherwise than in private, with the intention of inciting racial hatred. I shall speak about each provision in turn.

Proposed section 58 is quite simple in its terms—it creates an offence which requires a person to threaten another because of their race, colour or national or ethnic origin. While the general law affords protection where a person is the subject to physical threat, proposed section 58 will expressly cover such a person where the basis of the threat is the person's race, colour or national or ethnic origin. Perhaps more significantly, it will also afford protection throughout Australia in cases where there is no single person threatened, but a group of people identifiable by their race.

This offence of threatening physical harm to people is based on an assault-type provision (although it does not cover actual battery). The concept of threatening physical harm has been considered judicially on many occasions, and requires that `the person to whom violence is offered, to whom the threat is made, must . . . believe that violence is to be feared': McNamara [1954] VLR 137 at 138.

Proposed section 59 is similar, except that it is directed at cases where a person's property, rather than their own physical safety, is threatened with damage or destruction. Given the serious nature of the conduct to be dealt with by proposed sections 58 and 59, I believe that there is a strong case for including these provisions in the Commonwealth's criminal law.
Proposed section 60 creates a criminal offence in relation to the intentional incitement of racial hatred. There are four elements of the offence:
(1) the offence will only arise in relation to an act done otherwise than in private (note that proposed section 60(2) provides a definition of what acts are taken not to be done in private);
(2) such an act must be done with an intention to incite racial hatred (that is, the offence contains a subjective test);
(3)the act must be done because of race, colour or national or ethnic origin; and
(4)the act must be one which is reasonably likely in all the circumstances to incite racial hatred (that is, the offence contains an objective test).

The term `incitement' is to be regarded as referring to a conscious and motivated act—hence the inclusion of a subjective test as an element of the offence. The travaux preparatoires to the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination refer to `incitement' in the sense of provocation. The travaux also refer to `provocation to violence' against any race or group of persons of another colour or ethnic origin.

The travaux do not define `racial hatred' but it may be inferred by analogy to Article 1 of the Convention that the term `racial hatred' simply means hatred based on race, colour, descent or national or ethnic origin. Thus, the United Kingdom Public Order Act 1986 states that `racial hatred' means hatred against a group of persons defined by reference to colour, race, nationality (including citizenship) or ethnic or national origins. As used in proposed section 60, `hatred' carries its ordinary meaning indicating intense dislike or enmity. It is instructive to compare the use of `hatred' in this bill with section 20D of the New South Wales Anti-Discrimination Act, which refers also to inciting `serious contempt for', or `severe ridicule of', a person or group. This seems to indicate that that Act's use of the terms `incitement of', `serious contempt' or `severe ridicule' makes that Act in some ways broader in scope than the bill which uses the term `incitement to racial hatred'.

In considering whether a particular act, which in other respects satisfies the various elements of the offence in proposed section 60, `is reasonably likely in all the circumstances to incite racial hatred', a court would have to have regard to all the circumstances surrounding the case to determine whether that objective test has been satisfied. Section 20D of the New South Wales Act specifies two things to be included in the means used to incite, namely, where a person threatens physical harm to a person or property, or incites others to so threaten. In this bill, such activity is dealt with by proposed sections 58 and 59. However, it should be noted that if those threats do not incite hatred either because there is no third party present or that person is not incited to hate, there can be no offence under section 20D of the New South Wales Act. This is a serious shortcoming.

Among other things, proposed section 60 would deal with those cases where a person's acts are reasonably likely to incite, against persons of a particular race, colour or national or ethnic origin, intense racial enmity of a kind which is likely to lead to physical harm to persons of that group or damage or destruction of their property. In other words, a person does not necessarily need to actually threaten physical harm to persons or property to commit an offence against section 60.

It needs to be recognised that racial hatred does not exist in a vacuum or for the intellectual satisfaction of those feeling it. Racial hatred provides a climate in which people of a particular race or ethnic origin live in fear and in which discrimination can thrive. It provides the climate in which violence may take place. It is of itself a threat to the well-being of the whole community as well as to individuals or groups in the community. It needs to be confronted.

The kind of behaviour that proposed section 60 is designed to address has been made the subject of criminal sanctions in similar legal and social systems. I refer senators to section 319(2) of the Canadian Criminal Code; section 63 of the Human Rights Act of New Zealand; and section 18 of the United Kingdom Public Order Act.

The bill provides a maximum penalty of 2 years' imprisonment for the offence in proposed section 58 of threatening to harm a person while the offences in proposed sections 59 and 60 of threatening to damage property and incitement to racial hatred, respectively, carry a maximum penalty of 1 year.

I should explain that imprisonment is by no means the only sentencing option available to a court where a person is found guilty of one of these three offences. Where a person is found guilty of any Commonwealth offence, including those which the bill creates, the starting point for a court is found in section 16A of the Crimes Act 1914, which sets out the matters a court must have regard to when sentencing and requires the court to impose a sentence that is `appropriate in all the circumstances of the offence'. To determine the most appropriate sentence, a court is provided with a full range of options, such as fines, bonds or community service orders in additional to imprisonment. For example, section 4B of the Crimes Act provides a mechanism by means of which a term of imprisonment can be converted into a fine.

Commonwealth legislation will be amended following enactment of the bill to provide that where a person or corporation is convicted of a criminal offence under the bill as enacted, that person or corporation will not be eligible to receive a government grant or subsidy. For example, a company convicted of disseminating literature which was found by the court to be reasonably likely to incite racial hatred would not be eligible to receive an export market development grant from the government.
So, in essence, the difference between the Commonwealth bill and the NSW Anti-Discrimination Act in criminal matters turns on the offence of the incitement of racial hatred.

The NSW law does not criminalise as such the making of a threat on the grounds of race, but rather covers threats only where they are means by which racial hatred is incited. In contrast, this bill provides that the making of threats on racial grounds is an offence of itself.

Threats may often be associated with the incitement of racial hatred. However in the government's view, a threat to violence is of sufficient concern to be a specific criminal offence even when it is not a factor in the incitement of racial hatred.
The bill also provides for a civil regime by the amendment of the Racial Discrimination Act.
Section 18C will be inserted in the Act to make it unlawful for a person to do an act, otherwise than in private, if:
(a) The act is reasonably likely in all the circumstances to offend, insult, humiliate or intimidate another person or group of people; and
(b) The act is done because of the race, colour or national or ethnic origin of the other person or of some or all of the people in the group.
A number of initial points need to be made.

First, the provision is civil and not criminal in effect. That is, the process will be initiated by the victim of alleged unlawful behaviour via a complaint to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission and not by police investigations.

Secondly, like all complaints under Commonwealth human rights laws, the Commission will endeavour to resolve the matter by private and confidential conciliation. Only if conciliation cannot resolve the matter is there a public hearing and a determination by the Commission.
The Commission can immediately dismiss frivolous or vexatious complaints.
The format of the civil provision is similar to the model used in other Commonwealth human rights legislation such as the Sex Discrimination Act. It is—
based upon the availability of a remedy in specified circumstances,
judged against the objective criteria of what is reasonably likely in all the circumstances to give rise to a valid complaint, and
limited and targeted through the use of exemptions.

The requirement that the behaviour complained about should `offend, insult, humiliate or intimidate' is the same as that used to establish sexual harassment in the Sex Discrimination Act. The Commission is familiar with the scope of such language and has applied it in a way that deals with serious incidents only.
The bill requires an objective test to be applied by the Commission so that community standards to behaviour rather than the subjective views of the complainant are taken into account.
The exemptions are broad and cover acts done
in the performance, exhibition or distribution of an artistic work,
in the course of discussion or debate for an academic, artistic or scientific purpose or other purpose in the public interest, and
in making or publishing a report or comment on a matter in the public interest.

Under proposed section 18E an employer may be vicariously liable for the unlawful acts of an employee. However the employer has a complete defence if it is established he or she took all reasonable steps to prevent the employee from doing the unlawful act. This provision is in terms similar to section 106 of the Sex Discrimination Act and section 18A of the Racial Discrimination Act. The terms of section 123 of the Disability Discrimination Act achieve the same result.

The NSW Anti-Discrimination Act also contains, in section 20C, a civil prohibition of the incitement of hatred towards, serious contempt for, or severe ridicule of a person or group on the ground of race.

The provision is likewise qualified by exemptions and vicarious liability was extended to employers by an amendment to the Act this year. The difference between the Commonwealth and NSW provisions turn on the description of the conduct giving rise to a potential complaint and the extent of the exceptions.
It is arguable whether these differences would greatly alter the work of either the Commonwealth or NSW human rights bodies.

In the government's view, this bill is to be preferred over other models because it represents the sum of experiences in these jurisdictions. There are procedural defects in the NSW legislation and the allied system of administration required by the law, particularly the procedure for referring civil complaints to the Director of Public Prosecution without the benefit of any criminal investigation.
The Commonwealth bill reflects the input of public comment on the 1992 draft bill.
The bill is simpler, more focused and easier to administer. It targets circumstances which are preliminary to violence. It does not attempt to replicate laws dealing with actual violence.
It has a clear distinction between civil and criminal prohibitions. It fills a gap in our laws and enhances the social compact which underpins racial harmony in Australia.
Australia has a very proud record of protecting and promoting human rights. This parliament, as it should have, has led the nation in legislating to protect and enhance all Australians human rights.

The legislative regime, including the Racial Discrimination Act, Sex Discrimination Act, Disability Discrimination Act passed by this parliament are a clear demonstration Australia's commitment to basic human rights.
We are fortunate in that Australia has a significant degree of social cohesion and racial harmony.

This bill is an appropriate and measured response to closing the identified gap in the legal protection of all Australians from extreme racist behaviour. It strikes a balance between the right of free speech and the other rights and interests of Australia and Australians.

It provides a safety net for racial harmony in Australia and sends a clear warning to those who might attack the principle of tolerance. And importantly this bill provides Australians who are the victims of racial hatred or violence with protection.
I table the explanatory memorandum for the bill.
I commend the bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of these amendments is to provide 100 per cent discount for farm assets under the Austudy assets test. For the past four years, the Australian Democrats have been moving amendments to exempt the family farm from the assets test and for the past four years we have received little support from the Liberal, National or Labor parties. As we know, the government's drought package relaxed the assets test for farmers in exceptional drought areas. The Democrats, however, believe that the assets test is currently discriminating against all farmers and has done so for many years. Children from farming families deserve and have a right to receive the same level of government encouragement and support to continue their studies that city children enjoy.

PARA.TAB: The last time I moved an amendment of this sort, it was referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs. That committee received well over 100 submissions and each and every one of those—with the exception of the submission from the Department of Social Security—spoke of the inequity in the assets test as it impacts on farm families. One only needs to see that the average value of a broadacre farm is around $900,000 to realise how this inequity arises. That $900,000 in assets is simply what is needed to have some semblance of long-term viability in farming these days. It does not include any luxury items or any personal assets, it just includes basic farm business assets.

With the level of assets in 1992-93, Australia's broadacre farmers returned an average loss of around $17,500 for the year. They are expected to show a loss of around $6,000 in 1993-94. So, we have families who are losing substantial amounts of money but who are not able to access the majority of government payments. On top of that is the fact that, after we add up the transport, boarding and other costs, rural parents have to pay around $7,000 per annum more than their city counterparts to educate their children. The Democrats amendment not only recognises that farmers are often asset rich but income poor but also acknowledges that those farm assets are business assets and, as such, should not be included in the Austudy assets test.

In closing, I will read to the Senate a couple of comments on the issue that have been made recently by members of the Liberal and National Party coalition. Firstly, when debating this bill in House of Representatives, the opposition's previous shadow minister for schools, Mr Miles, said:

SPEECH.PARA: It seems a gross injustice that properties or farms are included under the Austudy assets test . . . . . . . . . . . .
This is one of the greatest anomalies and inequities of the Austudy system and, undoubtedly, it disadvantages rural students.
Mr Miles is quite correct. Secondly, in a letter to the editor of the Murray Pioneer, Senator Ferguson said:

The Coalition is genuinely concerned about the impact Austudy asset tests have on rural families endeavouring to further their children's education. Undoubtedly, assets tests for such families can be discriminatory, as many of them have significant farm business assets but relatively low to negative incomes.
Senator Ferguson went on to say:

The Liberal Party has had a long and proud history of upholding the rights of rural people and of condemning the discrimination they often face from Labor policies that appear to favour city dwellers.

Again, Senator Ferguson is quite right. I can only assume from the sentiments very clearly expressed in those quotes that the Liberal and National parties are going to support my amendment. The amendment reflects the policy of the National Farmers Federation, and I am sure that it reflects the wishes of every farming family in Australia. Regardless of what might happen in subsequent amendments, I urge the Senate to support this amendment to provide a 100 per cent discount on farm assets under the Austudy assets test.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am astonished to hear what the Australian Democrats are seeking to do today, because it is inconsistent with the position that they have advocated previously. And it seems to me to be inconsistent with the amendment that they had previously circulated in this place.

PARA.TAB: I have to confess at the outset that I am a little at a loss, because Senator Gibson, who had the conduct of this matter on our behalf, is on parliamentary business in New Zealand. He had left the matter in the capable hands of Senator Tierney, who has been caught in Newcastle as a result of the transport workers' industrial action. If the government would get its industrial relations in order, we might be better equipped in this debate.

Nevertheless, the position which the Australian Democrats had put on a previous occasion—and, as I understand it, amendments had been circulated in the name of Senator Bell—was the position that we had supported. That position is that if a farmer qualifies for a health care card because of very low income, he or she should be exempt from the assets test for the purpose of Austudy for his or her children. We ourselves have previously adopted that position in this chamber—

TALK.START.PARA: —And we've been successful.

—We have had it carried. We have supported it because it seems logical and sensible in the current circumstances. There is a tragedy in rural Australia at the moment; so many Australian farmers have found their income has been reduced to negligible levels—in some instances to a nil level—as a result of prolonged drought. I guess we have all heard of tragic circumstances where, in previously good, productive areas of Australia, there has not been effective rain for four years. So, in effect, farmers have had no real income for that incredibly long period.

PARA.TAB: The education of the farmers' children is a matter of national importance. As I have travelled around educational establishments in rural Australia, I have found that there is a very deep concern that the children of farmers are suffering. When I recently went to the university at Armidale, I was told that students simply were not attending classes. When I asked why, I was told that they could no longer afford the fuel to get themselves to the university for lectures. This is a national tragedy and it has to be addressed.

We know the unsatisfactory aspects of the drought response of the government. But that is just part of the issue. Another part of it is how we look at supporting the education of rural children in this very difficult situation. As I have said, it seemed to us that, if because of very low income farmers qualify for a health card, an assets test should not be applied to those farmers in calculating whether or not they receive Austudy support for the education of their children.

That position, as I recall it, was supported by the government—in fact, the government indicated publicly that it would support it. The government instructed its bureaucrats to prepare the forms, told rural Australia that this would be its position, that it would give support to rural children in this way, and then reneged on that promise. What we have sought to do in this chamber is hold the government to that promise. Whenever we have had the opportunity, we have moved an amendment of this sort. As Senator Teague interjected, we have had support for it previously from the Australian Democrats. We have therefore had the numbers and the amendment has been carried. But, regrettably, despite the pressure that has been applied to the government, it has not positively responded and has not been prepared to address the needs of rural children in this way. In circumstances where the Australian Democrats seem to have now abandoned this—

TALK.START.PARA: —You can only move one at a time.

—It is a very confusing situation. Senator Woodley seems to have come in with a new approach today. I do not know who is speaking for the Australian Democrats on this matter today. I guess they will have the opportunity to seek to clarify their position, but it looks as though there is a Queensland push that has come down and is overriding the Tasmanian position, or perhaps there is another explanation. Unfortunately, all they are really doing is leaving a very confusing environment for the Australian rural community.

PARA.TAB: We will stand by the position that we have advocated and received support for before. Presuming the Australian Democrats are now no longer going to move the amendment that Senator Bell previously circulated, at an appropriate time, when this particular amendment before the committee has been dealt with, we will move an amendment that says that where farmers qualify for a health card the assets test should not apply for Austudy calculations.

At an appropriate time in this committee debate we will also seek to make a further amendment in relation to exceptional circumstances. This will apply to some farmers. It is hard to see that, if they do not qualify for the health card, they will not fit within exceptional circumstances. Senator Boswell might clarify that. Nevertheless, it does seem to us that, as well as the exceptional circumstances that currently exist within rural Australia, a further exemption should apply to families as defined by regulation 13(1)(a) of the Austudy regulations. When families are in exceptional circumstances the minister should be able to exempt them from the other requirements for Austudy. They should also be supported in that way.

In other words, if rural families can come under one of the two tests—either they are getting a health card because of low income or they are under the exceptional circumstance provisions—they should be exempted from the other Austudy restrictions and the community should be prepared to support them in the education of their children during this period of great difficulty in rural Australia. With both of those amendments being carried, we believe that we will be supporting Australian rural children in an appropriate way.

We will also be waiting anxiously for a Senate committee report on the education of rural children, the application of assets tests and other such matters. It would be very helpful for the chamber to be further informed of this debate. I understand that report is likely to be put down within the next couple of weeks. If so, that will be a very helpful contribution to this debate in the future. I am sure we are going to have a debate in the future because the government is showing no signs at all of positively responding.

Senator Woodley's contribution this morning seems to me to create an inequitable situation between small business in rural Australia and those actually farming in rural Australia. Both are suffering at the moment, so why withdraw certain of the assets of one group and not of the other group? Small business, one of the service industries in rural Australia, is a further element of the tragedy of the drought that has been given insufficient consideration or care by government in addressing this matter of great concern. It seems to have been completely overlooked by the Australian Democrats in their contribution this morning. Senator Woodley might explain to the chamber why he has decided to overlook small business and to draw further inequities between those who are on the land and those who are, hopefully, trying to draw income from servicing those on the land. Surely their children are being as much affected and deserve as much attention and support as the children of those directly earning their income from the land.

This amendment on the run by Senator Woodley to hopefully gain a little further rural support for the Australian Democrats, who are proving themselves to be totally ineffective representatives of these communities, has been drawn up in a way that results in inequities and inconsistencies. I guess that demonstrates the real motive of the amendment, and that is to try to win points rather than address the needs of rural Australia in a considered and sensible way.

I do not believe the case has been made out for Senator Woodley's amendment—from what I have heard so far anyway in this debate. I urge the Australian Democrats to stand by their previous position. We know that we will have the numbers and can put a bit of pressure on the government to respond positively, that is, to support the health care amendments and also our suggested amendments on exceptional circumstances. Then at least we will be doing something positive for rural Australia today.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a Senate inquiry now—I think Senator Woodley is on the inquiry—that is investigating Austudy. It will bring down its recommendations in a couple of weeks. That is the time we should be looking at this amendment. Maybe that is the way to go; I do not know. Maybe that is what the Senate inquiry will establish. But, until the report of that inquiry does come down, the amendment that we have moved is a substantial amendment that will not only catch farmers who are being affected by the drought—and the 1,900 woolgrowers in exceptional circumstances—but also pick up all those small businesses that are suffering as a consequence of the lack of income of farmers. The small businesses in the towns that service farmers are probably suffering just as much, or even more in some cases.

PARA.TAB: The health card amendment that has been proposed by the Liberal and National parties will pick up all the farmers Senator Woodley has mentioned. Anyone on an income under $23,000 a year—and there are not too many people in rural Australia, certainly in western rural Australia, at the moment who are making that sort of money—will get picked up. The businesses in the major towns that are servicing rural Australia will also be able to access Austudy.

It is a good amendment because out in the community it is fair. It does not divide the community; it gives all people the same opportunities. It is based on need and on income. Everyone whose income is below a certain figure—and we acknowledge that there is very little positive income out there; it is mostly zero income or even negative income—will get picked up whether they are a rural producer or a small business. That has some sort of equity about it. The Senate inquiry that has spent a considerable amount of time investigating this may come up with a recommendation that there is a need to remove assets tests for farmers. If that is the case, we will look at it then.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let's put the whole thing off. You might as well. Is that what you are saying?

—No. Senator Woodley is doing some good work on this Senate inquiry. If the Senate goes to the considerable amount of trouble of taking a reference on notice and calling witnesses, then we should listen to what the Senate inquiry recommends. It may well recommend what Senator Woodley is suggesting. If that is the case, let us advance down that path in two weeks time.
—We'll never get there.

—You will get there. We have been consistent on this; both the Democrats and the opposition have been pursuing this matter since June. I do not know how many times we have addressed the issue—this is probably the fourth time, to my memory. We have consistently pushed and carried these amendments, only to have them knocked back by the government, despite the fact that the government in its July budget not only recommended but also asked students to apply for Austudy if their parents were able to access the health care card.

PARA.TAB: When students applied they found that the government had done a backflip. After building up the expectations of a number of students, particularly rural students, the government pulled the rug right out from under them. Virtually no rural students would have been able to access Austudy if it were not for the tremendous pressure put on the government by a number of us over here—and I include the Democrats—to get the drought relief package up, which included Austudy for farmers in the grip of drought and removed the assets test from them.

The amendment we are moving at the moment picks up everyone in need, including farmers. No-one will be excluded by the amendment we are moving who would have been picked up by Senator Woodley's amendment. So all farmers with a low income, a negative income or a minus income will be able to access Austudy, and so will the small businesses in rural Australia that are dependent on the farmers. Because the farmers are not spending, the small businesses are not receiving sales and so they are being adversely affected. For the time being this is quite an acceptable amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is an example of the difficulty that we have when we are trying to listen to a debate here while, at the same time, the Economics Legislation Committee is having a meeting, which I want to attend now, at which farmers, particularly citrus farmers, are talking about the problems of taxation on the rural industry. I cannot be in two places at one time. That is why I object, quite frankly, to these committees sitting at the same time as the Senate is sitting. This amendment is of great importance to the whole of Australia. It is important to farmers because they are, in effect, the backbone of this country in many cases. Many of them at present are in dire straits. Indeed, the worst form of child abuse in some places in Australia is for a farmer, when he croaks, to leave the farm to his children. People in the bush are in dire straits.

PARA.TAB: I am concerned to try to listen to the debate as well as prepare for this other meeting. I have to attend the other meeting now. I understand that an inquiry regarding assistance is taking place. It is not really assistance; the taxation system itself is discriminating against all families with children, particularly one-income families with children. In many cases farm families only have one income—and not a very good income.

Of course, in general, we are all in sympathy with what Senator Woodley is proposing. But what has been put forward by the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Hill) and the Leader of the National Party of Australia in the Senate (Senator Boswell) bears consideration. Unfortunately, I will not be able to hear the debate. I wonder whether the proposition that I heard being put forward by them—that this matter that has been raised by Senator Woodley might be better dealt with by way of a recommendation of the committee which is looking at the matter—should be considered. In the meantime, the health care card option that was being put forward and which I thought was generally agreed to around the place—

TALK.START.PARA: —It was passed by the Senate.
—I know. That is why I said it was agreed to around the place. I thought that was it for the time being.
—It was agreed to by everybody except the government.
