—Yes. I thought that that was it. So I apologise that I will not be here during the consideration of Senator Woodley's amendment because I have to attend this other meeting.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind the committee what we are actually doing here. We are supposed to be considering Senator Woodley's amendment which he has moved during this committee stage of the passage of the Student Assistance (Budget Matters) Amendment Bill 1994. The matter was debated on 20 September. Certainly, the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Hill) has been unable to remember what occurred then. In some ways it is a short period of time and we should be able to expect people to remember what occurred. But in other ways it is an inordinately long period of time for the passage of some quite simple arrangements.

PARA.TAB: I think it would be instructive if, for the benefit of the Leader of the Opposition, I were to quote from a contribution made to the debate at that time. I know Senator Hill probably would not have bothered to listen to this, but I said at the time:

SPEECH.PARA: This is not the first time we have tried to reform Austudy in this way.
This was in response to the accusation that the amendments were being made on the run and that there was a change. I said at the time:

I could be reading from a number of speeches given by me and my Democrat colleagues Senator Lees and Senator Woodley over the past four years. I could quote from past, well-meaning speeches and press releases from the coalition—and I am sure Senator Kemp will be interested in this. One was in 1991 by the then shadow minister, Dr David Kemp.
I said that he claimed—and I quote:
Families with little or no real income are being excluded by the assets test from Austudy and as a result are having to withdraw their children from education.

We heard a repeat of that. There were crocodile tears from the opposition. Senator Hill went on with some story about how he went to Armidale and was impressed by the fact that people were no longer contributing or taking part in education because they could not afford the trip to Armidale. Having been impressed by that, he was moved to see that there was a need for reform.

PARA.TAB: There has been a need for reform for several years, and we have been attempting to do it. In September, we foreshadowed that Senator Woodley would move an amendment. If there is any doubt as to that fact, page 1001 of the Hansard of 20 September states:

SPEECH.PARA: I foreshadow that we will move an amendment to this bill which will remove the tools of trade from the assets test for rural families. We will do that in the committee stage.

Here it is. It is in front of us. It has been foreshadowed. It was not made on the run. It was consistent with what we have been doing for four years. It is here, and senators have the opportunity. What did we hear from the opposition? We heard only an extraordinary proposition—some sort of joke; as if it were a time to joke—about Queensland and Tasmania and the Democrats not knowing what they were doing. We know what we are doing. We are consistent. We will move the amendment.

PARA.TAB: The amendment is here again for the opposition to make its mind up about it. Will the opposition support it or not? The opposition did not actually give an answer or a reason why it would not support it; it just spent a lot of time telling the world how good the health care card amendment was. We know that. We passed it. I foreshadowed I would move it again. Senator Hill made some joke about the fact that we could not both speak at once and move the same amendment.

I tell those opposite—and we are talking about Senator Woodley's amendment—to either cop up and vote for it or be branded for what they are: a bunch of weak people who cannot make up their minds about what to do to help the rural situation in Australia. That is what they will have to wear. They should either vote for it or be branded that way.

When the opposition does not vote for it, I will move that amendment, as was distributed on 20 September, which will ensure that those who are in receipt of a health care card will be eligible for assistance under Austudy without having their assets tested. The opposition should not come in here and try to befuddle Australia's voters with some sort of nonsense—its silly, petty little school boy jokes—about who ought to be moving what. It is moved. It is there. Vote for it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I fully support the summary of my colleague Senator Hill of the opposition's position on the Student Assistance (Budget Matters) Amendment Bill and on this amendment moved by Senator Woodley. It is a fact that the words of Senator Woodley's amendment have not been debated in the chamber before. I concede to Senator Bell, who has made some very substantial contributions on education matters over these last four years, that there have been intimations about the best way to meet the needs of children in the bush.

PARA.TAB: I agree that we have all debated various forms of words that might be the best solution to gain equity and justice for rural families, especially those in the dire straits of this continuing drought. The Liberal and National parties will not allow anyone to hold a candle to us for the great light that we want to give to the need for justice for rural families. That is why we have been consistently arguing that there should be the same test, the same concession, for student allowances, which is eligibility for the health care card.

It is that position that the opposition will adopt as soon as this amendment is disposed of. Senator Hill has circulated the opposition's amendment, which is in the same form as the amendment that I moved on behalf of the opposition six months ago and which the Democrats happily supported. We placed it within the Student Assistance Amendment Bill 1994, which was then in front of the Senate.

I do not want to repeat the comprehensive summary on this matter that was given by Senator Hill. However, I want to add one additional argument as to why the chamber should adopt the same position on this bill as the one we had six months ago on the Student Assistance Amendment Bill 1994. The House of Representatives—that is, the government, because it has a majority there—put to the parliament six months ago an amendment to the Student Assistance Act that made a number of improvements to student assistance arrangements. In addition to those improvements, which we all supported, the opposition moved an additional motion whereby families that are eligible for the health card would be freed of an assets test so that their children and other family members could gain student assistance.

That was the Senate's position. But when this measly government—this Labor Party—got that bill back in the House of Representatives, with the whole bill agreed to by the Senate but with a Senate amendment in addition, the measly minister in the House of Representatives said, `We will not proceed with this bill any further.' So it remains just lying on the table in the House of Representatives.

If the House of Representatives understood the arguments put in the Senate for assistance to rural families being on the basis of need, as tested by eligibility for the health card, the minister would pick up the bill from last June, proceed with it and get all the benefits that were in the government's original bill in addition to this widely accepted standard for helping rural families.

I put this argument to the chamber: now that we have another piece of legislation related to student assistance, it is appropriate that we put the same amendment. If the government again takes the measly route of rejecting all of these measures, it will then be stacking up two bills that we all agree with. We are adding the same amendment. Will the government come back with a third bill for student assistance matters so that we will put the same amendment on it? The government will have piling higher and higher a series of bills which the parliament accepts. The Senate, by a clear majority, wants rural families assisted on an equitable and comprehensive basis that does not divide farmers from small business operators. It wants to go about this on the basis of an accepted test, which is eligibility for the health card. So I put it to this committee that the appropriate way forward is for us to support Senator Hill's amendment, which relates to the health card test, and not Senator Woodley's amendment, which is now before us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think a few more things need to be said. Perhaps some explanation should be given if, as Senator Hill and other contributors from the coalition say, they do not understand the background to the amendment that I have moved this morning. It is a little hard to understand, because our staff have been negotiating for some weeks to try to get agreement and to find out what the coalition will support. Our problem has been that the coalition has not told us.

PARA.TAB: Senator Bell interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —That has been the other problem. We spoke originally to the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Miles), then to Senator Hill's office and to Senator Boswell's office, but they have not indicated to us which amendment of ours they will support. We have brought both amendments onto the floor so that we can have them before us.

PARA.TAB: We indicate that the amendment relating to the health care card, already moved by Senator Bell, is the one we will be supporting further down the track. Senators need to understand that, as Senator Teague has pointed out, the government has already rejected the amendment relating to the health care card. I suspect that it will have the same fate when it gets to the House of Representatives. In order to have a fall-back position, we are therefore moving this particular amendment, which has been circulated today. We admit that it does not assist small businesses. We do not want to make a differentiation between two groups of disadvantaged people—

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the health care card?
—We will support the health care card.
—Give it to both.

—That is what we want to do, so we want you to support both amendments. The problem is that the inquiry we have had has indicated very clearly the problems rural families are facing. I am disappointed that, although the coalition was so concerned about small business, it did not get small businesses to appear before that inquiry. We could have then had the evidence which is so clear now. Admittedly, the report has not been handed down, but I am totally convinced by the evidence which has been presented. It has reinforced over and over again the situation of farming families. I am not going to abandon them simply because I cannot help another group within the society. I want to help both groups, but if I can only help one at a time then I will certainly do that.

PARA.TAB: I understand the problem that particularly the National Party and my colleague Senator Boswell have. Let me return the compliment: there is no doubt about the work he does in Queensland and throughout Australia on behalf of farming families. But he would know that all of the peak farmer groups have been pressing constantly for the amendment which I have moved this morning. In fact, I will read from letters received from them. A letter from the Victorian Farmers Federation states:

SPEECH.PARA: The VFF has noted your initiatives to have the Senate exclude farm assets from the Austudy assets test. We support those initiatives completely as this is our preferred policy.
The Western Australian Farmers Federation said:
The Western Australian Farmers Federation gives full support to the proposed Student Assistance (Budget Matters) Amendment Bill as forwarded to us earlier today.
The Queensland Farmers Federation said:

Thank you for your letter setting out the proposed amendment to the Student Assistance Bill. The proposed amendment to exempt 100 per cent of farm assets for Austudy assets test is in line with the policy of the Queensland Farmers Federation. We support this proposal and wish you all the best for its success in the Senate.

I am trying to fulfil what the farmers are asking and also support the health care card amendment, because that will pick up a number of the other people who are also disadvantaged. We certainly do not want to divide the community but, by the same token, we do not want to abandon one section of the community if we can help it just because another section is not being helped at the same time. Let us do both things.

PARA.TAB: Surely we would want to do something about the incredible problems in rural Australia where communities, farms and families are simply being abandoned because people can no longer afford to remain in those communities or on those farms and to educate their children and to put food on the table. I believe that we need both of these amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: Certainly, I would press both amendments and ask the opposition to support both of them.

PARA.TAB: I might add that the Democrats do not control the business of the Senate. If it had been possible for this bill to have been held over until the inquiry had completed its business, we would have been happy with that. But, now that the matter is before us, we are not going to lose the opportunity to assist some farm families by way of my amendment and to assist additional people who would also be assisted by way of the amendment relating to the health care card.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bell really gave the game away when he indicated, in effect, that the Australian Democrats' amendment is an attack on the coalition. There had to be an extraordinary explanation for the Democrats' attempt to discriminate against small business in rural areas. The health care card proposal, which we both accept, would help all of those farmers and people within rural communities who are greatly in need at the moment. The Australian Democrats know that, but they want to take the political issue one step further to try to distinguish their position from that of the coalition.

PARA.TAB: The Democrats have no interest at all in joining with the coalition to apply pressure on the government, because that is not what they are about. This is just a cheap attempt to try to indicate to rural communities that the Democrats are taking the matter one step further. Yet, as Senator Woodley acknowledged, they are not. Those who gain under the health care card proposal are also covered by Senator Woodley's latest initiative. It is therefore unnecessary. If it is unnecessary in terms of benefiting the rural community, there has to be some extraordinary explanation for the Democrats' course of action, and that is that they want to distinguish their position ever so slightly from ours.

The Democrats are attempting to try to win a constituency that is in deep distress at the moment without making any real attempt to put pressure on the government, which is the only body that can actually benefit these people. We do not appropriate the benefits; the government must do it. What we can do is simply join together to apply the greatest pressure. The Australian Democrats have indicated today that they will abandon joining with us in an attempt to try to gain a few extra votes out of tragic circumstances. That is a major indictment of the Democrats. They ought to be ashamed and embarrassed by what they are seeking to do here today.

The Democrats have an opportunity to take a stand on a position that is well known and that we have joined together on before in order to keep the government to its promise. That is the best chance of getting this negligent government to perform. It is the best chance for us to consistently stand by an agreed position. This is an amendment that we have moved before. This is an amendment that we have constantly supported. This is an amendment that we will move, in view of the fact that the Australian Democrats want to abandon it today.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!

—Senator Woodley laughs, but the point remains that his amendment will not assist any more people than those who are already going to benefit under the health care card proposal. So why move this amendment? Because he wants to win a few votes out of tragic circumstances. What an indictment of the Australian Democrats. It is just a further demonstration that they really ought to be on the other side of the chamber rather than standing here and attempting to indicate that they offer an independent third party position. They do not. When it comes to the crunch, they will never put any real pressure on the government at all. They walk away from that. They simply try to exploit a situation of tragedy to gain a few votes out there in the rural community. That will not work either.

PARA.TAB: It is a matter of great disappointment to see the way the Democrats are behaving today. As has been said, the Senate committee will soon bring down a report which will advise us as to whether the health care card proposal that we have had support for is the best way to pursue the matter further in the future. We will no doubt give serious consideration to the Senate committee's advice to this chamber for the future.

But that report is not before us at the moment. What is before us at the moment is this bill that the government is insisting on pursuing today. We are saying to the Australian Democrats: let us stand by our agreed position; let us put the ultimate pressure that we are able to exert upon the government rather than simply trying to win a few votes out of what I described as tragic circumstances.

I thought I would hear from Senator Woodley why he wishes to discriminate between those on the land and those in small business servicing them, divide the rural community and further exacerbate the stress that is being experienced out there in rural Australia at the moment. We did not receive a satisfactory explanation. Therefore, I simply urge him at the last moment to join with us and support the health care proposal rather than to pursue the course that he has outlined this morning.

TALK.START.PARA: —He could withdraw.

—He could withdraw it, but he will not because that is contrary to the political objective that he is seeking to achieve. He should support us on the health care proposal and then we can continue to apply whatever pressure we are able to on this government to perform and to keep its promises.

—I think Senator Hill is a little confused. I am sorry about that because the advice he gives the chamber is usually so clear. I hear him arguing against himself. If I should wait until the inquiry completes its business and the report is handed down before I move my amendment, why is the same reasoning not used in terms of the health care card. The opposition is pressing that amendment today. I have noticed that not only is Senator Bell moving an amendment in that regard but also the opposition is moving the same amendment.

PARA.TAB: It seems to me that Senator Hill is very confused. Senator Hill just explained to us that we need to wait until the report tells us whether the health care card or my amendment is the one which is more practical, yet the opposition is pressing the health care card amendment today. The opposition has brought it in as a further amendment to the amendment already moved by Senator Gibson.

The problem is that the coalition is rather confused at this stage. That is a shame because I think we all want the best outcome possible. We certainly will be pressing our amendment and we will be supporting the amendment moved by Senator Bell or the coalition relating to the health care card. What the Democrats want is a guarantee that both of these amendments will cover all the possibilities. I have been advised that the health care card amendment and my amendment do not cover the same group of people. There are people who will be helped and assisted by both amendments. That is the reason I need to continue to press my amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was subjected to a great deal of misrepresentation and misunderstanding in the contribution that Senator Hill just made. That was probably because he does not have the grace to listen to the contributions we make. I listened very intently to every word uttered by Senator Hill because I was looking to see whether his position was consistent with that previously put by the other spokespersons for the Liberal Party on this matter.

PARA.TAB: We have to make sure that what has been presented to us by the previous shadow minister, Mr Miles, the previous carrier in this chamber, Senator Gibson, a previous spokesperson and chair of the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training, Senator Tierney, the sometime spokesperson Senator Hill, and the passionate contributor Senator Teague, not to mention the odd contributions—I do not mean that in a pejorative sense—of Senator Crane and even the occasional contribution from Senator Troeth and others is consistent with what Senator Hill has put. Those contributors were present when I made the Democrats' position clear on 21 September this year. That was only a restatement of the position that had been placed on the record by Senator Lees and me—this was before Senator Woodley came into this place—in 1992. We were only restating then that we would seek to have a situation whereby the tools of trade would not be part of the Austudy assets test.

If Senator Hill has suddenly discovered that this move will not benefit all those who earn their living from, and who contribute to, rural Australia, I can only agree with him. It will not help the police, the teachers, the meatworkers, the council employees, or the barman at the bowls club at Bourke. Let me tell the coalition that all of those people are greatly affected by the drought that we find in Australia at the moment. As a matter of fact, at the drought inquiry of the Senate committee on rural and regional affairs, which inquired into this matter in 1992, it was the barman at the bowls club in Bourke who told me how greatly the drought did affect the people in the rural communities.

These people cannot be helped by Senator Woodley's proposition which, I remind honourable senators, we are debating. Senator Woodley's proposition does not intend to help those people. We cannot take into account every little permutation and culmination of human behaviour when we are legislating. What we can do is start and move through. This is the start to help those most directly affected.

Having helped those most directly affected, we see a reason for also recognising the assistance that will be given by the health care card. That is why on 21 September this year I foreshadowed that I would move such an amendment. Honourable senators have before them that very same amendment. I acknowledge that it was Senator Teague's amendment which was passed in this place—attached to a different set of legislation—and passed by us with great agreement and enthusiasm. It will be received in exactly the same way. Let us not be petty about who does in fact move this amendment. Let us not be petty about that and try to score points. We will support it; I foreshadowed that we would support it. In fact, honourable senators have before them, in my name, that very amendment. But we are not discussing that.

We are discussing the reasons for not supporting the amendment moved by Senator Woodley. Such a pathetic list of excuses I have never heard before. All this shillyshallying about, and trying to move the debate onto another matter, will not save Senator Hill. This is a perfectly good amendment. It is supported by the farming representative bodies. It cannot be denied by us. It is an amendment which is consistent with four years worth of work that we have presented to this place. It is an amendment which Senator Boswell is under great pressure to accept on behalf of the rural representatives.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you explained that it discriminates against small business?

—I am certainly not saying that it will discriminate against small business; it is a step on the way to recognising the greatest assistance that can be given to those most directly affected now. If the coalition is concerned about small business, perhaps it could stand accused of not making any effort whatsoever to bring in a similar amendment to assist small business. There are opportunities for small businesses which do not receive any income at all to be covered by the health care card. There are many businesses which receive some income and therefore are ineligible for the health care card, but which would receive great assistance from an attitude similar to this one. An amendment which addressed itself to and came from the same sort of philosophy would be accepted and supported by us.

PARA.TAB: Here we are with an opportunity to support those farmers who are most directly affected. What does the coalition do? It turns its back on them. It turns its back on them on an artificial premise that the amendment does not help everybody. It cannot help everybody. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) is affected by the drought. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Downer) is affected by the drought. Does the coalition want us to bring in legislation to name them and to help them? Goodness gracious, where do we stop? We cannot take a ridiculous argument like the coalition's and make sense of it.

We cannot possibly legislate to assist everybody in Australia who is affected by the drought. Everybody in Australia is affected by the drought. If Senator Alston tries to deny that, I think he had better go back to his box and not contribute to this debate at all. He comes in here with five minutes worth of contribution and gets it all wrong, so he had better scurry out again. The amendment in front of us can assist those most directly affected by the drought.

Let us see whether the opposition is going to turn its back on the farming sector and deny it any assistance whatsoever. Let us see whether it has any capacity to help Australia's farming community or whether it wants to use very clever little artificial debating devices to avoid it. I know which one it is going to choose because of its track record. Every time we have tried to do something like this to assist Australia's farmers, what does the government do? It finds some artificial device to weasel out of it.

The last time we had this debate former Senator Walters led the charge for the opposition. Former Senator Walters said that it would ruin the economy, that we could not possibly give this sort of support. One time before, I think, Senator Crane argued that it was not going to assist everybody; therefore it could not possibly be passed. Here again, we have that same sort of idea perpetuated. We cannot cover all the bases and assist every single soul in Australia who is affected by the drought, and let us not forget that everybody is affected by the drought—

TALK.START.PARA: —How is it affecting your income?
—The price of bread is going up, or haven't you noticed?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask Senator Woodley: when will the Senate inquiry reach a conclusion and when will the report be put forward?

—I do not know the answer to the question, unfortunately, because I am not the chairman of the committee. The committee is working as hard as it can at the moment, I understand, to conclude that report, but I do not have that information immediately in front of me. I could, no doubt, find out the answer.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —It would make it much easier if we had the report. We are flying in the dark at the moment. A great deal of work has gone into that report over a number of months. It has probably cost this parliament a huge amount of money. Yet we are now asked to make a decision without the report. I reiterate that no-one, no farmer, will be excluded from being picked up by Senator Woodley's amendment who would be excluded from being picked up by the amendment that we are putting forward.

PARA.TAB: I have thought about this. I cannot see that any farmer would be excluded by our amendment. Certainly, our amendment picks up a lot of rural and regional Australians and small business that would not be picked up by the amendment that Senator Woodley has moved. It really would be helpful if we had the report from the Senate inquiry that Senator Woodley has been involved in to make these decisions.

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with Senator Boswell. It would be helpful to have that report. But, as I said before, the evidence which we have had confirms it constantly and any further evidence will simply confirm what we already know. I understand Senator Boswell's problem. I am very sympathetic to what he is saying. We tried to negotiate on this, and I know how hard Senator Boswell has tried.

PARA.TAB: This morning we received an amendment in Senator Hill's name. If we had known even a couple of days ago that the coalition was going to support the idea of a health care card, we could have taken it on board and maybe we could have been convinced by it. But the first indication of how the coalition is going to vote was an amendment I got this morning. Having received that only this morning after having tried to negotiate for weeks, then I am sorry; we insist on pressing our amendment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am going to move that the committee report progress in order that we might ascertain when this committee report is likely to be brought down and in order that the Senate might be better informed in this debate. I do not think that anything would be lost by such a process because it seems that the Democrats are saying that they will still support the health card amendment.

PARA.TAB: The position the government has adopted previously on these bills is that, when we succeed in getting the amendment through, they simply do not proceed with the primary legislation. In other words, whatever benefits that were supposed to be forthcoming from that legislation the government is prepared to abandon to try to win a political debate in here. That is an incredible position, bearing in mind that all the government is doing is emphasising its own breach of promise to the Australian people. Nevertheless, that has been the practice the government has adopted in the past and no doubt will adopt again today. Therefore, in the spirit of trying to ensure the best quality debate in this place, I move:
That progress be reported.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government opposes the move by the opposition at this very late stage basically to defer this bill and this debate. I have been sitting here for the last hour or so and I must admit that I have been embarrassed by the auction that seems to be going on the other side. I also feel a bit distressed for the Democrats. This morning we have seen the opposition come in and try to leapfrog over the Democrats to take the high moral ground. Poor Senator Boswell is left standing there wondering what is going on. It is an uncoordinated late attack by the members of the coalition, not knowing what they are doing. They come in and move an amendment which is essentially Senator's Bell's amendment. They try to take the high moral ground on the Democrats. They know they cannot do that. No-one should ever try to do that because the Democrats have all it all over us in terms of pretending to take the high moral ground.

PARA.TAB: Senator Hill has made himself look a bit inept in the whole process. Let us face it: the Democrats have a position they are prepared to come back from to try to get some advantage on this. What Senator Hill has done is come in here and, having belatedly moved an movement—not even circulated and discussed it with people beforehand—he now wants to move to report progress when he is the one who stalled progress by coming in at this late stage. Why? I know there are a few preselections going on. I know that Senator Teague over there is fighting very hard with Senator Chapman in South Australia for the rural vote, and this sort of thing would be useful out there. But the taxpayers' money of Australia has been used as a tool in the opposition's preselection process. That is what this is about. I am not cynical; I can see right through the opposition.

Who are the other victims? It is the poor Democrats for coming in here and trying to get some honest concession. The Opposition has raised cynicism and hypocrisy to ultimate levels here. Opposition members come in at the end of it all and claim that they have made progress and want to defer this debate. Come on, Senator Hill. We expect better leadership from the opposition on this. We know you have your problems but we expect that at least in the last couple of weeks we can get some cooperation in this place so that we do not spend Christmas morning here. The sort of behaviour this morning does not help that.

The government's position on the legislation is pretty well-known. I presume I can respond to the standard points later once we determine whether we are reporting progress or not. So I will do that then. This is the culmination of a cynical manoeuvre this morning by the opposition to come in here, basically using taxpayers' funds as a tool in the process, to try to embarrass the Democrats. All they have really done is embarrass themselves because they have taken word for word an amendment by Senator Bell. They have understood why he has not proceeded with that one at this particular stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was our amendment. In June we got it up. We moved it in June—six months ago.
—He always comes in at this stage of debate, when all the work has been done, and wants to take the credit. Let us, in fact, achieve some progress before we actually report progress.

PARA.TAB: Progress reported.

DEBATE.TITLE: HIGHER EDUCATION FUNDING LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 9 November, on motion by Senator Crowley:
That this bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Higher Education Funding Legislation Amendment Bill 1994 is another matter which has been adjourned for some time. As I recall, the last contribution was from the government justifying why the changes were needed to introduce a pro rata arrangement for the recovery of HECS loans. At the time, the argument was well rehearsed. We had been going through a considerable amount of rhetoric in rehearsing that and not reaching any conclusions. I saw this as yet another government alteration—I suppose that is a polite word for it—to that which had been established as the way of operating; in other words, the deal that had been agreed to by students and the government.

PARA.TAB: We have seen quite a lengthy progression of these changes over the past few years. There have been changes made to the threshold at which the students would be expected to begin repaying the amount of HECS deferred debt. That reduction was initiated, we are told, because those naughty students had gone and got themselves unemployed after they had completed their tertiary studies: it was all their fault that they were not repaying the government. That little myth was peddled for a while.

We then had a change which involved an increase in the rate of repayment. The rates of repayment were altered up one per cent all round. So a recent graduate who had just managed to cross the threshold would begin repaying his debt—not at the rate of one per cent—at the rate of two per cent. This is an additional tax. It means that those graduates who were paying two per cent would be paying three per cent and those who were paying three per cent would be paying four per cent, et cetera.

That could be seen as a minimal change affecting only those who are privileged enough to have employment. Even that alteration of the goalposts was not seen as bringing in enough of this extraordinary amount of money that the government was carrying over as debt. It was portrayed in the media for a time as bad debt. There was a bit of a run given to the impression that somehow these students were welshing on their agreement by not paying back the money that they owed quickly enough. I think whoever perpetuated that fallacy fairly quickly saw the unfairness of it because the media did not really pick that up. Those who thought about the matter for more than five seconds recognised that it was the fault of those who were running the country that these young people were unable to get employment and therefore were unable to reach the salary threshold to begin repaying. So that one was dropped.

We now have this latest proposition: instead of waiting until the end of the first year in which the taxable income passes the new lower threshold, instead of waiting for the end of the first year in which that taxable income can be assessed, a few assumptions are made. This is where I start to get alarmed. When governments make assumptions, people suffer. The assumption made here is that, if a person is in receipt of a weekly amount which, if multiplied out through the year, would bring him or her up to a certain amount per year and therefore over the threshold, the repayment can begin that week. The first PAYE tax deduction will include a contribution for the repayment of the HECS debt.

The statement is made—and logically; I do not disagree with anybody's right to make it—`Well, if they are at that income level, they ought to be repaying it.' That might be logical and it might be so, but it was not part of the deal. It was not part of the agreement which the students originally entered into. Because it was not part of the deal, changing the deal halfway through the game is something which most three-year-olds can detect as being unfair. You should try playing a game of catch with a three-year-old and saying, halfway through, `You've got to stand on your head first.' The three-year-old will soon tell you that that is an unfair change.

Those who have devised this new change have been away from the real world for just a little too long. They have been away from dealing with people who are entering into agreements on the basis of what their real expectations are in the real world in terms of their own commitments, why they make them, and why they decide that something is a fair enough situation to get into. The fact that that has changed is the basic reason why this is unfair. A number of amendments and alterations can be made to this original concept, but there is nothing that can be done that can alter the basic unfairness of this attitude which the government has brought to this agreement.

I had some information provided to me on this matter by the government's advisers. I must say I was impressed with some of the answers that were given to me in terms of the way in which things are calculated and how it all pans out. It seems to be not all that unfair when the calculations are taken into account. But it did seem to me that, in a piece of legislation like this, it would be appropriate to include some fairly basic definitions. One of the definitions that seemed to me to be lacking was a definition of the cessation of full-time study.

We have here a situation where certain things are to be applied to people upon the cessation of full-time study, and yet nobody has taken the trouble to work out exactly when that is. There is a taxation definition. There is an Austudy definition. The two are not necessarily compatible, and here we have a proposition to establish a third situation where the cessation of full-time study is to be taken into account. I would have thought that should be reasonably easy to determine. It is something that is fundamental to the operation of the proposition we have before us.

I was also not impressed by the fact that the liability for complying with this is still somewhat vague. I remember a previous debate, which was similar to this in that it considered the same philosophy, in which Senator Panizza and I were in some sort of agreement—surprisingly not an unusual situation. Senator Panizza pointed out that, from an employer's perspective, some of the questions were a little difficult to answer. An employer who had the responsibility of dealing with the PAYE section of people's income had to take at face value whatever students said about their HECS liability and yet was liable, in the long run, to accurately deal with the situation as far as the tax office was concerned.

As yet, I cannot see that this has been clarified sufficiently to enable employers to be able to tackle the area with any degree of confidence. I will admit that my first concerns about the extra complications are not as well founded as I thought they might have been because, in this day of computers and adjustments and the individual circumstances which almost all employees find themselves in, the onus on the employer to alter things and make changes to the payment schedules is not such a great onus. It is not as much of a problem as I first thought.

However, the other problem remains. I recall the previous piece of legislation we discussed which affected this. At first the representatives of students had been opposed to this. Then they changed their minds and informed the coalition that they had changed their minds and had found that it was a wonderful advantage and should be implemented as soon as possible. But in the interim, again, I think there is considerable disquiet. I suggest that there is no degree of unanimity in the student bodies that represent students in Australia. I suggest also that not only student bodies but also graduate bodies should be consulted here.

Senator Sherry, the minister at the table at the moment representing the government, would be aware that the alumni group of the University of Tasmania would be a far more representative body to be consulted on this than is the union of students, whose members are not directly affected at all because they are yet to graduate and be in that situation. I see no evidence that such bodies have been consulted. Those bodies from that area that I have consulted on this have been opposed to the concept of changing the rules yet again while the game is in progress and of affecting people who made arrangements under different circumstances.

I come back to my original point: there is nothing the government can do to remove the basic unfairness of the proposition that we have here. We are very doubtful about this. We remain to be convinced that it is in the best interests of those whom it most affects. It may be in the best interests of the government to get some more money back. But to portray that money as bad debt which is recoverable from students at a higher rate is a wrong portrayal; it is a misleading portrayal; and, I suggest, it is even a dishonest portrayal.

The responsibility for repaying the HECS debt lies with students. But they are obliged to repay it only when they are in employment which has a taxable income per year above the threshold limit. The definition of when the liability would be reached and when the liability should occur is crucial in the understanding of fairness. A great number of people will be directly affected by this. Their net income may well be above the threshold limit, but their taxable income, for all sorts of reasons, may be considerably below it. Those people will be at a great disadvantage in losing access to cash money for a considerable part of the year and will be greatly disadvantaged by this measure.

The concept of people who may want to make a contribution per week to lessen the opportunity for them to be hit with a bulk repayment at the end of the taxable year is easily dismissed by the opportunity within the present situation for those people who are concerned by it to make fortnightly payments in expectation that they will reach the initial threshold and get rid of their HECS debt as soon as they like. I suggest that those people are fewer in number than those who will be greatly disadvantaged by having less cash at the beginning of a working career which is perhaps uncertain and may involve only short periods of employment, other periods of employment and other periods of unemployment that are beyond their capacity to predict. During all that time, whenever their fortnightly income is pro rata above the deemed threshold, they are penalised, so they have less money.

With all the complications that there are about whether somebody is employed, whether there is a waiting period or a qualifying period to receive the jobsearch allowance or to be involved in the new proposals of youth training initiatives, I can see people having a short time when they may have an income that is above the threshold. That money will be removed from their pay packet. They will then go on to some other scheme or be involved in a different arrangement. These problems are legion and real.

I suggest that those who devised this proposition have been away from that sort of concern for far too long. They are more concerned about finding ways to rearrange things in order to get more money back into the government's coffers. While it may seem logical on paper, this way is unfair in reality. We are greatly concerned about it.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Higher Education Funding Legislation Amendment Bill 1994 is a major issue because, amongst its provisions, it seeks to curb one of our most basic rights: the right of freedom. In this case, we are talking about the freedom of association or its corollary, the freedom not to associate.

PARA.TAB: The government proposes the continuation of compulsory unionism for students. Let there be no doubt that yet again it is the government riding roughshod over the basic rights of students. It is forcing these students to join a student union under threat of having their academic careers terminated. This is in direct contravention of three separate international agreements signed by Australia, including article 20 of the United Nations Declaration on Human Rights, the International Convention on Civil and Political Rights and the ILO convention concerning freedom of association. These conventions specifically denounce the practice of compelling individuals to join unions. I think of the hypocrisy of the government in its being prepared to use external powers to enforce other matters, such as those in Tasmania, but not this one.

The ALP complained bitterly—and quite rightly—when the Menzies government tried to outlaw the Communist Party, but does it have some profound method of distinguishing between the right to join and the right not to join? The compulsory membership of a particular union is no more justifiable than would be compulsory membership of the Labor or Liberal clubs on campus. We would support secretariats, of course, but in this situation we need to define exactly what the available options are for individual assessments.

The Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Crean) had the hide to say that the freedom of choice about joining student organisations was an insult to students and a suppression of their basic freedoms. We really have to ask what freedoms he was referring to when the freedom to risk losing a tertiary education was one of those in question.

This legislation relates to a number of other issues, one being that of donations to political causes. One of the main objections to this system is the way in which fees compulsorily collected from students, regardless of their backgrounds and beliefs, can be used for a range of campaigns, including political campaigns. For example, the recent pro-PLO resolutions organised by the AUS caused all sorts of difficulties within the community.

Worse still, this is something which really relates to states rights and to issues of individuals being able to overcome the government monopoly in these areas. One of the things we have to stand up for here is individual freedoms. I am disappointed that the government is taking this view over a range of issues, in particular concerning students. I therefore do not support some of the issues raised in this particular piece of legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Higher Education Funding Legislation Amendment Bill makes a few minor amendments to the Higher Education Funding Act and, significantly, brings in pro rata payments of HECS for students in their first year out of university. The Greens have no problem with the minor amendments to the act but are committed to opposing clause 12 and the government's intention to collect a faster repayment of HECS through charging pro rata HECS.

PARA.TAB: Students who have just finished university do not find work straightaway. They keep on with the casual work that got them through university, which could be consistent work or a couple of months work at relatively high pay that gives them enough savings to get through the semester. When students do find work, because of the nature of the employment market it is rare to land into a full-time job. Often there are periods doing short-term contract work, such as relief work, which can be infrequent, to gain experience. There are students who opt for self-employment or consulting work, which can be infrequent, short term and have large income swings, while waiting for more stable work opportunities.

Through this amendment the government is attempting to capitalise on the sporadic work opportunities of those in their first year of work after leaving university. In any one week, if their income is over $504 before tax they will lose three per cent of that to HECS payment. In a scenario of the minimum impact of this change, this would mean taking $15 out of a wage of $400—and that may not be consistent. Across the board this takes an extra $5 million out of the pockets of new graduates, the amount the government hopes to earn from this amendment. This comes at a time when graduate incomes have fallen and student debt is increasing.

The government has not made these changes in isolation. The government has a recent history of tightening the noose around students' necks through HECS payments. In the last two budgets, students have been commanded to repay HECS at faster and higher rates. At the same time, they now have Austudy debts of up to $11,000 extra to pay off, on top of their HECS debts.

Graduate incomes are also at their lowest level in 20 years. Statistics released by the Graduate Careers Council of Australia on 4 October this year showed that annual graduate starting salaries had dropped by $200 in 1992 and 1993 despite a rise three times that for average earnings in the community over the same period. Women also earn 90 per cent of the wages of fellow male university graduates and graduates earn 80 per cent of that which other workers earn.

As starting salaries slip below average weekly earnings, adding up to $26,500 per year, and as the job market becomes harder and harder to crack, the government is realising that it will have to continually put pressure on students to pay the money back at higher rates while they earn less. The government realises that many former students will never pay off their debts.

The Greens are opposed to increasing HECS any further, as the government is probably hoping to do in next year's budget, and has flagged as much in the latest recommendations of the recent DEET report entitled Resources allocation in higher education. This bill is a shoddy attempt to claw back small amounts of money from students who are suffering poverty under Austudy, debt for a greater part of their working lives, a dwindling number of jobs, less and less public funding of their higher education institutions and a poorer quality of education. The government should get its priorities right and start looking at the real issues.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of the Higher Education Funding Legislation Amendment Bill is to bring forward repayment of the HECS liability and introduce a pro rata payment threshold for students who leave full-time education for the first time. The changes announced in the last budget will take effect from 1 January 1995. This arrangement is effectively a PAYE tax system being applied to the repayment of the HECS debt.

PARA.TAB: The HECS liability is now to be paid each week from the pay packet. As Senator Hill pointed out in the debate on this bill the last time the Senate met, we support some of the provisions of this bill; however, we oppose the attempt to introduce pro rata payments for HECS. We will oppose this measure because we believe it is inequitable and unfair and it contains a number of unexplained anomalies.

We believe this new attempt could be the first of many changes by Labor to try to introduce pro rata payments for all students across the board. As I indicated earlier, there are some provisions of the bill that we will not oppose: for example, amendments removing the restriction on the number of units for which eligible clients under the open learning deferred payments scheme may defer payment in the first semester of study. We will support an amendment to increase the maximum level of grant funding available under certain provisions of the act to reflect the revised amount available following verification of relevant HECS information. We will support an amendment to transfer funds to the Aboriginal Education (Supplementary Assistance) Act 1989. We will also support the minor changes in the definition of an overseas student to ensure that members of foreign armed services studying in Australia pay full fees rather than HECS.

So we are supporting quite a number of changes in this bill. However, as I mentioned earlier, we have major concerns about the introduction of pro rata payments. It is just one more step in an evolving pattern of this government scrambling around for more and more money in order to fund its inadequately funded higher education system.

This arrangement started originally with an administration charge of a few hundred dollars. We now have HECS charges of $2,400 each year. At the moment, as a result of this HECS measure which has been in place for several years, the community has an outstanding liability to the government of $2 billion, and the Department of Finance is pretty desperate to claw this money in. That is the foundation of the major part of this bill to which the coalition objects.

We believe the pro rata payment and PAYE approach is just a crude attempt to get this money in at all costs. It denies many students equity and fairness. It provides a double whammy for students: they get the HECS liability and then the ground rules concerning the timing of the prepayment are changed in order to suit this ALP government. Students and prospective students entering higher education are fed up with the constant changes to their liability. The government keeps changing the rules on the run. Some students have started a course under one set of rules and, during that course, have seen those rules change several times.

This creates fear in students because their commitments might be altered overnight and therefore the debt they have to pay at the end could change. Their liability, on which they are working out their financial affairs over the years they are at university, can change as well, affecting their standard of living. As we know, many students teeter on the brink of poverty and even a small change to the rules, such as that which the government is indicating, can affect them greatly.

Many students are in the position where they will earn money over a Christmas vacation. This will boost their income and that boost in income can be affected by the pro rata tax system because it can take the surplus money that they need to finance themselves through the year. We have had a succession of ministers—Dawkins, Beazley and Crean, and the progression increases—who just change things at the drop of a hat. For the reasons I have outlined, the Senate should deplore the way the government is approaching the whole HECS matter.

This bill will have quite an impact. Until this change, HECS was paid in a lump sum at the end of a financial year. If their total earnings for the year were above the HECS threshold then students were in a position where they did not have to pay tax at this point. Now if students earn $5,000 and it is spread over the full financial year they are not required to pay HECS. For these students there is no particular change. The ALP is now hitting a group of people who work hard for the intensive part of the year and then have to pay this higher rate.

Under pro rata PAYE payments, people finishing higher education for the first time may earn $5,000 in a part-time job over two months and then earn nothing for the remainder of the year. Under this bill they will be required to pay the HECS week by week over the two months through their pay packet. This is one of the mean and unfair ways in which this Labor government is planning to recoup this $2 billion in outstanding debt.

The bill says the measure will bring in $5 million for each of the next three years. Why is the government burdening former students who have just finished their courses with this complex scheme that has the anomalies that I have described to the Senate. People struggle after years of study with little or no income. They have been on the poverty line. They finally get into the work force and they are hit with this changed rate of repayment which again upsets their financial planning. Not only do students have problems with planning for the time of study but also they are not too sure what will happen after the time of study because the government keeps changing the rules.

This legislation is bureaucratic and is based on the application of a very complex formula. The rules for determining who has to pay are incredibly complex. It is unfair because students leaving full-time education for the first time already have these large debts. This change, with the government dipping into a person's income, has happened with haste. The government is not waiting to see the full year picture.

We seek to amend this bill to remove the pro rata HECS payment. We are also very concerned that this will be a forerunner for the ALP government to bring in more legislation to slug students further—legislation that could apply a HECS payment to any part-time income, for example. The next step would be to have student vacational income, if over the average weekly earnings on a proportionate basis, incur an earlier payment of the HECS liability.

Students are worried about the prospects and are very uncertain about their financial future. This Labor government will not come clean on its intentions, yet we all know the crisis that it faces financially and the effect this will have on future arrangements for higher education funding. The government has to get its money from somewhere and, unfortunately, instead of the community obligation which has tended to cover much of the funding, what it has increasingly done is slug those who are least able to afford it—students who are on a very low income.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to respond to some points made in senators' contributions this morning and also to the public contribution, at least via a media release, made by Senator Hill, the shadow minister for education. The debate on the Higher Education Funding Legislation Amendment Bill has concentrated on the pro rata HECS threshold.

PARA.TAB: The issue is that, from 1 January 1995, people leaving full-time education for the first time who have a HECS debt will begin repaying their debt immediately if their taxable income during the financial year exceeds the pro rata HECS repayment threshold. In what is proposed to be past practice, individuals who ceased full-time study at some point during a financial year and who entered the work force and earned an annual equivalent income above the first HECS threshold were not required to make a HECS payment in that year.

The implementation of this measure will be consistent with the income tax pro rata arrangements on the tax free threshold for those who stop full-time education for the first time during the year. The repayment salary threshold will be calculated using the proportion of the year that the taxpayer is not in full-time education. Income earned during the study period—the pre work force income—will be added to the threshold, calculated on a pro rata basis up to the maximum of the standard thresholds. The resulting thresholds will be measured against all taxable income during the year, including pre work force income, to calculate the necessary repayment amount for the year in respect of the accumulated HECS debt.

I would like to make a number of points which pick up the issues that various speakers in the debate have raised in opposing this provision. Students are not affected if they are on vacation break or enrolled in a course. Students who work during holidays and return to university within four months will not be affected by this measure.

This change does not increase the size of an individual's debt. It will bring forward an individual's repayments. The policy applies only to those who cease full-time education for the first time and, therefore, will not affect HECS debtors employed on a casual or contractual basis or those who return to the work force after periods of unemployment, unpaid leave or unpaid maternity leave. Taxpayers who believe that they may earn above the weekly threshold for some weeks, but that their annual taxable income will still be assessed below the pro rata HECS threshold, can obtain a variation certificate from the Australian Taxation Office to give to their employer to reduce their tax instalments.

There is provision for a person to postpone payment of his or her HECS debt in cases of financial hardship. If a person's taxable income is over the minimum threshold and a payment is required, but to do so would cause financial hardship, applications can be made to the Deputy Commissioner of Taxation to postpone payment. Repayment would recommence when the person is in a better financial position.

I will respond directly to some of Senator Hill's comments, particularly those made in media release No. 40 of 1994, put out on 9 November. It is not true, as the opposition has suggested, that the pro rata salary threshold conflicts with the equity principles on which HECS is firmly based. This measure still ensures that only students finishing full-time study and gaining employment at an income above average weekly earnings begin to repay their debt. These are students who have obviously benefited from their education and who are in fact the group of students more likely to be able to pay.

If the opposition has its way regarding proposed pro rata payment, its grandstanding on changes to HECS alone over the last two budgets will have cost the government some $51.6 million. Of course, the opposition is long on the rhetoric of suggesting government cuts to balance the budget but very short on the detail.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are you talking about? How do you calculate it at $51 million?

—I am getting to some of that detail now. This includes revenue from proposed measures such as double the standard rate of HECS for students studying for second and third undergraduate degrees, savings forgone of $24.5 million, and 1.5 times the standard rate of HECS for students taking overly long to complete their courses, savings forgone of $12.1 million. These measures would have ensured that people using extra higher education resources receive less Commonwealth subsidy, enabling places to be provided for students who had not already had access to higher education. What the opposition fails to understand is that contributions made by students through HECS are returned to the higher education system.

PARA.TAB: Some additional points made by Senator Hill and those opposite in opposing this measure include the allegation that the charge has been sprung on students. It is not the case that this measure has been sprung on students. The measure was announced in the 1994-95 budget. It is outlined in the Department of Employment, Education and Training portfolio budget measures statement. The opposition alleged that anomalies arose from the measure, particularly because it will apply only once. It seems to be suggested by the opposition that the proposed change should apply to people returning to employment after periods of maternity leave or unemployment. That is certainly not the government's intention. The measure will only apply the first time a person leaves full-time education to maintain consistency with the Income Tax Rates Act 1986. Sections 16 to 20 of this act relate to pro rata arrangements already applying to the tax-free income threshold.

The opposition alleged that the government wants to charge a pro rata HECS payment to students who finish full-time education and gain full-time employment within the same financial year regardless of their total year earnings. The proposed measure does not introduce a pro rata HECS payment. It adjusts the HECS repayment salary threshold to take into account that a person has not been in the work force for a full financial year. Total taxable income for the financial year is compared with this threshold. A person would be considered to have finished full-time education for the purpose of this measure whether or not employment had been obtained.

The opposition alleged that the proposed pro rata payments are totally inequitable and make a mockery of the principles under which HECS is supposed to operate and that it would rip $5 million a year from graduates and students who are likely to be able to pay. The pro rata salary threshold does not make a mockery of the equity principles on which HECS is firmly based. This measure still ensures that only students finishing full-time study and gaining employment at an income above average weekly earnings begin to repay their debt. These are students who have obviously benefited from their education and are in fact the group more likely to pay.

The opposition also alleged or is suspicious that eventually any student who earns over average weekly earnings in any one week will have to pay HECS regardless of their total yearly earnings. This is alleged to affect contract workers, vacation workers and any student or graduate working for any part of the year. It is not the government's intention to assess HECS repayments on the basis of weekly earnings. HECS assessments are always made on the basis of total taxable income for the financial year. There is also no intention of targeting vacation earnings of students. Clause 12 of the amending legislation, which deals with part-year work force period, has been drafted to specifically exclude students working during holidays.

In concluding my remarks, I have a couple of other comments. I do not want to be too harsh on Senator Woods. I will leave rebuttal of his contribution to another day. In respect of Senator Tierney, who talked a great deal about the government's policy—the same theme came through from Senator Woods—we will look with interest at what the opposition proposes as a new policy.

The opposition made the very recent attempt to come up with some sort of policy parameter document, `the things that batter'—the document that has never seen the light of day since that famous statement by the current Leader of the Opposition (Mr Downer), who may not be so current after the next few weeks. After the opposition's last failed attempt to come up with any policy parameters we look with interest as a government to see what proposals—within the context of its continual cries for lower government expenditure without increasing taxes—based on fairness and equity the opposition will be putting forward.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
The bill.
Clause 12.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: Clause 12, page 4 (line 27), to page 9 (line 32), omit the clause.

SPEECH.PARA: This is the pro rata provision. The arguments for opposition have been expressed from around the chamber, except for the government. The government apparently feels that it can impose certain obligations on students before they commence their course in relation to repaying HECS and then vary those obligations as their course progresses and as it concludes. This has been a consistent pattern of this government, which increased the rate of HECS, reduced the threshold for HECS and now is ratcheting forward the requirement for repayment of HECS in relation to the students who are covered by this bill.

PARA.TAB: That is unfair in our view. As I said in my second reading contribution, the government ought to outline for students at the time they commence their education the obligations that it is going to impose on them in relation to paying part of the cost of that education and the time for and detail of repayment. It has therefore let students down in unilaterally seeking to make these changes that will detrimentally affect a number of such students.

As I said in my second reading contribution and as others have said today, it discriminates against particular students—those who have a short period of employment within the financial year within which they finish their education—in favour of students who for other reasons work only for part of the year. We have no doubt at all in view of the government's pattern in relation to variations to HECS that this is only a step towards introducing a HECS repayment requirement on any part-time work that a student obtains. Therefore, when the spokesman for the government stands today and assures the Senate that that is not the government's intention, all we can do is judge that assurance against the record of this government, which has been to consistently vary the obligation by increasing it and bringing it forward.

As I said earlier, students who work for what might be just a few weeks during the financial year in which they finish their courses have often had to pay their living costs out of what they earn during that very short period of time. Therefore, the government's attempt to gross out that part-time payment over the whole of the year to bring upon the students the obligation for early repayment is, in our view, not only unjust but also it fails to appreciate the financial reality of students and of those who have just graduated.

Overall the HECS scheme is a fair scheme as it requires the community to make a contribution towards the cost of education. Education is obviously of public benefit and of private benefit. We have no objection to that private benefit being implemented in terms of a debt which is repaid on gaining subsequent employment, but it has to be done in ways which are fair and it should not be unilaterally varied to the disadvantage of students who entered education upon a different undertaking by this government.

In those circumstances, I move this amendment which will delete this discriminatory, unjust and inequitable provision and return us to the previous situation. If we are successful and if the government ultimately accepts the view of the Senate, which I hope it will, students will have the Senate to thank for again bringing this government to account.

TALK.START.PARA: —Clause 12 introduces a raft of complex and extremely technical provisions to the principal act. This measure is not expected to raise large amounts. It imposes an additional burden on some students when they can least afford it, for example on re-entering the work force, and adds unnecessary complexities to the principal act and accompanying administrative arrangements. It is arguable that the change is justifiable neither on equity grounds nor on a cost benefit analysis. They are not my words; most senators have actually read them.

PARA.TAB: Senator Hill's comments on the amendment to delete clause 12 stand on their own. Senator Hill has made out a good case, as indeed have other senators who are supporting him. But it is interesting to note that this cumbersome bureaucratic attempt to impose this extra burden, which is not going to bring in large sums at all, takes up six pages in the legislation itself.

TALK.START.PARA: —Gobbledegook!
—Yes, of gobbledegook, and seven or so pages in the explanatory memorandum. One would have to be a Rhodes scholar to work it all out.
—You had better not graduate.

—That is right. Really, it is over the top, bureaucratic nonsense. It really is something that the government should reconsider. It should not be in the legislation for the principal reasons that have been explained by Senator Hill, Senator Tierney, Senator Bell and others.
—Except Senator Woods.
—That was a different question. That is the next bill or the one after that. I will be supporting Senator Hill's amendment.

—The Democrats will also be supporting the amendment moved by Senator Hill. It is entirely parallel to the amendments that were previously circulated in my name, but we will not get into that argument about who thought of what first. I also support the comments made by Senator Hill and the reasons he gave. During the contribution by the parliamentary secretary particular emphasis was placed—and possibly rightly so—on what the government is doing here.

PARA.TAB: I think the statement made by Senator Sherry in support of what the government is doing here—that this money is taken out of the earnings of those who are earning above average weekly earnings—can be challenged. At the time a recent graduate may be earning in excess of average weekly earnings. The problem we are faced with is that the assumption is made that that level of earning will continue. That is what is wrong with this whole proposition—it is based on an assumption which cannot be justified. There is no way that the government can substantiate that assumption.

We are concerned about people for whom that assumption may not be true. It is all very well if people are beginning a professional career and the salary structure is such that their initial salary is above average weekly earnings. This means they will be above the HECS threshold and if they are guaranteed five, six or 10 years of constant earnings, they start at that level and go along merrily from there. We are not concerned about those people. I think they will not be concerned about beginning to repay their HECS debt at an earlier stage than they had agreed to. But we are concerned about people in regard to whom the assumption is not true. They might begin employment in what may not be their lifelong profession. They may not have the surety of being employed for a full year. Having been employed for a month or two, they may then face a period of unemployment.

But the government still keeps that money. We do not see the minister or the proponents of this proposition organising a scheme whereby the money which has been taken is immediately refunded. No; it has to be held until the end of the financial year and comes back with a tax refund. That is very nice but it does not help people who, having finished education perhaps at the end of November—and this is another matter that I want to return to—get a job such as casual bar work for a month over the Christmas period, a bit of delivery work or some promotional work. Perhaps it is the sort of work that can be found at the `Taste of Tasmania'—a wonderful event that takes place in Tasmania during the Christmas break. A lot of young graduates get themselves a few dollars by working there. But it only lasts for a couple of days. I am sure the parliamentary secretary realises that.

People who work during these sorts of carnivals that occur over the summer break are involved in what is only very temporary work. It is lucrative while it is going on and above average weekly earnings are probably received. But the government has retained not only the PAYE tax component but also, as Senator Tierney said, this extra PAYE which has now crept in. This extra tax may be at the level of several per cent. To retain that for the following five or six months is unfair and it was never part of the deal. That is what we need to be aware of.

It is not only those people who are affected. People might be working part-time, three or four days a week, receiving perhaps $17,000 or $18,000 a year for that. They may receive, for a couple of months of the year, an offer of full-time employment in the same position, or they might work overtime or act in a higher position for a short time. Immediately, that is taken on a pro rata basis across the threshold; the government steps in, takes the money and keeps it for the taxable year, without paying any regard to the fact, which is a most likely fact, that extra deductible expenses will be incurred in achieving that extra income. The money that is retrieved is proposed to be calculated not on the tax form which is filled in at the end of the year and submitted then; it is taken on a pro rata basis on the assumption that such a level of income will be achieved all the time.

As Senator Harradine stated, I think that is getting to the stage where we have an immensely technical and convoluted way of screwing a few extra dollars out of those people who are in that situation through no fault of their own. It is an agreement they undertook with the government, which the government decided to change. As I pointed out in a contribution earlier, even three-year-olds can detect that it is unfair to change the rules while the game is being played. So we strongly support the motion to delete clause 12.
Progress reported.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to the concessions made by Mr Willis yesterday that the government was considering an increase in income tax to reduce the gap between its spending and its revenue. That is the Labor government way of doing business, is it not, to put up taxes rather than attack the deficit? I ask: will not the foreshadowed tax increases simply inflate the current wages claims in the same way as projected increases in interest rates have done—another deliberate policy of the government's, to push up interest rates—and will the minister give an undertaking that the second phase of the income tax cuts will be delivered without any increase in income taxes in the intervening period?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, my understanding is that Mr Willis said nothing of the kind and it is a complete fabrication that is being uttered by Senator Hill. He made the point that fiscal policy will obviously have to be considered in a budget context. The time is not yet right to do that.

PARA.TAB: We are looking at a situation where the deficit may well be much less than that which was forecast—and Mr Willis made that point—down from 11.7 to possibly rather less than 11.3.
