A surplus in 1997-98 as compared with the $2 billion deficit that was originally projected is also possible at this stage on the kinds of figures that are emerging. Against the background of this sort of situation it is simply wildly premature to be contemplating any specific fiscal policy reaction, whether on the further efforts on the outlays side, to the extent that that was possible, or, if it is of another kind, on the revenue side. Mr Willis, as I understand, made it perfectly clear, and I quote him exactly:

ANSWER.PARA: If we made the decision that there needed to be further tightening of fiscal policy, and we decided that had to be done on the revenue side, obviously then we have to decide exactly how that would be done with what tax approach, but we are nowhere near that point at the moment and we may not get to that point.

It is simply raw dishonesty on the part of the opposition leader in this place to preface his question in the way that he did. Mr Willis said nothing of the kind, for the reasons that I have just specified.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. The minister knows the code as well as we do. Mr Willis's words follow the words of Mr Keating, and they were both hinting that the government was going to resolve its deficit problem by pushing up interest rates again. We all remember the l-a-w tax cuts promises. I ask the minister: as we were told when the government last broke its tax promises that they would not be implemented until fiscal conditions permit, probably in 1998—they were the terms of the l-a-w tax cuts breach of promise—what is the current position in relation to taxes? As the government has pushed up interest rates, can the Australian people now also expect it to push up taxes?

—Mr Deputy President, there is absolutely no change whatsoever in the government's position as stated on the subject of tax cuts, as enunciated very clearly at the time that we brought forward the major set of tax cuts to the obvious benefit of the Australian public. And while we are talking about code, maybe the opposition would decipher some of the code that makes it possible for it to talk about reducing the fiscal deficit and at the same time talk about a tax break on savings which would cost of the order of $10.5 billion to $12.5 billion? Would it break that particular code and tell us how it proposes to do that? How does it propose to do that as a result of public service efficiency gains when the total of public service salaries is $4.9 billion and yet it is talking about cuts of $10 billion to $12 billion if it is going to finance its own promised tax cuts? The opposition is absolutely talking in tongues—not only in code but in tongues—and whenever it opens its mouth on fiscal policy it puts its foot in it.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology. I refer to the release by the Industry Commission of its annual industry review. I note the review concludes that Australia has enjoyed improved industry performance resulting mainly from increased labour productivity but states that further reform is necessary if we are to match future growth of our major trading partners. In this context, the Industry Commission welcomed the increased integration of Australia into the international marketplace. Against this background, can the minister inform the Senate of what strategies the government has in place to ensure that the pace of reform within Australian industry is sufficient to capitalise on our improved productivity and international orientation?

—The Industry Commission has in its review highlighted the opening up of the Australian economy to the international marketplace as a key reform over the past decade. It has identified that the challenge for this decade, and indeed for the next century, is to ensure that Australian industry is able to respond to the opportunities that become available and to capture those opportunities. The stakes have been magnified by the opportunities and challenges now open to us because of the work the Prime Minister, the foreign minister and the trade minister did at Bogor a fortnight ago in bringing down the barriers to trade in APEC—a huge leap forward for Australian industry and a massive opportunity for a country that has gone through a large amount of restructuring to make its industry base more efficient.

PARA.TAB: What I think is apposite as far as the Industry Commission is concerned is that last week the Australian Manufacturing Council, a tripartite body of business, government and unions, brought down a report—handed to me by John Prescott, chief executive of BHP and Chairman of the Manufacturing Council—entitled The wealth of ideas: how linkages help sustain innovation and growth. It looks at what needs to be done in the Australian economy to drive economic growth further and to give Australian industry a competitive edge in the booming markets that beckon us in Asia and the Pacific.

This report is an interesting report. It builds on all of the work done in the reports by the McKinsey organisation on emerging exporters and the earlier work done on what makes Australian industry more competitive. The report identified that innovation—the ability to create new ideas—and being able to transform those new ideas commercially, to keep those scientific or technological ideas in Australia and commercialise them here, are the elements that will drive Australia into a more competitive position in the markets of the world and specifically in the markets of Asia.

Whilst we see that Australian government spending on research and development is ranked seventh among the countries of the OECD—that is among our peer group economies in the Western world—private sector expenditure on research and development is ranked 19th. Therefore, the need to lift private sector expenditure on research and development, particularly in the manufacturing and services areas, to capture the innovative edge and the wealth of ideas the AMC report speaks of is an urgent national necessity.

The government has indicated that about August next year it will be bringing down a major statement on innovation. I look forward to working closely with the leaders of Australian industry and the Australian science community in order to find ways in which the level of private sector investment in research, including that which contributes new ideas and new products to the market, in Australia can be lifted.

One of the other important aspects of this report is that it is very important, quite apart from what Professor Michael Porter has said in his very useful work on this subject, for Australian companies to have leading edge customers—customers that demand high standards. It is with those high standards that leading edge customers provide that Australian industry will stretch targets to lift the quality of and improve the cost of the work that it does. It is a very useful report. It has been well hailed by over 100 business people who attended a conference on that report with me last week. I think in many respects it is a blueprint for the way forward for Australian industry to become more competitive in Asia and the world.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. He would be aware of the Queensland Labor Premier's unprecedented full page advertisement in last week's national media criticising his handling of the Port Hinchinbrook development. Is it a fact that, as Mr Goss asserts, every one of what he calls `the strictest environmental controls' was checked and approved by the federal government? Is it a fact, as Mr Goss asserts, that these approvals included the removal of the small area of mangroves on which the minister halted work on 15 November? Is Mr Goss correct when he says that the issue of mangrove removal was never specifically discussed by the minister's department or anyone else during the 10 months of the detailed consultations? As the seagrasses have thrived since four-fifths of the mangroves were removed in the 1970s and 1980s, why should the public not see the minister's last minute intervention as nothing more than a grubby attempt to pander to the extremist Green vote, irrespective of the desperate need for national development and regional development in our country?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The only letter that seems to have been interpreted as signifying my approval of the tripartite deed of agreement between the Queensland government, the Cardwell Shire Council and the developer, Mr Williams, is my correspondence to my counterpart in Queensland, Molly Robson, which is dated 29 September of this year. In that letter I indicated and made it very clear that I retained a number of concerns about this proposed development, including the absence of an adequate environmental impact assessment that had led to a very unsatisfactory situation where baseline studies were being conducted at the same time as the development was proceeding.

PARA.TAB: In that letter, which has been on the public record, I agreed that the baseline studies should be able to address most of the concerns about the lack of information which had been identified in a report that had been commissioned by my portfolio from Mr Peter Valentine which deals at some length with the issue of mangroves, prospective mangrove clearance and its relationship with seagrass beds. I pointed out my views in this letter in these terms:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . if, as a result of this further work . . . it becomes clear that World Heritage values are likely to be damaged or destroyed through the proposed development, then it will be necessary for it to be amended in such a way as to avoid that damage or destruction. Otherwise, I will need to consider invoking the relevant provisions of the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act 1983. I would be grateful if you would make that clear to the developer.
In the event, what I warned of in that letter was precisely what occurred.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. One of my colleagues said, `A poor man's Richo,' but at least Senator Richardson was prepared to go to Ravenshoe. Why has the minister made this decision without ever visiting the Port Hinchinbrook site and without ever speaking with the people who will be forced onto the dole as a result of his intervention in this particular thing? Given the enormous financial and social impact of his decision on the local community, does he have the courage to come with me this week to Cardwell and listen to the concerns of local people, or does he have a streak down his back as wide as the Barrier Reef?

—I will make two comments in response to Senator Macdonald's supplementary question. The first is that this project has not been stopped. But I have an obligation and a responsibility, which I am treating seriously, to ensure that the World Heritage values of the Great Barrier Reef World Heritage area are not damaged or destroyed. The other point is that I think there is at this stage nothing to be gained by going to Cardwell and possibly inflaming the situation. That is a view shared by a number of other people who have been involved in this issue.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction. Articles in today's press report that Taiwan has complained about the strip searching of one of its nationals by Australian customs officers at Sydney Airport last week. Can the minister give the Senate an analysis of the incident?

—I thank Senator Cooney for his question. Those of us who have been in the Senate for some time know that Senator Cooney has had a long interest in civil rights, legal processes and so on, and I am not surprised that he asks this question. I have received a number of details from my department about the incident that occurred. I am aware that, apparently last Friday, a representative of the Taiwanese government made representations to the Australian government over the incident at Sydney Airport which, I think, took place last Tuesday.

PARA.TAB: I have received information from the Customs Service about the background to the strip search. According to my initial examination of all the material, the officers of customs acted in accordance with the legislation and the rules laid down by this parliament in checking whether people may or may not be carrying prohibited goods into the country.

Nevertheless, over recent months, as a result of the Conroy review, I have had several discussions with senior customs officers on the issue of searches, of running the primary barrier and protecting, in accordance with the law, Australia's barrier, particularly with people being examined and so on.

TALK.START.PARA: —What does `reasonable cause' mean?

—The `reasonable cause' provision is laid down in the regulations and the rules of customs as a result of the legislation which this parliament carried in 1990 with the support of both the opposition and the government.
—Was it met in this case?

—Yes, as I understand it, and I have examined it. I believe that it was. However, one of the issues that the Conroy review raised, and it has been raised by others in the community, is the general issue of whether officers of customs should have the power themselves to make a decision to carry out what is called a strip search or even an internal search. I believe there are issues involved here of legal process where, if at all possible and without in any way weakening the protection of the barrier system to stop illegal goods and prohibited items coming into the country, we can separate the processes of customs administration from a proper legal warrant being issued by a non-customs person.

PARA.TAB: I have to say to Senator Cooney that that is a matter I have today asked my senior officers to investigate—to review the case that occurred last week and to see whether it is possible, without any derogation of the protection of the barrier, to determine, when a strip search takes place which a person does not want to participate in and refuses to participate in, whether that should be done after an independent legal assessment or a warrant issued by a non-customs person. I do not know whether we are able to do it but that is certainly a matter I have asked my officers to look at.

In the meantime, I can say that, on all the advice I have been given, the customs officers acted totally in accordance with the rules, the regulations and the law as laid down by this parliament. I also want to say that some of the press reporting about what occurred has been absolutely wrong, lurid and sensational. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories and concerns the Resource Assessment Commission's coastal zone inquiry. Last week the Prime Minister said that there was probably no better example of why national strategies were needed than the Australian coast. As Australians are in danger of loving their coast to death and as there have already been 26 national and state inquiries into the coastline in the last 20 years, does the government yet have the political will to implement coastal zone management legislation on behalf of all Australians? Does the minister see it as important to rationalise the 1,500 various agencies under some 900 pieces of legislation governing the coastal zone? Does the Prime Minister's entry into this debate signify that we can expect more than a token response to the RAC coastal inquiry?

—The government has always had a strong commitment to the sustainable management of our coasts—as, I might say, it has had for all parts of Australia. I can say to Senator Kernot that the Prime Minister has a strong personal commitment also to better planning and better sustainable management of our coastline. As one would see from the recent speeches he has made, he has certainly indicated that very clearly on the public record.

PARA.TAB: He has asked me and my department to coordinate a whole of government response to the Resource Assessment Commission's coastal inquiry. In the near future, cabinet will be considering a package of measures to reinforce the application of the government's sustainable development philosophy for the coastal region. That, of course, has come about as a result of a process which began with the 1992 inquiry by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts.

Of course, coastal management inquiries have suggested a number of areas where the Commonwealth should focus its attention in order to improve coastal management. Amongst those important principles are community involvement and participation in coastal management, the increase in the capacity and knowledge of coastal managers, the objective of providing integrated solutions to particular coastal issues and, of course, the issue of developing appropriate links with our regional neighbours. This particular response does include intergovernmental measures that have been developed in cooperation with state governments.

At the meeting in July this year of the intergovernmental committee for ecologically sustainable development, a number of jurisdictions agreed to the establishment of an intergovernmental coastal working group and identified a range of coastal issues that it would address. All the states, the Northern Territory, and also the Australian Local Government Association, sent representatives to the meetings of the working group. Some of the things that were discussed at those meetings did appear in the newspapers on the weekend. But many of those matters that were raised in the newspapers were way off track.

The Commonwealth is not considering either a Commonwealth coastal resource management act or a national coastal management agency, which were recommended by RAC. Those recommendations would have brought the Commonwealth into conflict with the states. I will also not be recommending at any stage a hotel bed tax or charges for beachgoers. Anticipating where Senator Kernot's supplementary question might lead, they are ruled out absolutely. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. Is the minister saying that he will rely mainly on yet another intergovernmental committee and working groups? Can we expect to see any action on this issue from his government by the end of this year?
—No. I did not say that. I have said that it is a matter for cabinet to deliberate on in the very near future.

—My question, which is addressed to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, refers to the major campaign that he and the Prime Minister launched in early November to encourage eligible permanent residents to become Australian citizens and to stimulate general debate about what citizenship means to us all. What has been the initial response to both the television advertisements and the publicity surrounding the launch?
—This is a bit of a test for you, Nick.

—It may be a test for me, but it would be a test that Senator Hill would fail. We have seen that by way of his performance this morning. On the other hand, I thank Senator Zakharov for this question and note that, unlike the cynicism from the other side, she has been interested in the issue of citizenship because, probably unlike the opposition, she recognises that the whole concept of citizenship—the definition and role of it—in Australia in the late 20th century goes very much to the concept of how we develop ourselves as a nation. It is a debate in which those on that side of the chamber want to have absolutely no part.

PARA.TAB: The government is concerned about the issue. That is why we kicked off a campaign to encourage the 1.1 million or so permanent residents who are eligible to take up citizenship to do so. We also started the campaign to ensure that Australians continue to think and talk about the concept of citizenship and its significance for everyone into the future.

As Senator Zakharov pointed out, the Prime Minister and I launched the campaign at a ceremony that welcomed 45 citizens in Sydney on 4 November. Since then, most people have seen the campaign of three national advertisements which is based on the concept of `Australian citizenship: welcome to our family'.

Since that date, the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs has been operating a 24-hour per day, seven-day per week national telephone inquiry service. As a consequence of the campaign and other associated promotions, I am pleased to report that the initial response to that campaign has been enormously encouraging. In only three weeks—21 days—the hotline has taken more than 20,500 calls, which is an average of just below 1,000 per day. Those calls have generated a request for 11,125 application kits. The enormity of that response augurs very well for the final outcome that the government wants to achieve, which is that those inquiries translate into applications for citizenship. I repeat that there have been 20,500 calls and 11,125 requests for kits in less than three weeks.

As Senator Zakharov also said, the government is concerned to ensure that people talk about the concept of citizenship and its meaning for Australians towards the end of the 20th century. The campaign that we launched in Sydney was one of a number of campaign launches. There have been launches in all other states. Two things have tended to emerge from those launches and the number of people involved with them. The first is the diversity of the backgrounds from which the people have come. The second is the enormous pride that they all take in making a commitment to Australia.

The role of the media in the objective of the government has been quite encouraging. Be it print, talk, talkback radio, television, all aspects of the media have got behind discussing the issue in a way that promotes the whole concept and encourages people to take up citizenship. In terms of that media debate, a number of issues have arisen. One is the raising of the profile of citizenship, and the other is the concept of dual citizenship. Those issues were canvassed by the Joint Standing Committee on Migration. That committee reported to this parliament just a few weeks ago. I will be responding to the recommendations of that committee early next year.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to four recent government decisions; namely, the new cable television rules, the ditching of the open skies agreement with New Zealand, the ANL rescue package, and the Creative Nation commitment to assist in the site preparation and development of a movie studio in Sydney. Is it a fact that at least three of these four decisions are the very antithesis of Hilmer and will reduce, rather than enhance, competition? Why were none of these decisions approved by cabinet, only by the Prime Minister in collaboration with various ministerial mates from the New South Wales Right? Given Mr Keating's long record of doing deals not in the public interest, why should Australians not be extremely suspicious of this repeated avoidance of cabinet scrutiny of prime ministerial decisions?

—There is no basis for any suggestion of inadequate or incomplete process so far as these particular decisions are concerned. In the case of each one of them, there was a time constraint of one kind of another. For example, with the Air New Zealand exercise there was the imminent arrival of the 1 November deadline. In the case of the pay television decision, there was the consideration that a bidding auction was under way for product and the parties were desperately keen to get a decision out of the government and no cabinet meeting had been scheduled in that particular time frame so as to make a cabinet process possible.

PARA.TAB: Cabinet has been meeting extremely regularly. It has met 17 times in 21 weeks since July. There have been 21 cabinet committee meetings in the last 21 weeks. Cabinet processes are absolutely central to the way this government performs and operates, and will continue to be so.

The second part of the answer is that it is a bit of a cheek for the opposition to be telling us about our process, given the way in which it has shown a conspicuous incapacity to get its own act together when it comes to almost any item on the public policy agenda at the moment—whether it is the Racial Hatred Bill, whether it is the ATSIC land fund, whether it is its attitude to fiscal policy and budget numbers and how on earth it is going to square the circle there or whether it is an attitude to the constitution and the republic issue and how it is going to get that. The opposition is in a comprehensive shambles.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, on a point of order: this cannot, by any stretch of the imagination, be relevant to the question. The minister is now addressing the policy issues of the opposition. That is obviously irrelevant and I suggest you recommend that the minister return to the question.
—I understood Senator Evans to be making a very brief excursion into political debate in answering the question. I take it that he has now finished that part of his answer.

—What I am saying very simply is that we do not need any instruction from Senator Alston or anyone else on how to get our policy act together when those opposite so conspicuously have not got their policy act together, quite apart from anything else.

—Mr Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for that comprehensive plea of guilty. It is quite obvious that these were major, controversial decisions, all completely ignored by the Prime Minister in terms of cabinet consultation—contempt for the democratic process. I ask: if the minister seriously claims that there were time constraints in respect of each of these decisions, why does he not spell out what those time frames were and why it was that the government did not have time to quite get around to having each of those decisions properly considered by his colleagues? For example, is it not a fact that the cable television rules will now force Australians to pay more for local phone calls, which will mean that the pay television industry will remain heavily subsidised by a taxpayer owned government enterprise in the form of Telecom? Is it not the real fact that none of these decisions could have withstood the gaze of cabinet, let alone the light of day?

—I am indebted to Senator Alston for his expression of confidence in cabinet and cabinet processes. I expect to see some further evidence of that in the future. The basic answer is that it is none of his business how we go about reaching our decisions and it will ever remain so unless and until the electorate is ever misguided enough to give those opposite the chance of doing the same thing.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Trade. In its 23 November edition, Australian Business Asia reported on research into the level of services provided by trade bodies. The minister would no doubt be pleased to know that Austrade received a positive rating of around 90 per cent from those interviewed. Can the minister advise what Austrade is doing to build upon its increasing effectiveness in supporting Australian trading performance?
—Mr Deputy President—
—Why are we losing market share, Bob?

—If you would like an answer, ask a question. I have seen the report and I am pleased by it. It is a very rewarding and very positive assessment. But it is not surprising, because it is not out of kilter with the assessments made by others. For example, it supports the evaluation recently done by AGB McNair, which showed that Austrade helped Australian exporters make $4.8 billion in exports in 1993-94, an increase of 14 per cent on the previous year's result.

PARA.TAB: Given that that research was commissioned by Austrade, although it was done by an independent body, people may have some doubt about it as an absolute measure of effectiveness. But the relative performance, the 14 per cent increase, is a direct and appropriate comparison and reinforces the view that, on the basis of these two independent surveys, Austrade is substantially responding to the major changes made by the government to Austrade in the post-McKinsey era under the excellent work of the chairman, Robert Johnston, and managing director, Ralph Evans.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why are we continuing to lose market share?

—Opposition senators know that there is a very good answer to their interjection. That is why they do not ask about it. Austrade, while it has good cause to be pleased with those outcomes, is not standing still. It is researching ways in which it might do better. I want to refer today particularly to two aspects, although there are a number of others.

PARA.TAB: First and foremost, there was the launch today of the new logo for Austrade. We got feedback from around the world that the existing logo, effective as it was in Australia, was not seen internationally as an effective representation of Australia. Therefore, it needed some sort of modification to make it internationally effective, and we have done that. It is an important and substantial modification. It will be part of a major increased promotion of Austrade internationally.

Of itself, that is not sufficient to achieve a good outcome; you need to put in the services that underpin the presentation. I am very pleased to report on one particular initiative of Austrade that I think Australians, particularly those in small business and in regional centres, will be pleased with. Austrade will take the services which it now supplies to business in the major capital cities and major regional centres to small-to-medium enterprises in regional Australia. It will not spend taxpayers' money on building edifices around the nation. It will take the services out through the existing local government, state government and other Commonwealth networks to create services for Australians wherever they live and work.
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Notwithstanding the interjections, it remains our view that it does not matter where people live. If they pay their taxes, they are entitled to have fair access to the services, and we intend to continue to provide those services to them.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport. I refer to the government's disastrous handling of the opening of the third runway at Sydney Airport, which has reduced the number of aircraft movements at the airport from 65 to just over 50 an hour and which has dramatically increased the level of aircraft noise in the suburbs to the north of the airport. What a double banger! Will the government reopen the east-west runway, which would increase the capacity at the airport and distribute the noise more equitably?

—We do come across some breathtaking stuff in here from time to time when getting criticisms from members of the opposition. During the period that I spent in that portfolio I got more representations from both senators and members of the federal coalition about opening the third runway at the first available opportunity than just about anyone else, particularly from those members and senators representing regional centres outside of Sydney. The reason for the east runway not being in that position is quite simple—that is, advice from the CAA that for both operational and safety reasons it would be unwise to do so.

—Mr Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. Apart from the quite dishonest reply by the minister about advice from the Civil Aviation Authority, why does the minister not display a little bit of honesty for a change and admit that the reason the government will not reopen the east-west runway is to protect the right wing mates—Brereton, Punch and McLeay—at the expense of the left wing members for Sydney and Grayndler, but, more importantly, at the expense of those innocent people who live in the inner suburbs like Stanmore, Petersham, Lewisham and Marrickville?

—One of the values of a parallel runway system, as Senator Parer knows full well, is that it removes the need for simultaneous operations of cross runways, across parallel runways. It is better to operate a parallel runway system without a cross runway system for safety reasons. Those opposite are the same people that are constantly complaining about aviation safety. It is pathetic.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction, Senator Schacht. Today's Australian reports some comments made by the minister about uniform standards and measurements and their relationship to trade in the Asia-Pacific region. Can the minister inform the Senate what role Australia is taking in this matter and what the benefits may be to Australia and the region should there be a successful outcome?
—Yesterday in Sydney I hosted the opening session of the Asia-Pacific legal metrology forum. I know most of those opposite may get the issue of metrology mixed up with meteorology.
—Mythology.

—Yes, mythology may be better for the Liberal Party these days. This is a very important forum. It is being hosted by the National Standards Commission, which I have responsibility for within the industry portfolio. It will discuss issues such as regional cooperation, the harmonisation of metrological requirements and the mutual recognition of tests and certification. It is being attended by 12 members of the APEC organisation and eight from countries of the south-west Pacific that are not members of APEC.

PARA.TAB: The use of uniform standards and measurements between countries in the Asia-Pacific region is a very important issue and will help APEC achieve its target of free trade by 2020. By harmonising measurement requirements and achieving mutual recognition requirements, the forum will make a valuable contribution to regional cooperation.

This meeting is important in view of the Bogor declaration of only 10 days ago. That Bogor declaration estimated that a free trade outcome in the Asia-Pacific region could be worth more than $300 billion of additional real income to the economies of the Asia-Pacific area. It is also estimated that the information from related measurement activities could add 4 per cent to the gross domestic product of national economies. For the APEC countries this amounts to $450 billion annually. If we really want to see success in this area we need to get the harmonisation of these measurement requirements across the APEC region.

Harmonisation is one thing the Liberal Party is not very good at. Look at the rabble opposite. Harmonisation and unity are not words that sit well with the Liberal Party at the moment. With the proper harmonisation of trade measurement rules it will be easier for Australia and other countries in the region to trade more successfully with each other. Therefore, metrology—measurement—issues are very important for the free trade goal of Australia. The fact that we are holding the first forum is the beginning of that process within the APEC region. I am sure all senators, including those opposite, look forward to the success of the outcomes of this very important forum.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Collins representing the Minister for Transport. I refer the minister to the bloody-minded disruption to air passenger and cargo traffic being caused by the TWU's national strike in support of its 12 per cent wage claim in defiance of the Industrial Relations Commission. Given the inability of most businesses, directly and indirectly affected, to protect themselves from economic damage, and the inability of passengers to protect themselves, will the government introduce emergency services legislation similar to that which exists in the states to ensure the commission's orders are not defied with impunity?
—I will redirect that question to the Leader of the Government.

—It is a question most appropriately addressed to the industrial relations spokesman but he is a bit reluctant, so I am happy to respond on behalf of the government. The government supports the Industrial Relations Commission's decision to suspend the bargaining period which had been notified between the oil companies and the TWU over enterprise agreements for aircraft refuellers and oil tanker drivers. The Minister for Industrial Relations did indicate on 16 November that enterprise agreements have to be determined at enterprise level, not at industry level.

PARA.TAB: The government condemns the TWU strike action in defiance of the Industrial Relations Commission's decision, and we have made that absolutely clear. With the bargaining period suspended, strike action taken by the aircraft refuellers and oil tanker drivers is not protected by the provisions of the act. That opens the way for oil companies to seek a range of remedies provided for in the act. If they choose not to exercise the rights available to them at the moment because they judge that will be inflammatory, that is a matter for their judgment; it is not a matter for the government to second-guess them.

The call by the opposition spokesman on industrial relations and, of course, its putative leader, Mr Howard, for national essential services legislation to be able to deal with disputes of this kind is simply an attempt to make obvious political capital out of the current industrial situation rather than being any kind of practical suggestion to help in its resolution. Existing Commonwealth and state laws provide ample scope and flexibility to deal with an emergency situation. In the case of every state, there is emergency services legislation presently in existence and, in the case of the Commonwealth, in relation to serious industrial action of this kind, there are various remedies available, including bans clauses, stand downs, suspension of awards, orders restricting a registered organisation's rights under the Industrial Relations Act; plus there are common law remedies, for example, for interfering with contract.

The government's position is absolutely clear. It has been applauded by the companies in this instance which have expressed strong support for the support they in turn are being given by the government. While we are perfectly willing to accommodate the reality of some degree of industrial disputation in the specific context of enterprise bargaining conducted at enterprise level, because that is the logic of the process to enable some degree of disputation of that kind to take place in the natural course of industrial relations, we are not prepared to accommodate disputation taking place on an industry-wide basis, which is against the spirit and letter of those particular provisions. And we are certainly not prepared to accommodate industrial disputation taking place in direct defiance of the Industrial Relations Commission's determination.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 15 November, Minister Crowley, in answer to a question by me on child care, made this curious assertion:

QUESTION.PARA: There are . . . basically no outlays for the cost of child care provided in the home as compared with the cost of child care outside of the home.
There is no . . . example in any other of the tax systems for the transfer of costs within the family itself.

I ask the minister: why does she think that that contribution is costless? Does she really think that the labour of a non-earning spouse caring for children at home costs nothing, while that provided by others is worth something? Does she think that mothers who have made the decision to leave the paid work force to look after their children forgo no income? How can she deny both the direct costs incurred and the incomes forgone where a spouse looks after children? How does she explain those particular statements?

TALK.START.PARA: —Part of that question should be properly directed to the minister with responsibility for taxation. But I do not resile from the responsibility that belongs to me at all. There is no outlay—and I did use that word—for child care. It was interesting that Senator Harradine asked why there should not be a tax treatment or at least some kind of consideration of costs for child care outside of the home as apart from the cost of child care within the home.

PARA.TAB: But he did not ask me this question about mowing the lawn. He did not ask me this question about doing the laundry. He did not ask me this question about a whole lot of things that are done in the home and enjoy tax relief outside of the home. Why be selective? Why are we picking just one comparison between something done in the home and something done out of the home? This is one of the things that surprise me—there is a selective examination of what goes on within a home and what is valued within a home. There is a lot of work being done that suggests that in the not too distant future we may have to rethink how we value the work that is done within the home. That is not a new suggestion. The government has been looking at that for a long time. I know the Democrats have raised it as something that is very important.

For Senator Harradine to just pick one issue is quite interesting. It may not be done; it may be done. But why would he want to pick one example? Why not argue about some other things? Much of his question asked me to speculate or to have an opinion. It did not go to facts. I do not resile at all from what I said in answer to him the other day. As to the matters that ask for an opinion, as I say, I do not think it is appropriate for me to comment further.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. I refer to a document presented to the Labor Party caucus committee for the environment, sport, tourism and territories entitled `Brief on the Proposed Oyster Point Development'. At page 4 in the section entitled `Current position—Cardwell', the document states, amongst other factors:

QUESTION.PARA: This region is dominated by strong National Party representation in both federal and state parliament.

All National Party representation is strong and vigorous. I ask: since when has the political party to which the local member belongs been a deciding factor in determining whether a project approved by a state Labor government should be overridden by the minister on behalf of the Commonwealth? Is this the standard of decision making we are going to get in the future? Is the minister going to veto every project in a National Party electorate on the assumption that decisions should continue to be exercised for the good of the Labor Party instead of the good of the nation?

TALK.START.PARA: —I think even for Senator Boswell that is a rather silly question. I have not seen the document to which he refers, though I am aware that the caucus environment committee received, as it often does, a delegation and listened to views expressed on this particular development. I take the decision making processes very seriously. My responsibility and obligations in this issue go to the protection of the World Heritage values of the Great Barrier Reef World Heritage area. In that regard, I have acted absolutely properly. I can assure Senator Boswell that there is no significance as to who the local representatives of the Cardwell area are in either the state or the federal parliament. This decision was made on the basis of departmental advice and the decision making process did not go to those sorts of political considerations.

—Mr Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. The document to which I refer is riddled with inaccuracies. For example, it said that development included a golf course, which it did not, that it would be the largest integrated resort in Australia and that the Aboriginal community was not consulted. Most importantly, it suggested that the development was exempted from an EIS by the Office of the Coordinator-General in Queensland when in fact an EIS could not have been imposed because the project had already obtained the necessary zoning approval. What efforts did the minister take to correct these inaccuracies when the document was presented to the committee? Did the minister do nothing at all, or was he too sucked in by this sort of deception when he made his own decision?

—As I have indicated, I did not talk to the caucus committee about this issue. I believe that a submission was made by a group of interested conservationists who were given the opportunity to present a case and present their view to the caucus environment committee. That is not an unusual procedure, and it had nothing to do at all with my role or the decision making process that I involved myself in or that was part of the process engaged in by my portfolio.

—I direct a not unexpected question to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Can the minister guarantee that no beef being sold to Australian consumers is contaminated by the chemical chlorofluorazon or helix? What guarantee can be given that no similar chemical contamination will occur and what monitoring mechanisms will now be put in place to ensure that Australian beef never contains chemical residues?

—It is true that I was expecting that question but I was actually expecting it from the opposition; it is a fairly obvious question to ask. The following measures have been implemented by AQIS and state governments in cooperation with the relevant industry sectors to ensure that Australian beef does retain its reputation for safety and wholesomeness: the immediate discontinuation of the use of cotton trash for cattle feeding purposes, the identification of cattle enterprises known to have fed cattle cotton trash material—and this is possible because of the records that have been kept by the cotton industry—and, as necessary, the placement of detention orders on those cattle enterprises whose animals have shown CFZ residues in excess of the Australian maximum residue limit. This action would preclude the slaughter of cattle until levels have declined to below the MRL. We are 100 per cent lot testing of cattle from properties that are in the risk areas. We are testing carton beef held in store from at risk districts produced prior to the commencement of the targeted testing. Levels of monitoring under the existing national residue survey have been increased and there has been the provision of extension services to cotton and cattle industry members to ensure full understanding of these management measures and to prevent future occurrences.

PARA.TAB: Authorities conducting meat inspection at domestic meatworks in New South Wales, Queensland and Victoria have instituted an equivalent inspection and sampling program to those in place at export meatworks for cattle sourced from the risk areas. This involves, as I have said, a 100 per cent lot testing program of cattle from properties in the risk areas. Product is removed from the domestic food chain if testing indicates levels above the MRL. The National Health and Medical Research Council has advised that consumption of meat containing CFZ residues up to the MRL presents no risk to human health and the MRL was deliberately set at a very conservative level to ensure that meat would be quite safe to eat.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for that answer. I am sure that Australian consumers are assured by it. What I would like to know—and I am sure they would like to know as well—is whether the equivalent meat inspection for export that has been conducted in New South Wales Queensland and Victoria will continue and on what basis—on a nationally consistent basis or reliant upon the cooperation of the states.

—Those services are very much state government responsibilities and, I might add, always have been. But a high level of cooperation is always given, and was on this occasion, to dealing cooperatively with AQIS. Our principal involvement, as Senator Bell knows, is with export. But there is always a high level of cooperation and that cooperation has been evidenced on this occasion. Constitutional responsibility for the control and use of agricultural and veterinary chemicals rests with the states but, as I am sure Senator Bell knows, the registration of agricultural chemicals will be under the control of national legislation from early next year when the national registration scheme is expected to commence after the final two states, Western Australia and Tasmania, have passed the required legislation.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Family Services. The National Council for the International Year of the Family in its final report released last week highlighted all the anomalies and problems in the government's programs to assist families with young children and called for the amalgamation of the child-care cash rebate and the home child-care allowance. Is the national council right or wrong in its criticisms of the operation of the government's child-care programs? If the council is right, what is the government going to do about it and, if it is wrong, why is it wrong?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen The Hon R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a very bold question from Senator Minchin in the light of the division on family policy in the opposition over there. It is the opposition which has established the Lyons Forum.
—Have a go at answering the question.
—I will certainly get there, Senator Hill, in my good time. I wanted to remind the opposition about the Lyons Forum and one of the better quotes from one of its own members, Mr Bradford.

—I rise on a point of order, Mr Deputy President. It is not Senator Crowley's own good time; it is our good time that is at stake here. The Senate is entitled to have an answer to a question about whether the report was right or wrong. That is no justification for a divergence into someone else's attitudes. I ask you to bring Senator Crowley to order.
—Senator Crowley, I ask you to address yourself to the question.
—Yes, I am. It is important that opposition senators listen very closely because as their own Mr Bradford said:

ANSWER.PARA: I think in the past the Liberal Party—

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order, Mr Deputy President. This is deliberate defiance of your ruling. Mr Bradford is a member of the Lyons Forum, as Senator Crowley well knows. She is simply regurgitating a predetermined line. The question was whether a report is right or wrong—a pretty simple proposition. She should be directed to answer it.
—And she can answer it how she chooses.
—She cannot, my friend. It is a pity you do not read the rules either.

—Senator Crowley, the standing orders do require that you respond to the question not in terms of the opposition's view. If you are doing what all ministers do, you will restrict your discursion to just a few moments.

—I might come back to the discursion. We have received from the council a very comprehensive report entitled Creating the links. It canvasses very extensively a number of issues, particularly payments to families, and services to support families. Anyone who is interested in family policy should welcome such a comprehensive analysis. I was going to make a point about Mr Bradford and the Liberals opposite, but in particular Mr Bradford. Mr Bradford says that he is concerned about Liberal Party policies on family—
—You were asked whether it is right or wrong.

—Yes, I am getting there. Some people in the Liberal Party have been tainted by contemporary thought. We on this side are not afraid of contemporary thought. We have actually got a report that reflects what the Australian community raises as serious issues.
—Is it right or wrong?
—No, this is not a right or wrong question; this is a question about how best we can improve on policy.
—I rise on a point of order, Mr Deputy President. Senator Crowley just accused Senator Minchin of asking the wrong question. Would you ask him to ask the right question or rule her out of order.
—I am sure Senator Crowley understands that the answerer must respond in terms of the responsibility of the minister. I am sure she is about to do that this very moment.
—As I said, the important thing is that that report from the council is actually the culmination of extensive consultation with Australian people—70 public forums and over 500 meetings.
—Answer the question.

—Senator, I am. It is what the community of Australia is saying. The report picks up on what the Australian people recommend. It is one of the documents that will very extensively assist government in formulating its Australian government agenda for families. We will be examining the report and all its recommendations very extensively. But we are not about to leap to a judgment or leap into despair or conclude one way or another until we have very thoroughly examined it. Because a number of the recommendations cover a number of portfolios, including those of a number of my colleagues, I am not about to make comment until they too have had an opportunity to examine these recommendations very thoroughly.

PARA.TAB: There is no doubt that it, along with the conference last week—a very useful conference on families and a fitting climax to the International Year of the Family—will provide very good assistance to government, not to formulate policy but to build on the comprehensive family policy that is already in place. This government does not shy away from reform. It does not shy away from seeing ways in which it can improve.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are shying away from answering the question.

—No, not at all. In fact, I think it is very important that we accept the importance of listening to the community. From time to time there are ways in which we can improve or make things better. We will be examining that report to see whether there are recommendations that we can pick up to do just that.
—Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

—Order! Earlier today I reported to the Senate the death of Sir Magnus Cormack. Sir Magnus, of course, was a very distinguished former senator and President of the Senate. He had an outstanding career in the Senate and made an enormous contribution to its work and proceedings. Before his death he strongly expressed the wish that the use of a condolence motion and subsequent speeches not take place in the Senate. I understand it is the wish of honourable senators that this wish be respected. I ask honourable senators to stand in silence to acknowledge the passing of Sir Magnus Cormack and to remember the great contribution he made to the Senate.

TAB.EMPHASIS: Honourable senators having stood in their places—

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer by the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner), to questions without notice asked by Senator Ian Macdonald and Senator Boswell this day, relating to development at Hinchinbrook Island.

SPEECH.PARA: Australians have seen a quite remarkable and unprecedented action by a state Labor premier in that he has taken out a full-page advertisement in the Australian and many other sections of the national media—certainly, the media in North Queensland—publicly criticising the way in which the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, Senator Faulkner, has handled the Oyster Point-Port Hinchinbrook matter. Mr Goss is concerned about the backflips by Senator Faulkner—the fact that Senator Faulkner has had all the details of this proposal for several months and it was not until right at the death that Senator Faulkner chose to take some action to stop work on the project. That, of course, raises the point as to whether there is any serious environmental concern by Senator Faulkner about this matter or whether it is simply part of the ongoing Labor Party factional brawl.

PARA.TAB: It is interesting to note that a prominent Queensland unionist has now become involved in this Oyster Point matter. It is a unionist by the name of Ian McLean. I do not quite know what Mr McLean's union is but I was not aware that it had any major involvement in this Oyster Point project. It is interesting, Mr Deputy President, as you would know, that Mr McLean used to be the Queensland president of the ALP. He is a member of the Left, like Senator Burns, but he was unceremoniously dumped in a bloody coup by Premier Goss earlier this year. So this left wing president of the Queensland Labor Party was dumped by Goss and his right wing mates, and he has been absolutely fuming ever since. One cannot help thinking that Mr McLean has got his left wing factional allies, Senator Faulkner, Senator Burns and Senator Reynolds, onto the job to embarrass Mr Goss and to make Mr Goss pay for the stabbing of their mate Mr McLean.

I know that Senator Burns and another Labor senator have been slinking around the back blocks of Cardwell—not publicly, not meeting with people there—trying to find out how they can possibly do anything. He and his Labor Party colleagues understand that the tide is against them politically in that area and Senator Burns is slinking around there trying to find out what sort of solution there might be to get the Labor Party out of this enormous mess, this factional battle between the right and left wings of the Labor Party.

As I indicated in the question I asked—a question which Senator Faulkner was not able to answer, or chose not to answer—it really is up to this parliament to demand from Senator Faulkner answers to those questions. Is it a fact, as Mr Goss asserts, that every one of what Mr Goss calls the `strictest environmental controls' was checked and approved by the federal government—by Senator Faulkner and his department? Is that true? Is Mr Goss correct or is Senator Faulkner correct? They both cannot be because they are saying different things. One of them is telling lies, and I think we as the parliament and the people of Australia want to know who it is.

Is it a fact, as Mr Goss asserts, that the approvals given included the approval to remove the same small area of mangroves that Senator Faulkner halted in his 15 November order? Is that right? Is Mr Goss correct? Is the Queensland Labor Premier telling the truth in this full page advertisement when he says that, or is Senator Faulkner telling the truth? They cannot both be telling the truth because they are saying different things? Was Mr Goss correct when he said that the issue of mangrove removal was never specifically discussed in the 10 months of detailed consultation between the federal government and the Queensland government?

TALK.START.PARA: —No, he wasn't.

—I hear the left wing faction of the Labor Party sticking up for Senator Faulkner again. Senator Kernot is in the paper praising Senator Faulkner and wanting to be part of the team, which she always is. The Australian Democrats agree with the Labor Party on everything. The people I represent want to know the truth. They want to see Senator Faulkner up there, and they want him to see what is really happening. (Time expired)

—I wish to make a comment on this item as well. Senator Ian Macdonald is determined to turn this issue into a conspiracy when, in actual fact, if there were a little commonsense, a little preparedness by a few people to come out of their respective corners and sit down, negotiate and discuss this issue, I am confident it could be worked out very easily. The problem is that we are dealing with egos of people who are not prepared to admit that perhaps they did not always have all the information, and I am speaking particularly of the developer, Keith Williams.

PARA.TAB: Keith Williams has his own idea of what kind of development should go on the site. He could be continuing to work up there at this very moment if he would cooperate, but he would rather grandstand and turn on the local community and split the local community. I emphasise to Senator Ian Macdonald that I am in possession of a petition that shows just how many Cardwell residents—

TALK.START.PARA: —Five of them.
—Oh, no, Senator. Will I name them? No, I will not name them because of the threats and intimidation that are going on.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators—Ha, ha!

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased that the opposition laughs. I am very pleased that the listeners can hear that the opposition thinks it is amusing when people get death threats. I am very pleased that the opposition thinks it is amusing when a 67-year-old woman who has been supporting the environmental protection actually has her home threatened.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. Is Senator Reynolds suggesting that members of the opposition are issuing death threats? If not, could she indicate who is?
—That is not a point of order, and you know it.
—It is a point of order if she is inferring—
—It is not a point of order.
—You speak on it, Senator Crowley, if you think you know anything. You know nothing about your own portfolio. What would you possibly know about this?

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Colston)—Order! Senator Ian Macdonald, if you are making a point of order, make a point of order. Do not go into great discursion.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am being distracted by those vicious interjections from the Minister for Family Services, and, Mr Acting Deputy President, you are not protecting me. Senator Reynolds suggests that someone has been making death threats. I am not sure that she is suggesting we have been doing it, and she should be clear on that. If she is suggesting someone else is doing that sort of thing, it is a matter of very great concern in this parliament that she should name them and have them brought before the parliament.
—Order! There is no real point of order. Senator Ian Macdonald was making a point. I am sure that Senator Reynolds can continue.

—A number of statutory declarations have gone to the Minister for Police, Paul Braddy. They have been put in writing to his office and will be dealt with. I am not suggesting death threats in this chamber; I am suggesting that it is pretty poor when the colleagues of Senator Macdonald laugh at the thought of threats. Those threats are in statutory declaration form. It is a very serious matter. He might not think it is serious, but many on this side and many other senators think it is important.

PARA.TAB: The issue that we are debating is who is right. Is the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner) correct or is the premier correct? The senator opposite may not have noticed that it is not unusual for people to have differences over important issues. This is a very important issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who is right—Goss or Faulkner?

—Obviously, Premier Goss feels very let down because he thought this development was going ahead and he then found that there were problems, which I am sure had not been drawn to his attention. So his action in taking out a full page advertisement is perfectly understandable. However, even the best premiers, like the best ministers, are not always absolutely correct. They may not necessarily have all the information at their fingertips all the time. The issue is not who is right or wrong but how we will resolve this dispute. That is the important issue.

PARA.TAB: Keith Williams should talk to some of the well-known ecotourist developers in Queensland. I recommend that he make contact with a Brisbane based architect, David Toohey, who, in an article in the property section of the weekend Courier-Mail, says that Queensland is missing out on the ecoboom. In other words, we are still putting forward old-style 1980s resorts instead of going into sensitive, environmentally friendly ecotourist developments. That is what this is all about. It is not about who has got it right and who has got it wrong. Where will we go from here? How can we get a good resort that is appropriate for that site?

TALK.START.PARA: —What does Ted Lindsay say?

—Ted Lindsay is very concerned about the division in that community and the failure of Keith Williams to be prepared to take advice on an appropriate ecotourist development. It is not a question of whether that development has to close down. Keith Williams has decided to close it down. He only wants an old-style development. Anyone who cares to look at the record of Hamilton Island will see that that resort is not functioning as effectively as it should. It is old-style, 1980s style; it is not ecotourist style.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —Instead of going into the usual Senator Ian Macdonald style of bashing somebody else, I want to look at what Mr Goss said in the advertisement and show why he is misleading the public. He said:

PARA.TAB: We have been concerned to ensure that the Port Hinchinbrook Resort has minimal impact on the environment . . .

SPEECH.PARA: If that is so, why has there never been a full, independent environmental impact assessment? Surely if he did care about World Heritage values, this is the minimum he would insist upon. More importantly, why was the environmental review report rewritten to such a significant extent after the developer wrote a letter to the coordinator-general which read:

My suggestions for amendments to the report are not negotiable on the grounds that I am not about to embark on this major project with skeletons in the cupboard that I will have to argue about at a later date.

What sort of a process is it we are talking about where the developer can threaten with the statement, `I am not going to build unless you agree to this', and we see the Queensland premier responding to the changes on behalf of the developer?

PARA.TAB: Why did the Queensland government insist that baseline studies be done at almost the same time as the mangroves were being cleared, thus providing a fait accompli and affecting the baseline studies? Why did the Queensland government refuse to release so many reports and refuse to or not complete FOI requests on environmental information,

SPEECH.PARA: even after the Coordinator-General had signed a memorandum of understanding in December last year? Mr Goss also says—this is his big plea—that this resort `was approved in the 1980s by the National Party Government'. So he is saying, `We did not have any choice in the matter, we good little Labor government.'

PARA.TAB: What he does not say is that his own Labor government in the last few months has given the developer the most environmentally damaging approvals for this project. It is the Queensland state Labor government which has given a permit to discharge into the marine park under the Clean Waters Act. It has also given a Canals Act permit, a Harbours Act permit, a Marine Parks Act approval and a permit to clear 6.5 hectares of mangroves for what the developer calls `aesthetic reasons' and what Senator Parer calls `the total concept'. It is the Queensland state Labor government which has given a permit to occupy a marine park. Mr Goss could have refused any of these permits, but instead he forced them through. Mr Goss has also said:
As a result of extensive environmental assessment . . . we approved a smaller project with some of the strictest environmental controls ever imposed on a development in this State.

SPEECH.PARA: How misleading is that? There has never been a full environmental impact assessment. There may well be an agreement with environmental controls, but it has already been breached for several reasons—by mud slump into the creek, by no independent environmental monitor and by the developer not providing monthly updated work plans as he was requested to do.

PARA.TAB: Mr Goss in his letter also says that Senator Faulkner says he took his action because of his concern about the effect of mangrove removal of the seagrass beds in the World Heritage area. He goes on to say that no such concern has been mentioned by anyone during the 10 months of detailed consultation. This is probably the most misleading thing.

I have seen submissions to Mr Goss's coordinator-general from three conservation groups, four scientists, the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority, the Australian Institute of Marine Science, through the Valentine report and from Mr Goss's own scientists at DPI and the Department of Environment and Heritage, all expressing concern over the mangrove clearing.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Valentine report was afterwards.

—There were all the rest of them, all expressing concern. Dr Tony Preen said in a letter to Senator Faulkner, which was passed on to the state government, that a number of members of the public in their submissions to the coordinator-general discussed the removal of mangroves as a concern.

PARA.TAB: But the most damning evidence comes from the Queensland government's own principal scientist from the northern region, Rob Coles, who drew attention to this. I do not have time to quote it all. Mr Goss said:
Our Government has co-operated with the Federal Government . . .

SPEECH.PARA: Why, then, did both Mr Goss and Ms Robson refuse to call a moratorium on the clearing when Senator Faulkner requested it? Mr Goss says:
Our concern for the environment has always been at the top of our priorities . . .
He also says that a recent expert report has warned of a `sea of mud' that will damage world heritage values. That is what he has been told now for months. Mr Goss said:

PARA.TAB: The handling of this project raises serious issues . . .

SPEECH.PARA: We agree. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe that what we have seen today from the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner) is an absolute disaster in terms of public administration. Senator Faulkner in his answer to Senator Boswell today admitted that he had no knowledge of the details contained in the document which Senator Boswell referred to, which was presented to his own caucus committee on environment, sport, tourism and territories. Here we have a minister who is supposed to be overseeing a department. He pays so little attention to the process that he does not even turn up to the meetings of the caucus committee that is supposed to oversee his portfolio. I seek leave at this point to table a document.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Colston)—Order! Is leave granted to table the document?

TALK.START.PARA: —Not until I have seen it.
—They do not like the truth. I will send Senator Crowley a copy of the document. They do not like the truth that this document is highly inaccurate and Senator Faulkner does not have the ability—

—I rise on a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. The usual niceties in this place allow people on this side to see a document before leave is requested. That is all I was referring to, Senator; do not misrepresent it. If you want leave, then come and seek it.
—Order! There is no point of order.
—Senator Faulkner is totally incapable of overseeing what happens in his own caucus committee, let alone what happens in his own department. This document is manifestly inaccurate.
—Rubbish!

—Senator Burns wants to know what the inaccuracies are. Let us start off with the inaccuracy that this resort will accommodate 1,500 guests and 750 staff on-site and will be Australia's largest integrated resort. There is no proposal to house the staff on-site. Many resorts in Queensland are bigger than this resort. In fact, I stayed in one the other night when I was on the Gold Coast. Those resorts are substantially bigger than this one. It is just a lie to say that it will be the biggest integrated resort in Australia. It is a lie to say that it will include a golf course. A golf course will not be built as part of the development. The developer will use the existing Cardwell golf course. There will not be an international airport, as is suggested in this document.

PARA.TAB: All of these things in this document are false, but they are false for a reason: they attempt to paint a misleading picture of the development. What Senator Faulkner did, either through ignorance or through his own inability to oversee the process, was allow—

TALK.START.PARA: —Or both.

—Possibly both, Senator Abetz. Senator Faulkner allowed the caucus committee to be snowed by a misleading and deceptive document. Senator Faulkner ought to hang his head in shame that he pays so little attention to what goes on. He admitted that he did not even turn up to the committee meeting where this presentation was to be made. If a coalition frontbencher did not turn up to a committee meeting of the coalition backbench which oversaw his or her portfolio, he or she would simply be strung up. That sort of behaviour shows a total and utter disregard for proper process and good administration. But that seems to be what we get from Senator Faulkner.

PARA.TAB: This document suggests, for example, that the approval for the channel was fast-tracked through the Office of the Coordinator-General. Of course, that is nonsense. It took 18 months to get the approval from the Office of the Coordinator-General. It is wrong to suggest that there was an attempt to evade the EIS because all the zoning applications had already been obtained for everything for which Cardwell Shire Council could give a zoning application.

This document is severely deficient in its explanation of the environmental concerns. The document does not mention the fact that the mangroves in question have been cleared twice in the last 15 years. It does not mention that the seagrass is nowhere near the breakwater or the channel. Those are the sorts of inaccuracies that are in this document. Senator Faulkner allowed his own caucus committee to be snowed and misled. It is either because Senator Faulkner is incapable of exercising his role as a minister or because he wanted it that way. But Senator Faulkner has very grave, wide ranging powers which were given to him under the act. I believe that Senator Faulkner, through his ignorance and duplicity in allowing the committee to be misled, has shown himself to be incapable of exercising those powers properly and he should be taken out of the portfolio.

TALK.START.PARA: —I journeyed to Cardwell last week. I did not go slinkingly; I went very openly. I was very concerned to talk to people who were public spirited, unlike Senator Ian Macdonald who went up there like an exhibitionist. He paraded and bared his body to the waist to put on some silly T-shirt indicating support for a resort that should not go ahead. Senator Macdonald talked a load of rubbish about Ian McLean, the previous President of the Labor Party in Queensland. He is a good unionist and has been more public spirited and done more good for the community in this country than Senator Macdonald ever has or ever will. He is an official of a very important union which is an amalgamation of three previous unions, shortly to be joined by two others. It will be an organisation that will be very substantial in the community.
—What has that to do with Oyster Point?
—Senator Ian Macdonald, you had five minutes earlier and you have had another five minutes since. I would ask you to be quiet.

—Let us make a comparison between Keith Williams, who bought the resort, I understand, for $500,000 and those people who are concerned about the environment. I have spoken with people in Canberra from the Aboriginal community. I have also spoken with people from ATSIC in Townsville and other people in Ingham who make up the Aboriginal community. They clearly do not want this resort to go ahead in its current form. They want to have some say in the nature of the resort and their role in it.

PARA.TAB: Let us have a look at what the supporters of Williams are saying. I was in a hotel the other evening when Senator Faulkner's measured statement about what should be done to ensure the integrity of the World Heritage area came on the TV. Some uncouth yobbo with two or three of his mates started directing abuse at the TV set and threatened to physically assault Senator Faulkner if he should come to Cardwell. Is that reasoned debate? Are those the sorts of people one would want around supporting one's ideas?

There is an issue of the integrity of Mr Goss as against the integrity of Senator Faulkner. I suggest in this instance that the letters that were written are very clear indeed. There is no doubt that Williams, after destroying most of the mangroves, wishes to establish a sand beach in place of the mangroves which would encroach on the seagrass beds and destroy them. If it did not destroy the seagrass beds, then more sand would be put on the beach which would further aggravate the situation and make sure that they were destroyed. Senator Faulkner clearly has a responsibility to guarantee the integrity of the World Heritage area.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about some jobs?

—Senator Ian Macdonald says, `What about some jobs?' A reasonable resort with probably 100 beds or a few more will also provide jobs. The integrity and condition of the World Heritage area is absolutely important. The federal government and the state government did not decide that that area has World Heritage value. It was decided by a world body which has agreed that it should be protected.

PARA.TAB: We can also look at some of the other attitudes that have been expressed. Mr Hallam, the President of the Chamber of Commerce, has been quoted in the press in this regard. By his own admission he is money hungry. He is concerned only about making a profit and not concerned at all with the future of that particular area.

I have known that area and been through that area for 40 years. I know that many of the people of Cardwell went to the area because it was a quiet place and they did not want any development. They were happy there. There are still some people who want to live there quietly with a reasonable cost of living who are concerned about what will happen to their rates and other values and what changes will take place in the community.

There are amongst the people of Cardwell a few Johnny-come-latelys who are there to make a quid and will sell out at the highest possible price and leave those who stay behind to face the repercussions. The 500 people who have signed the petition saying that they do not want the resort to go ahead in its current form have shown a great deal of courage, given the sort of abuse and hooliganism displayed by the supporters of Keith Williams. Let us have a look at how democratic he is and how much he wants to hear different points of view. Only supporters were invited to his meeting. (Time expired)

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator O'Chee asked for leave to table a document. That is okay by the government.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will also address this matter. There are a number of points I want to cover. Both Senator Reynolds and Senator Burns talked about getting together petitions. We know how they have engineered their petitions. We know about the rent-a-crowds. We know about the free buses from Townsville. So Senator Burns should not give us that dishonest stuff.
