PARA.TAB: The point I should make is this: why has Senator Faulkner gone down this road which Mr John Laws calls Faulkner's super folly? I will tell honourable senators why—
Government senators interjecting—
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Colston)—Order on my right!

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. Those opposite are a left wing rabble. Why has Senator Faulkner gone down this road? If honourable senators would like to read the Bulletin of two weeks ago, they will find the answer. Ex-Senator Richardson, who made his name up in the Daintree, wrote an article in which he said that Senator Faulkner has to make a name for himself somewhere in the environment. He said, `He cannot, unfortunately, do it in Tasmania'—Senator Sherry will be pleased to know that—`because we, the government, signed a deal with the Tasmanian government when we snatched the last bit of land off them, and we said that we would not take any more land.' The lines at the bottom of the Bulletin article say that Senator Faulkner had better make an issue of Oyster Point in Hinchinbrook Passage. That is the only way he can make a name for himself. Here was an opportunity for Senator Faulkner to make a name for himself.
—To do a Richo.

—But he does not have the brains of ex-Senator Richardson. He picked the wrong one. He has got the whole of North and Far North Queensland in absolute fury. Senator Faulkner, in response to Senator Macdonald, said that he has not stopped the project. That is dishonest. A project—as I interjected to Senator Kernot before—is a total concept. It includes the total operation. We cannot halve it; we cannot quarter it; we cannot have politicians or bureaucrats saying how big it will be. That is a commercial decision. This project that is to be built is to have 750 beds and an inland marina; it is bordered by the main highway where we can see the big signs that say `Senator Faulkner's folly'—thanks to John Laws. He obviously gave him the tip-off for that. Inside is an area that was cleared seven years ago. I looked at the mangrove areas and I photographed them. They are minuscule—something like 100 metres by a couple of metres.
—Foreshore mangroves we are talking about.

—All mangroves are foreshore mangroves; that is where they start, and then they go inland. As Senator Macdonald found, Senator Faulkner made a decision to stop a $100 million project without ever going to the site. Who in this country would make a decision like that, which is at the expense of the local community, without even looking at the site? Then, having made the decision, he has not got the guts—
—That's the sort of thing you see all the time.

—Of course, the left wing unions do it all the time. They have no regard for the attitudes of people, for individuals, for the ability to create jobs. Senator Faulkner made a decision without even looking at the site. How irresponsible can one be? This is just indicative of the irresponsibility and the mismanagement of this government. (Time expired)

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Motion (by Senator Harradine)—by leave—agreed to:
That the time for taking note of answers this day be extended by 10 minutes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley), to a question without notice asked by Senator Harradine this day relating to home child care allowance.

SPEECH.PARA: Normally when one receives an answer to a question about which one is confused, one asks a supplementary question. The response by Senator Crowley was so vacuous and so nonsensical that I just did not feel like asking another question to get a similar response.

PARA.TAB: I think it is very important to understand what Senator Crowley's response was, and to do that we need to put it into context. I prefaced my question by referring to her answer to my question of 15 November. In that question I said:

SPEECH.PARA: If, as the minister states constantly, child care is a cost of earning income, why is it not also a cost for a one-income family in which one spouse cannot engage in paid work if the other does not care for the children?

I went on to a number of other questions. Her response to me, as I adverted to in my question today, was that there are basically no outlays for the cost of child care provided in the home as compared with the cost of child care outside the home. Then she went on:
There is no comparable example in any other tax systems for the transfer of costs within the family itself.

Obviously she has not heard of the US, French, Irish, Belgian and other tax systems which recognise the contribution of spouses to earning family income by allowing income splitting or quotient apportionment for family members.

PARA.TAB: Today she said she did not resile from her statement. She did not answer the questions that I again asked today. Does she really think the labour of a non-earning spouse caring for children at home costs nothing while that provided by others is worth something? Does she think that mothers who have made the decision originally or at the time to leave the paid work force to look after their children forgo no income? Does she truly believe that? If she does, she is off the planet. I am really worried about Senator Crowley and her understanding of her portfolio of family services. How can she deny that a direct cost is incurred and income is forgone where a spouse looks after the children?

It is so clear to me and I am sure to all the Senate that the response of the Minister for Family Services was a dreadful failure. What did she also say? She rubbed salt into the wound. She said that one does not get any payment for lawn mowing. Lawn mowing! I did not think the minister believed that lawn mowing was a cost of earning income. We are talking about the cost of earning income. The minister herself has agreed that child care is a cost of earning income. If one spouse is earning the income, surely a cost is incurred by the other spouse caring for the children.

It is logical—unless, of course, Senator Crowley believes that those who receive the child-care rebate for the cost of child care also should get a lawn mowing allowance, for example, and that the others should not. It is incredible. The fact is that it is recognised when families split up, when divorce takes place. We all know that, in family law decisions, work performed by the non-wage earning spouse is recognised for the purposes of income splitting. I believe it is time Senator Crowley was spoken to by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) or somebody else and told to get her act together.

TALK.START.PARA: —I feel somewhat inadequate taking note of the answer following on from the fine contribution of Senator Harradine. Senator Harradine described the answer of the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley) as being somewhat fatuous. I fully agree with that. There would be no more respected—
—Vacuous.

—Oh, `vacuous'. Chances are that both would be applicable. I misheard Senator Harradine. There would be no more respected person in this place or genuine defender of family values than Senator Harradine. One would have thought that the minister might have given a bit more consideration in her answer to Senator Harradine, who has sat in this chamber as an Independent now for some 18 years, and that she would have treated that with the degree of respect that it deserved and tried to come to grips with the thrust of Senator Harradine's question. Instead, we got a response which was all over the place. It was an embarrassment not only to this government but to her colleagues.

PARA.TAB: Unfortunately when ministers sit on the front bench, often when they are answering questions they do not see the looks on the faces of their colleagues who sit behind them. It would have been a good experience for Senator Crowley in recent times if while she was answering a question she had turned around and seen the look of dismay on the faces of her colleagues. Senator Crowley would have to be one of the weak links in the Labor government. We know that there are many weak links, but she would have to be one of the weakest. I was absolutely astounded during her answer when she referred to the unpaid work of lawn mowing and laundry type work within the home. I have never known that the government considered that it would be appropriate, for example, to subsidise laundromats within the local community or to provide a subsidy for lawn mowing so that people can go out to work. But that is what she has done with child care.

If Senator Crowley honestly believes that the role of a parent looking after a child at home ought to be equated with the role of a person who might mow the lawn once a fortnight, who might do the washing every couple of days—or, if there are a lot of children, possibly every day—and that he or she ought to be treated in the same way as a parent who makes a deliberate decision for the benefit of those children, and ultimately for the benefit of society and Australia, to forgo income to give those kids a head start, then she is mistaken. She parades around this country as the Minister for Family Services, but that would have to be a misnomer because she does not seem to have a grasp of what families are about or the services they need. As the Minister for Family Services she has been a dismal failure.

The Labor Party in Senator Crowley has a minister who is grossly incompetent. She is an embarrassment to her colleagues and she has a unique capacity of not coming to grips with the questions that are fielded to her by anybody other than the government. Today we witnessed her trying to respond to Senator Nick Minchin, my friend and colleague from South Australia, who also has a very strong background in support of families and the services that they need. He has been a good advocate for them in this chamber. When he asked his question what did we see Senator Crowley do? Her defence was, `Senator Minchin has asked the wrong question.' She could not answer the question, so what did she do? She said, `Senator Minchin, you have asked the wrong question.' That sort of display by a minister is nothing short of embarrassing to Australia as a whole. It is not about party politics. If a minister does not have a grasp of the subject matter at hand and says to an opposition senator, `I cannot answer that question because you have asked the wrong one,' then surely she has a problem. Similarly, for the way that she treated Senator Harradine today at question time she also deserves to be condemned.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
A message from His Excellency the Governor-General was reported informing the Senate that His Excellency had, in the name of Her Majesty, assented to the following law:

PROCTEXT.PARA: Primary Industries Legislation Amendment Act 1994 (Act No. 137 of 1994)

DEBATE.TITLE: ATSIC AMENDMENT (INDIGENOUS LAND CORPORATION AND LAND FUND) BILL 1994

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Consideration of House of Representatives Message

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to the message I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate does not insist on the request disagreed to by the House of Representatives.

SPEECH.PARA: The government made its position perfectly clear on this particular matter when it was last debated in this place on 16 November. The particular request seeking an additional appropriation of $3 million in order to cover the administrative costs is not accepted by the government as being a reasonable further impost, given the large amount of money that has been made available for the total purpose of this legislation, including not only land purchasing and land administration but also the administration of the process itself.

PARA.TAB: The government's position, as I said, has been made perfectly clear in the earlier debate in this place and also by the minister at the table in the other place, Mr Beazley, when the request was debated on 17 November. Under those circumstances I need detain the chamber no longer, but I simply express my hope that we can proceed to deal with the substance of the legislation by accepting my motion and then proceeding immediately to the third reading and enabling the matter to go back formally, accordingly, to the House of Representatives.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make some comments on this motion to not press the request and not send the request for $3 million back to the other place for consideration. The government is now clearly and fully on the record in terms of its commitment to this land fund and to Aboriginal people. I was listening very carefully to Senator Evans's words when he was trying to justify the rationale for the House of Representatives' rejection of this amendment. I think he was very wise to say that the amount of money that has been allocated for management and administration does not need to be increased. He did not mention the word `acquisition'.
—I said `purchase' and `management'.

—Did you? I did not hear that, Senator Evans, but if you did say it I stand corrected. I note that the terms `acquisition', `dispossessed' and `restitution for the dispossession of their lands' have disappeared from the government's vocabulary. In particular, `land acquisition fund' has disappeared from the government's vocabulary in relation to this land fund bill.

PARA.TAB: The rejection by the House of Representatives of this $3 million additional request, which would actually quarantine the acquisition and management funding from the costs of administration, has been done on the most patently hypocritical of grounds. Not having been able to support an endeavour to quarantine acquisition funding from management funding by supporting an amendment of the Greens in the committee, the government now refuses to limit the amount of administration funding to what it initially stated was a $3 million cap. The government's own figure was used for that amendment. It said it will grant $3 million in administration. If the administration costs remained at that level of $3 million, the only thing eating into the management and acquisition funding would be the management costs under this fund.

The refusal of the House of Representatives—and also of the government and the Democrats in this chamber—to support that request to the House of Representatives indicates that it does not actually want to prevent the administration costs eating away at the acquisition component of the land fund.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you voting to press this request?

—I am indicating that I am in support of pressing the request to the House of Representatives because that is a legitimate and appropriate thing to do. I want to put on the public record why, just in case that motion does not get agreed to. It is a legitimate right of mine to pronounce what I consider are the implications of, firstly, the rejection in the House of Representatives of our request and, secondly, the committee's inability to press that request. It means we are acceding to something the government has done that shows up its credibility in relation to the Aboriginal people of this country who stand to gain nothing from the native title legislation or from any management funds.

PARA.TAB: The Aboriginal people of this country who deserve and need this land fund are those who have been totally dispossessed by settlement of this country. They are the people who need to acquire land, which will in some places replace what they no longer are able to gain under the native title legislation. In some cases it will mean that they can acquire land which could have been theirs if it had not been taken up with other forms of title which extinguish native title. They will be able to reacquire the land that was originally their people's land and their people's country.

This government refusal to quarantine the administration costs from those of acquisition and management is a despicable act. It is a miserly amount, not a generous amount as seems to be implied by the rhetoric of the government and of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and even by the media's false acceptance of the government's words. It is a paltry amount of $21 million, which was going to be $21 million for the ILC in this coming year and for the next three years, with $3 million for administration costs. We are now told that there is no guarantee that there will even be $21 million available because the Minister for Finance, Mr Beazley, in the House of Representatives stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The government rejects the idea of a cap on the administrative expenses of the ILC and, consequently, any further appropriation to cater for those expenses.

We now know that this government is only prepared to give $24 million beyond its current allocation for the land acquisition and management costs within Australia for the Aboriginal community. It is not prepared to increase the allocation by a measly $3 million and neither is it willing to quarantine the inroads of any administrative costs that might go beyond that $3 million from eating into acquisition funds.

PARA.TAB: This should be on the public record because the government's credibility is in tatters. This is not the fund the Prime Minister announced, at the time of the native title debate, would be set up for those dispossessed—95 per cent of the Aboriginal people of this country—who do not stand to gain from native title. It is a management fund; it is a duplicate bureaucracy to that of the ATSIC land fund bureaucracy. It has no credibility in the eyes of any Aboriginal person who has no land at the present moment. It is a signal to such Aboriginal people that, unless they are within a few steps from the front of the queue for this miserly amount of $21 million, they will get nothing. They will never get anything because the amount will be totally eaten into by management and administration within the next 10 years, our best case scenario, or possibly far quicker than that.

The Greens indicate we would like to press this amendment. We are not proposing to call a division if we do not have support, but we want to clearly indicate that it deserves to be pressed. We deserve an answer as to why the government cannot do better than this paltry fund, which it is refusing to amend or concede any improvement to by the consideration of the chamber.

We have here a government that is incapable of managing a democracy. It is quite capable of negotiating agreements outside the parliament. It is quite capable of pushing legislation through the House of Representatives by numbers. But it is incapable of accepting that Australia has a bicameral system of parliament, that the people have a say, that there is a states aspect to the legislation, that there is a review aspect to the legislation and that the Senate has a perfect right to amend this legislation.

I ask those people who are not pressing the amendment and who might seek to go on to the third reading to be warned, because the minister, Mr Beazley, has also made it quite clear in his statements in the House of Representatives that not only is the government not supporting the request for $3 million more to quarantine the administrative costs from the land management and acquisition costs but the government has indicated that it is not prepared to support any of the amendments that have been made in the Senate, or at least to support what Senator Evans referred to as the seven deadly sins. I think the seven deadly sins have been replaced by one deadly sin, which is the deadly sin of the government that it is so arrogant that it will not accept what has happened in the debate in the Senate and it will not even accept an increase of $3 million on its current allocation. Let the whole Aboriginal community and all those who care about social justice for Aboriginal people take note that this is where this government comes from.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have thought about this matter. I have had the opportunity to read what was said in the House of Representatives in response to our request. I think it was a cavalier approach taken by the government, knowing that it had the numbers in the House of Representatives on this issue. We debated this particular request, not ad nauseam but at length. I believed, and still believe, that the arguments advanced in support of the request were valid. I still believe they are valid.

PARA.TAB: I know there have been statements made by the government or representatives of the government about this matter—that if we are going to press the issue there is a possibility that they will jettison the legislation. Well, be it on their heads. I do not want to see this legislation jettisoned. I want to see it do what it was meant to do—that is, to provide as much money as possible to be used as far as possible for the acquisition and management of land, not to be eaten up by endless uncapped administrative expenditure.

There have been public discussions about that issue. The suggestion was made: why not increase the amount by $3 million in addition to that which was suggested by the government? Of course, we could not amend the bill because we did not have the constitutional power to do so. What we had to do was make a request to the House of Representatives for that to occur. The government has now made it clear that it is not interested. We want to add an additional $3 million, but it is not interested.

The government makes the unfounded assertion that we do not have regard for what ATSIC says about this matter. We do. I have certainly had regard for what ATSIC has said and written about a whole range of matters. Perhaps in contradistinction to some people, I have agreed with much that they have said on some other issues over the years. But I do not think we should be kowtowing with regard to what the government might or might not do. I think the legislation should achieve its objectives. I saw this request as one of the means of achieving those objectives, or at least the basis for ensuring that the objectives, as far as that was possible, were achieved.

I will be opposing the motion that has been moved by Senator Gareth Evans. I would like to see this motion defeated, the third reading take place and then for us to look at the amendments. The government has said we might not be able to look at the amendments, although I do not think the minister has said that to us in so many words. There have been arguments relating to the practicability of one of the amendments since we have discussed them here. I would like to hear arguments for and against that when that particular amendment comes back for our consideration.

With regard to this matter, I believe we should press the amendment, and press it strongly. I hope that the matter goes to a vote, that the third reading takes place and that the House of Representatives then considers the amendments properly, not in the offhand way in which it has appeared to consider this request.

TALK.START.PARA: —I listened carefully to what Senator Chamarette and Senator Harradine have said. One of the coalition's concerns is that the government has shown no sense of fairness when it has dealt with any of the proposals put up by the Senate. We know that the proposal that extra funds be appropriated to meet the administrative expenses of the land fund was a very genuine attempt at bipartisanship on this matter. I think it was a test for the government as to whether it wanted to be bipartisan—or non-partisan, to use the Democrats' phraseology—on this matter.

PARA.TAB: I was appalled to read the editorial in the Australian newspaper on the Friday before last that said that opposition senators, the Greens and Senator Harradine had obstructed the progress of this legislation and were holding up the expenditure of $200 million. I think it was a very sad reflection on what is widely regarded as a quality national and international newspaper that whoever wrote that editorial should have been deceived by the spin doctors in the Prime Minister's department that $200 million was going to Aboriginals. Clearly, no-one from the Australian newspaper had listened to one nanosecond of the debate in the Senate if they could be fooled to think there was $200 million waiting to be spent on Aboriginal land acquisition. Of course, the amount, as Senator Chamarette told us almost daily, is only 10 per cent of that amount.

This request should have highlighted the government's hypocrisy on this legislation because it was a request for $3 million to pay for the administration and a generous percentage of the amount available for land acquisition. The government and its spin doctors chose to say, `We're putting a cap on their expenditure.' They did not choose to focus on the fact that we were actually seeking an extra $3 million. It certainly was a test of the government's goodwill on this matter. Last time we were debating this matter in committee Senator Gareth Evans had to put up his seven deadly sins, which we have called the seven straw men. He had to say, `These are all the things that are unliveable and unworkable about this legislation.'

The coalition, in putting out its media release shortly after Senator Evans made his statement in this place, went through and rebutted the workability of these notions. To say that the government could not possibly live with $3 million more for administration is, of course, a joke. To say that the national strategies could be integrated with the regional strategies is, of course, a joke—and it is simply stupid to suggest that they should not be integrated. To say that the ILC must have perpetual control and that de facto ownership of the land is unworkable is, of course, a joke.

The one that really hits home and really exposes the arguments of government members against the amendments and why they will not even come to the table and talk about them—not even discuss them, not consider them—is that if we press the request they will put the bill aside, will not even consider it, will give the money to ATSIC and will not even discuss it. They showed that when they dealt with the $3 million request. The Minister for Finance (Mr Beazley) spoke for about two minutes and said, `No, we are not having that. Send it back.' That is how much consideration the government gave to what could only be regarded as a bipartisan, non-partisan gesture to test the government's goodwill on this matter—and, of course, there is no goodwill. The ultimate one is that the government says there should be no consultation with traditional owners. So the ILC will go into an area wanting to purchase some land saying that it is unworkable and not fair that we be required to go and talk to the traditional owners.

Senator Chamarette and I had the opportunity to discuss this position with Justice Robert French, the head of the Native Title Tribunal, last Thursday. We were discussing all of these matters of giving notice to traditional owners under the Native Title Act provisions and what is required to find out where all the parties are in the mediation process. Of course, Justice French could not discuss his personal views on that but, quite frankly, anyone who has been out there dealing with land issues could not possibly concede the logic of the government's argument that one can go into an area and purchase some land and not seek out the views of the traditional owners. There are three other ones as well.

The government has shown no willingness to move forward on any of these amendments at all. I am not saying there are more Aboriginal groups supporting these amendments than there are not. We do not know that. People come and talk to us; we talk to them; Lois O'Donoghue puts her view and says, `If you don't agree with this bill as it stands, you are wrecking the reconciliation process.' There are all of these views.

The problem with pressing this request is that it puts the government in control and allows it to put the bill aside, to shelve it, to send the money to ATSIC, or to do any of those things. The Senate would not be doing its duty if it allowed that to happen. Just to press this one request and allow the issue of this $3 million to be the thing that is considered by the government is not the sensible, legislative way to go.

I would foreshadow, as a more practical way to resolve this matter, that the matter of the amendments and the request be referred to a Senate select committee. I foreshadow that I will move that. I ask that the motion, including the terms of reference, be distributed in the chamber now and that the Senate give consideration to this motion. I foreshadow it at the moment, but I propose that the matter of the amendments that have been made by the Senate, as well as the request for the extra administration money, be referred to a Senate select committee. That committee would be required to consult with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities around Australia as to the workability and the general nature of the amendments, whether or not they in fact seek to achieve what the parliament seeks those amendments and the bill to achieve—in other words, to allow the people who are most affected to have a first-hand say in the amendments, particularly these crucial ones that have caused the disagreement amongst Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.

There is much disagreement in the community. We have only to look to this morning's Australian Financial Review. An article on page 2 by Michael Dwyer actually refers to disagreement within the ranks of the cabinet and federal government ministers. It states that there are divisions that need more negotiation and consultation to solve and that this is the right way to go.

I hope the Senate will support the reference to a Senate select committee. I would propose that the Senate select committee be made up of two people nominated by the government; three by the Leader of the Opposition; one by the Australian Democrats; and one by either the Greens or Senator Harradine. I propose that the committee be required to report at the earliest possible time—that is, 31 January 1995—so the government cannot accuse the Senate of any delay. There would be no more possible delay than would happen under the government's scheme, which is to set it aside or basically to dump the bill altogether. I also propose that the terms of reference be as read. The amendment has been circulated and, clearly, will have to be dealt with later. I, therefore, propose that this committee now report progress.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you pressing the amendment?
—I move:

PARA.TAB: That progress be reported.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Would Senator Campbell answer my question, please? Is the opposition pressing this request or not? I am not sure.

—It is quite clear from what I said, if Senator Kernot had been listening. The coalition is suggesting that the matter of the request being pressed not be dealt with by the committee but that the committee report progress with a view to establishing a Senate select committee to look into the request. I believe that, if we dealt with the request, it would be superfluous for a Senate select committee to look into it. That is the position of the coalition, and we will move it in that way.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator McGauran)—Senator Kernot, the motion before the chair is that progress be reported.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, but I have not had an opportunity to speak on the request. We are dealing with a request. We are not dealing with all the amendments; we are dealing with one request. I put it to Senator Campbell that he is seeking to avoid taking a vote on this amendment, on the third reading and on anything to do with the land fund because of the problems in the Liberal Party at the moment. The Liberal Party is hoist with its own petard. It wants to be seen to support principle when all it wants to do is avoid taking a vote.

PARA.TAB: This morning the opposition delayed taking a simple vote on this request. We have had 30 hours of debate on this bill. The only thing that has changed in the week since we have not been in this place has been the statement by shadow minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander affairs, Mrs Gallus, and the responses by some of the opposition's own members. That is what has changed. This morning those opposite could not come in here and say, `Yes, the request we asked for, which was based on principle, is still very important to us.' Yes, the principle is important, but the principle of self-determination of Aboriginal people is never as important when there is leadership turmoil. That principle is never as important as the principle of avoiding a double dissolution trigger.
That is the real deadly sin. If you want to talk about the seven deadly sins, these are the motives behind Senator Campbell's tactics and the opposition's tactics. If the principle is so clear—

TALK.START.PARA: —You are wrong.
—Yes, I know I am right.
—You are wrong, I said.

—If the principle was so clear one week ago, nothing has changed in this debate to make that principle less important. The only thing that has changed is the opposition's predicament. That is what this is about. I am sure the government could find $3 million if it wanted to. The issue is not one request or one amendment in isolation, is it?

PARA.TAB: Senator Campbell interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a technical distinction. The issue is the totality of the amendments that the coalition has made to this bill.
—Are you voting for the request?

—We are not going to have the request. Senator Campbell is shoving it off. He is avoiding the issue, and delaying the legislation yet again. He is using any tactic he can think of. It took him five hours between this morning, when he could not vote on this request, and now to think up this wonderful device to delay yet again delivering a modicum of justice. That is all we are talking about. Make no mistake: this is a desperate and dishonest act on his behalf. I do not think we can take any rhetoric of the last 30 hours—
—Mr Temporary Chairman, I raise a point of order. I ask that that be withdrawn. I do not think it is a fair reflection on my character.

—On the point of order: an honourable senator cannot accuse another honourable senator of committing a dishonest act, especially in the ordinary processes of this chamber. That is a disgraceful reflection, and it ought to be withdrawn.

—On the point of order: it is one thing to describe an individual senator as dishonest. It is another thing to describe a tactic being adopted by a particular senator, reflecting the view of his own party room, as dishonest. In all the circumstances of the case, that is what Senator Kernot was doing. She is fully entitled to do so in accordance with the precedents of this place.

—Senator Kernot, if you directly related it to Senator Campbell, I think you should withdraw. The opposition believes that you have done what is claimed. In the spirit of that, I ask you to withdraw, particularly as you were granted leave to speak.
—I was denied leave to speak by the opposition.
—You were not.
—I was, because the opposition moved to report progress.
—Senator Gareth Evans is correct. You can call a tactic dishonest, but not a person. You know that, so I will leave it to your judgment.

—Yes. It happens. I am happy to withdraw it if Senator Campbell thinks it applies to him. But I still think it applies to the tactic. It is a dishonest tactic to seek to delay for five hours a simple debate and a vote on the matter of a request so that one can have an emergency meeting to work out tactics on how to deal with avoiding to take a vote on this land fund bill at any cost. That is what this is about and the opposition cannot hide from it. It is a disgrace—
—Proper scrutiny.

—Proper scrutiny! It is a disgraceful act and it is a dishonest tactic. Let us concede that most people do not take much notice of what we do in this place. The opposition thinks it can get away with this little tactic. It thinks, `Send it off again. Who will take any notice of another select committee? Who cares about the cost or the time? The most important thing is that we do not get a debate on this bill before Christmas.' That is its primary motive, and I object to it.
—The question is that Senator Campbell's motion to report progress be agreed to.

PARA.TAB: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: I move:

PARA.TAB: That the committee have leave to sit again at a later hour this day.

SPEECH.PARA: I move this motion because the committee made no progress at all, in fact, in its earlier deliberation on the request matter. It is the government's firm belief that the matter of the request should be pushed to resolution today.

PARA.TAB: The arguments are clear on both sides. They were amply and well debated. I stress again the substantive point: the government's proposal doubles the current allocation for acquisition and management of Aboriginal land, it appropriates funds for 10 years into the future and it establishes a billion dollar fund which will be entirely devoted to funding land acquisition and management in the indefinite future. All of this is on top of current allocation to ATSIC of some $900 million, plus $400 million-odd to other agencies. They are the substantive issues that we believe ought to be brought to resolution today.

There is no case, as Senator Kernot has said, for further delay on this matter. It is simply a tactic on the part of the opposition. In the event that the opposition should want to further pursue this tactic by referring, as was foreshadowed, the request and all the other amendments off to a select committee, that will only be making even more manifest the nature of this particular enterprise on which it has embarked.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: Omit all words after that, substitute:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)"For the reasons set out in paragraph (2), further consideration of the bill be deferred until the select committee established by the subsequent provisions of this resolution reports.
(2)That the reasons referred to in paragraph (1) are as follows:
(a)the bill has been significantly amended by the Senate but there is disagreement among Aboriginal persons and Torres Strait Islanders about some of the amendments;

PARA.TAB: (b)because of these disagreements senior ministers in the government are urging fresh negotiations and consultations with Aboriginal persons and Torres Strait Islanders to diffuse divisions that have emerged concerning the value and efficacy of the bill in its original and amended forms:
(c)some attempt must be made to reconcile those differences, including by means of select committee evidence which may urge compromise leading to the redrafting of amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: (3)That a select committee, to be known as the Select Committee on the Land Fund Bill, be appointed to inquire into and report, on or before 31 January 1995, on the following matters with respect to the Senate's amendments and request for amendment, to the ATSIC Amendment (Indigenous Land Corporation and Land Fund) Bill 1994:

PARA.TAB: (a)whether, taken as a whole, the amendments and request achieve the aim of making the bill a more effective instrument to assist those Aboriginal persons and Torres Strait Islanders who will be unable to assert native title rights and interests to acquire land and manage it effectively;

(b)whether any of the amendments or the request should be modified, or deleted and replaced with alternative amendments, in order to reconcile disagreements among Aboriginal persons and Torres Strait Islanders and better achieve the aim set out in paragraph (a);

(c)such other matters, arising in the course of the committee's inquiry, in relation to the amendments and the request, as the committee determines are reasonably relevant to reporting on the foregoing terms of reference.

SPEECH.PARA: (4)That the Committee consist of seven senators, as follows:

TAB.TAB: (a)two nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate; and

PARA.TAB: (b)three nominated by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate; and

TAB.TAB: (c)one nominated by the Leader of the Australian Democrats; and
(d)one nominated by the Greens (WA) or Senator Harradine.

SPEECH.PARA: (5)That the Committee may proceed to the dispatch of business notwithstanding that all members have not been duly nominated and appointed and notwithstanding any vacancy.
(6)That:

TAB.TAB: (a)the chair of the committee be elected by the members of the committee from the members of the committee;
(b)in the absence of agreement on the selection of a chair, duly notified to the President, the allocation of the chair be determined by the Senate;
(c)the deputy chair of the committee be elected by the committee from the members of the committee immediately after the election of the chair;
(d)the deputy chair act as chair when there is no chair or the chair is not present at a meeting; and
(e)in the event of the votes on any question before the committee being equally divided, the chair, or the deputy chair when acting as chair, have a casting vote.

SPEECH.PARA: (7)That the quorum of the committee be four members.

(8)That the committee and any subcommittee have power to send for and examine persons and documents, to move from place to place and to sit in public or in private, notwithstanding any prorogation of the Parliament or dissolution of the House of Representatives.

(9)That the committee have power to appoint subcommittees consisting of three or more of its members, and to refer to any such subcommittee any of the matters which the committee is empowered to consider, and that the quorum of a subcommittee be a majority of the Senators appointed to the subcommittee.

(10)That, without limiting its power to pass procedural or other resolutions that are not inconsistent with this paragraph or these terms of reference, the committee observe the following procedures, namely, that:

TAB.TAB: Submissions and calling of witnesses

(a)as a general principle, evidence be invited in the first instance in the form of written submissions and following examination of submissions, the committee decide which witnesses are to be called for examination; and

(b)subject to any contrary order in relation to a particular submission, the submission to the committee by a person of a statement relating to the inquiry be deemed to be the giving of evidence before the committee by that person in accordance with that statement.
Evidence
(c)evidence be heard in public session except in instances where the committee or a sub-committee resolves to hear evidence in camera.
Statements to the media

SPEECH.PARA: (d)the chair be authorised to make statements to the media on behalf of the committee concerning its activities.
Broadcasts and re-broadcasts of public proceedings

TAB.TAB: (e)the recording, broadcasting and re-broadcasting of public proceedings is authorised in accordance with the rules contained in the order of the Senate of 23 August 1990, as varied by the Senate from time to time, concerning the broadcasting of committee proceedings.

SPEECH.PARA: Release of evidence and documents

TAB.TAB: (f)the secretary is authorised to supply for correction, copies of proof reports of both public and in camera proceedings to the witnesses whose evidence appears in those reports.
(g)subject to any contrary order in relation to a particular submission, each document submitted to the Committee be published.

SPEECH.PARA: Adverse Evidence

TAB.TAB: (h)subject to any contrary order, evidence which adversely reflects on a person, be forwarded to that person inviting their response.

SPEECH.PARA: (11)That:

TAB.TAB: (a)the terms of reference of the inquiry be appropriately advertised in the media; and
(b)written submissions be sought and examined by the committee and oral evidence be heard, including oral evidence from the authors of the most important submissions.

SPEECH.PARA: (12)That the committee be provided with all necessary staff, facilities and resources and be empowered to appoint persons with specialist knowledge for the purposes of the committee, with the approval of the President.
(13)That the committee be empowered to print from day to day such documents and evidence as may be ordered by it, and a daily Hansard be published of such proceedings as take place in public.

(14)That the committee may report from time to time its proceedings and evidence taken or any interim conclusions or recommendations arising from its inquiry, and may make regular reports on the progress of its proceedings.

I take this opportunity to respond to the remarks of Senator Kernot, who is obviously angry and frustrated at this move. It cannot be said that the Senate is in any way delaying consideration of this bill. It was the government which said that it would withdraw this bill and put the funding through ATSIC. It is the government which said that if we insist on the request the bill could be set aside. It is the government which has refused to even contemplate any amendments whatsoever. It has mentioned its seven deadly sins as things it could not possibly live with.

PARA.TAB: The government has said on each occasion when amendments have been put up that it has had this most broad consultation process in the history of Australia. Particularly those of us who sat on the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration know just what that consultation was. There is a document on the public record—it was provided to the committee—which sets out who was actually written to in relation to that legislation. We know from the public utterances of Aboriginal groups and Aboriginal individuals across Australia, and from those who gave evidence to the committee, that the consultation process was far from adequate. We know that many Aboriginal groups support radical amendment to the land fund bill.

There is certainly disagreement. The Greens think there should be certain amendments that we do not agree to. Senator Harradine supports some amendments that we do not agree to. There is some common ground between the Greens and the coalition on a range of amendments. There is even common ground between the government and the coalition on some minor amendments, but there is broad disagreement amongst many Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people and their representatives on the shape of this bill. Senator Chamarette made it quite clear during the debate that she thought it would be better not to have any land fund bill than have the one the government has at the moment without the amendments.

The coalition now seeks, in a timely way, through the weeks available in January, until 31 January, to move throughout the community and get genuine feedback and conduct genuine consultation on the ground by talking to the Aboriginal people and to Torres Strait Islanders to find out what they really think about the bill and the amendments. It is a genuine consultation process—something that has not been touched on by the government.

Every time the government consults, it makes a phone call. We do not quite know whom it rings. But it can make a decision to oppose the $3 million of administration expenses at the drop of a hat. It is quite incredible that any Aboriginal group would say, `We do not want $3 million to pay for the administration. We would rather have the $3 million eat into the money available for land acquisition.' That must have been a very interesting consultation. We are saying that the government should go out and talk to the people affected.

The coalition has come a long way in proposing amendments that focus the bill and in fact make it more representative of and more effective in addressing the needs of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. We may not have it right. We are not like the government in that we cannot say, `We think our amendments are the be all and end all. We think that when our amendments go through the bill will be perfect.' We know very well that the bill will not be perfect, but we know equally well that if you go out and do a genuine, thorough consultation process then you will probably get it more right than it is now. That is why we are proposing this amendment.

We could have predicted five hours ago that if we proposed a Senate select committee Senator Gareth Evans and Senator Kernot would say, `You are delaying it.' We are not delaying it; we are actually giving the bill some life. If Senator Kernot had voted on the request, it would have been shunted back over there. The government has already said that it will not accept any amendments and it would set the bill aside.

We are saying that we will use the next few weeks constructively to find out how we could make the bill work. They are the specific terms of reference. A specific task is to make the legislation effective, to try to reconcile the differences, to try to figure out whether when Senator Evans says that these things are unworkable they are unworkable. We will be convinced. If they are unworkable, then we will be convinced and constructive, but the government will not be.

The time frame is short—it is shorter than it really should be—but we specifically said the first sitting day of 1995, which is 31 January, so that we could not be accused of delay. Quite frankly, we should probably have the committee sitting for another month or so so it can be done even further, but we said, `Let's make it the first day in January so we can't be accused of delay.'

The reality is that if the government and the Democrats got their way the bill would go back over to the House of Representatives, which might pick up two or three of the less contentious amendments and send it back over here without agreement to 65 of them. It would not do any genuine consultation because that does not suit the political agenda of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating).

Senator Kernot talks about triggers and so forth, but the reality is that this makes not one iota of difference to all of that. That is not our intent. For Senator Kernot to suggest that it is the coalition's intent is quite ridiculous. We could have had the vote on the request today.

TALK.START.PARA: —You avoided it.
—We could have had the vote on the request. Perhaps Senator Kernot will tell the Senate how she was going to vote on the request.
—I think I was going to vote for it.

—You were going to insist on it. That would result in a process whereby there would be disagreement between the chambers and no genuine consultation. This proposal ensures that there will be genuine consultation with Aboriginal people and Torres Strait Islanders across Australia. It will ensure that, when the report comes back to this parliament on the first sitting day of the new year, 31 January, there will be genuine public discussion on all of these issues. It will ensure that all Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people will be consulted.

PARA.TAB: We will not have a process whereby this debate will be taking place in this quite unreal place thousands of miles away from Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Australians and whereby the only public debate is filtered through the people who live on the second floor. We will ensure that the community genuinely sees what this land fund bill can and should do. It will allow for feedback from the community.

It is very important that we take this legislation seriously. The coalition, the Greens and Senator Harradine and the Democrats every now and again have been constructive in looking at the amendments, amending the amendments, finessing the amendments and trying to find agreement and common ground. We have now been told after 30 hours of debate that the government just cannot live with it. We have seven sets of amendments that it just cannot possibly live with. I repeat, because it astounds me, that one of those things that the government cannot live with is the fact that, when the ILC goes out to purchase some land, it is considered unworkable that it goes and speaks to traditional owners. That is absolutely outrageous. It is outrageous that it cannot live with $3 million being set aside for administration expenses to ensure that the money goes to land acquisition and management. It is just absolutely outrageous.

TALK.START.PARA: —You didn't press it.

—Is Senator Kernot really suggesting that we should send it back to the House of Representatives? What will it do when she presses it? When the House of Representatives comes back next week, it will send it back here again. So where will we be? Right back where we are now. What I am proposing is something constructive. I am proposing that we go and talk to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. I hope Senator Kernot is on that committee. I hope she will have an input as to whom we go and talk to. I hope she will listen to those people and not just the government and her caucus colleagues.
—I hope I am on the committee.

—I hope you are on the committee and I hope you will take it seriously. I will not go on any longer. The wisdom of referring this bill to a Senate select committee is quite clear. It seems that the Democrats do not want to consult with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. They do not want to take it out to the people whom it affects. They would rather keep it in cosy Canberra where it can all be discussed between Senator Kernot, Senator Evans and a couple of people over at ATSIC. We should be talking to all the people in ATSIC. We should be talking to the regional commissioners and ATSIC representatives and bodies right across the country. We should be talking to land councils. We should be talking to everyone who has a stake in this.
—We have.

—I wish to table the discussions in relation to consultation. Quite frankly, it is an absolute joke. This is genuine consultation. This will ensure that we can put to the test the workability and the credibility of the amendments. We do not have to be the judge. We do not have to fight it out in here and say, `We think it's workable; you think it's unworkable' and then go to the press gallery and hope it gets the story right the next day. We will go out to the people. We will let the people decide. We will let them tell us what they think about their land fund bill because, in the end, it has to be their land fund bill.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government rejects this proposed course of action by the opposition for reasons that I will now fully spell out. In the first place, there is no substance whatsoever to the argument about lack of consultation in the lead-up to the debate on the ATSIC Amendment (Indigenous Land Corporation and Land Fund) Bill. The consultation has continued to occur throughout the long period that we have been debating this bill.

PARA.TAB: For a start, the land fund was initially established by the Native Title Act, with all the consultation and discussion that was entailed in the lead-up to the enactment of that legislation. It was an important part of the total package that this land fund was coming. The broad principles were debated and discussed in that context.

The ATSIC Amendment (Indigenous Land Corporation and Land Fund) Bill was developed on the basis of consultation with all interested parties. The Special Minister of State wrote to all ATSIC regional councils, prescribed organisations under the Native Title Act and peak indigenous industry, farming, mining, environmental and religious organisations. He did that on 11 April 1994, seeking the submission of views on the structure and operation of the proposed land fund.

A long list of specific responses to that invitation were received in writing. Those responses were, on the whole, very positive and very constructive. In addition, a number of unsolicited contributions were received from a number of Aboriginal organisations, including the Kimberley Aboriginal Association, the Ballarat and District Aboriginal Co-op, the South Australian Aboriginal Lands Trust, the Aboriginal Benefits Trust Account Advisory Committee and the Danila Dilba Medical Service operating out of Darwin.

In addition, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) met with representatives of major Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander organisations on 18 April. At that meeting, indigenous representatives agreed that the land fund should be administered by an independent specialist body with a focus on indigenous land issues. The broad principles of this legislation were thoroughly canvassed. The Prime Minister met again with these representatives on 16 June 1994. Prior to that meeting, those representatives were provided with copies of the draft bill, turning the broad principles into specific legislative form. Consensus was reached on the main features of the legislation, and a number of changes were made to address particular concerns raised at that meeting. The bill lay on the table over the whole of the winter recess, allowing a further opportunity for consideration of its provisions.

We then had the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration, to whom the bill was referred, embarking on its own consultative process. It met on 23 September, but after an exercise designed to bring to it from around Australia a number of people to give evidence about it. On that occasion, evidence was taken not only from ATSIC but also from the Swan Valley Noongah Community Group, the Kimberley Aboriginal Association, the Eastern Goldfields, the Warrungah community, the New South Wales Aboriginal Land Council and the Northern Territory government as well.

Aboriginal groups met in Melbourne in November to discuss the bill during the course of this process. A further process of consideration and input to our deliberative processes occurred on that occasion. The Greens claimed during this debate that they had consulted extensively on the terms of the bill and their amendments to it. As a result of those consultations, they were opposed to various things in the bill. They were not claiming that they had not had enough time for consultation. They were saying that, as a result of the consultations that had already occurred, they took the view that a whole variety of things in the legislation needed to be fixed. It is an argument utterly at odds with the claim now of a need for further consultation.

Of course it is the case that a degree of disagreement is apparent among intended beneficiaries of this legislation. That ain't unusual in the legislative process. People might agree with the broad principles of the legislation but they may want more money, a different process to apply or further opportunities for particular barrows to be pushed. That is life. That is the legislative reality with which we deal every day of the week when we pass legislation. If we seek to wait until such time as all possible disagreements are subject to all possible processes and all possible attempts are made at reaching all possible forms of agreement, we would never legislate about anything. That is the truth of the matter.

We also cannot say that this was a precipitate process as far as the parliament itself was concerned. Indeed, my quick calculation is that in the recorded history of the timing of debates in this place—certainly since 1950 when these records started to be kept—this is the 12th longest debate in the history of the Senate. We have spent a total of 27 hours and 10 minutes debating this legislation. We spent four hours and 40 minutes on the second reading in the week beginning 17 October. In committee we spent a total of 22 hours and 30 minutes.

This legislation has been exhaustively debated as to its terms and its content all the way through and on the basis of claims and counterclaims about what particular Aboriginal groups who have been subject to the consultative process and input into the process actually wanted. To make the claim at this stage that there has been incomplete consideration of this either by the Senate's own processes or by the consultation which led up to the Senate's own processes is to state a palpable nonsense.

The third point I want to make echoes that of Senator Kernot earlier on. The real reason the opposition wants to refer this matter to a select committee is simply to avoid somehow being caught once again in Aboriginal policy between a rock and a hard place on this particular issue. The opposition is profoundly embarrassed by the mess it has got itself into on Aboriginal policy. It is scrambling, desperately hoping that it can find some way out of the awful impasse that it confronts.

The press was full of reports, sourced to opposition spokesperson Mrs Gallus, last Friday that the opposition might in fact backflip in its position on these amendments because it did not want a double dissolution trigger. Someone was again reported as saying that the opposition would look seriously at the bill when it re-entered the Senate. I indicate right now that the government has every intention of bringing the bill back to the Senate after an appropriate lapse of time to enable the opposition to have further consideration of it. There is nothing we want more than to pass this legislation in due course. We would like to pass it as soon as possible, but if it takes a longer, more indirect process so be it.

The opposition seems to be moving in that direction. It has said that it would look seriously at the bill when it re-entered the Senate in order to avoid the possibility of being caught in the electoral politics of this.

But then we were told in another report in the Canberra Times that other senior Liberals last night were not backing Mrs Gallus on this particular matter. `This could prove to be an embarrassing gaffe for her' to float this particular option in the way she did. Indeed, it did seem to be an embarrassing gaffe because that is exactly where she has found herself with, once again, the props taken out from under her by her leaderless leadership which simply wants nothing more now than to find some way of putting off the day until, hopefully, in the new year some time maybe, somehow, the issue will go away and some solution will present itself that will be more politically palatable than the impossible position the opposition has got itself into at the moment.

So now it is proposed, in order to advance that particular sleazy political objective, to send this off to a committee for an utterly unnecessary further process. The process that I have described of consultation is answer in itself to the necessity for this process now. It is absolutely unnecessary. There is ample opportunity for any further process of deliberation that people want to engage in, a rethinking of the amendments that have been passed, a further consideration as to whether they are or are not unworkable, as the government sincerely continues to claim they are, in the period which would normally elapse between the reintroduction of this legislation in the House of Representatives and its further consideration in this place.

I make the final point, lest there be any doubt about it, that the government will treat this reference to a select committee if it is carried—as it seems certain it will be—as a failure to pass this legislation within the meaning of section 57 of the constitution. There is ample precedent for this. For example, in 1951 there was a double dissolution when a reference to a select committee was followed two days later by an application to the Governor-General for a double dissolution. That reference to a select committee in all the circumstances of the case then was treated as a failure to pass and so I am sure it would be on this occasion.

Let me make the point, in making the point in these terms, that the government wants this legislation. We are not looking for some artificial trigger for a double dissolution. As the Prime Minister said, support for this bill would be welcome for any reason. There are alternative ways of delivering funding support for land acquisition without this bill, but they are infinitely less satisfactory than this bill because what this bill establishes is a billion dollar fund, a firm legislative framework, proper legislative process, proper structures and proper criteria.

We want this legislation and will continue to do everything we can to have it passed in a workable form by this parliament. We are not looking for some artificial excuse not to pursue this particular legislation. We want it and will seek it by all available means. If we cannot get it any other way, we will be prepared to go down the path of securing its passage ultimately by a joint sitting of the two houses of parliament following the process laid out in the constitution. I give notice now that that is the course that we will follow.

TALK.START.PARA: —And you couldn't care less about the amendments.

—The amendments have been the subject of some 22 hours of debate. I have indicated that the government is not taking a dog in the manger attitude to all the amendments. There have been many more amendments passed than those which I flagged and identified as the problem amendments when I spoke in the last stages of this bill in the Senate. I spoke of seven particular problem areas—the seven deadly sins, as I described them—of this legislation as it has now been sat upon, not passed, and failed to be passed by the Senate. Every single one of those amendments went to a fundamental issue so far as the workability in practice of this legislation is concerned.

PARA.TAB: That is why we want to proceed with the bill in the form, so far as these particular subject areas are concerned, in which we originally moved it. That is why, if this course is taken, that is the course that we will follow at the appropriate time. This is a major piece of legislation. It is a groundbreaking piece of legislation. It is a piece of legislation that has been sincerely crafted after an extremely extensive process of consultation. We believe it does reflect the wishes of the overwhelming majority of Aboriginal people in this country. We argue and believe that it is right in principle and it is the right piece of legislation at this time. For all those reasons, we reject this particular reference to a committee. It is utterly indefensible, utterly unnecessary and simply a delaying tactic and will be viewed by all reasonable minded Australians as such.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison Sen C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to say at the outset that the coalition had advice to the effect that taking such a course of action could well be viewed as a failure to pass. Section 57 of the constitution says that if the Senate rejects or fails to pass legislation then those provisions can be brought into effect. I might not happen to agree with that interpretation; nonetheless, it is a piece of advice that the coalition had and it took this decision knowing that.

PARA.TAB: When a person levels an accusation at the coalition saying that we are merely taking this action to avoid any trigger for a double dissolution, that person does not know what he is talking about. We had advice to that effect. Section 57 of the constitution says `if the Senate fails to pass it'. We have heard the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) say quite clearly that the government is going to take the approach that this is a failure to pass. The minister has indicated quite clearly that the government will use the provisions of section 57 of the constitution to cause a double dissolution if need be. That has quite clearly been admitted by the minister and it is obviously something which has been on the government's agenda throughout.

In relation to the coalition's approach to the legislation, there has been from the beginning of the debate in this matter a question of lack of consultation. In fact, the question of lack of consultation was raised in the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration. On page 18 of that report, Mr Robert Bropho from the Swan Valley Noongah community of Western Australia was reported as saying that neither he nor his group whom he represented had been consulted. The report states:

SPEECH.PARA: As he said, "First of all, you have to consult with the Aboriginal people."
"Me and my mob believe that you should consult the people first. You do not go and make these decisions and then come back and tell the blacks."
Furthermore, Mr Dickie Cox from the Kimberley Aboriginal Association complained:

Our people need to know what is going on. Our people in the Kimberleys told us to come down and find out, because we have not had any people—not even those from ATSIC or the government departments—come and tell us what has been happening lately.

That was raised at the outset. During the days of debate on this bill, some 67 amendments were passed and a request was made for an extra $3 million per annum to be spent. The amendments I mentioned were of great substance, not to mention the request that the government took such exception to that it referred it immediately to the other place where it was rejected and sent back to this house. The government has also indicated that it will not be accepting the coalition's amendments.

PARA.TAB: We have a situation where we know what the government is going to do. If we pass these amendments and the legislation is sent back to the other place, the government will reject it and send it back here. There will be further delays. We might as well use this period usefully to make up for the lack of consultation that took place previously. During the debate on this legislation the people from the remote communities of Far North Queensland, the Northern Territory, northern New South Wales, north of South Australia and north-west of Western Australia could not be here. They were not glued to the radio listening to the broadcast. They did not watch it live on television. They were in areas where they did not have ready access to this sort of debate.

We are now giving the Aboriginal community across Australia a chance to have a look at the bill and at the amendments which have been put forward and then to pass some comment, to put forward an invaluable contribution towards the resolution of this matter. We have seen the press give great coverage to the division in the Aboriginal community on these very amendments. There has been no attempt on the part of the government to try to bring some form of consensus—which it so frequently talks about—to this whole affair. There has been nary a sign of it from the government.

If some advance is made and some consensus is forged over the Christmas break, this committee will be worth its weight in gold because it will be able to resolve differences which exist at the moment. I am not saying that this committee will be that successful, but it is worth a try because the consultative process that this government embarked on at the outset was a joke. During the debate, there was not sufficient time for adequate consultation to take place. The coalition received submissions from a variety of Aboriginal groups, but I do not pretend to say that those submissions covered the whole spectrum of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander thinking in this country.

The aspect of the request involving the extra $3 million is an important aspect which needs to be included with this reference so that there can be some form of comment on it. I notice that we have been criticised for not resolving the question of the request today. If we had, it would not have been able to have been included in the terms of reference. It is one of those matters on which there should be further consultation. I would like to hear what people have to say about having administration costs capped at a certain amount. I would like to hear what the wider community has to say about how we can contain administration costs, how we can stop them from eating away at the taxpayers' dollar, which is supposed to find its mark in the form of land fund acquisition, social welfare or defence spending.

The all too frequent criticism throughout this country today is that the purpose for which we allocate and appropriate moneys is always neglected at the expense of bureaucracy and high administrative costs. I would like to have some feedback on that very question. I would like to have some feedback on the question of the $3 million per annum and how it could adequately cater for the administration for which it is intended. I would like to see what people think about individual grants being made, in that there is no requirement to be a corporation. I am confident that that would be well received.

I am confident that a great many coalition amendments would be well received by the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. I have no problem with taking them to the people. I have no problem with standing by the amendments that we have proposed during this lengthy debate. Nonetheless, there would be great value in embarking on this democratic process—if we dare to call it that—going to the people and finding out what they want. These days it seems as though that is just a tactic to avoid the passing of a bill which the government does not want to pass anyway, or some tactic to avoid a double dissolution. I have already covered those points.

In summary, I say to the Senate that there is too much division and too much confusion about the land fund bill in the wider Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander community not to have a reference such as this. It is a well balanced reference. It represents the structure of this Senate. The terms of reference which Senator Campbell outlined are wide; they are encompassing. They cover all the aspects which need to be looked at. They cover the question of disagreement among some Aboriginal people about these amendments. As reported today in the Financial Review, government ministers were of the opinion that fresh negotiations and consultations with the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities should be undertaken to diffuse those divisions that I have mentioned, and that some attempt must be made to reconcile those differences. As outlined in the body of this reference, the committee would look at the amendments and test them to see whether they achieve what they set out to do. In the process of that, the bill will be tested.

TALK.START.PARA: —Haven't you tested them already?
—No, we did not test it all—
—You just put them up in here and voted for them.
—Senator Collins would be quite happy with half a day's hearing on one of the most important pieces of legislation this Senate has recently undertaken.
—Where do you get half a day?
—It was not a full day, as I recall.
—Do you mean the Senate finance one?

—Yes. We have just heard that this is a major piece of legislation—groundbreaking, in fact. If the government is to be believed, it involves some $1.5 billion. And this is all we can give to it by way of Senate committee scrutiny. Bills of a much lesser nature which have come through this chamber have got much more attention via the committee system than this bill has got. In speaking proportionately, I do not think that what the coalition is proposing here is anything at all untoward.

PARA.TAB: The other terms of reference look at whether the amendments, or the request of $3 million that I mentioned, should be modified or even deleted. Furthermore, the terms of reference seek to give the committee the power to look into other matters which might be reasonably relevant to its report. Those terms of reference are thoroughly sensible. The alternative is that we simply have a stand-off between those who support the amendment and the government, which opposes it—a stand-off which gets nobody anywhere. We have heard the minister say that he wants to see this bill through. If he is dinkum, he will participate in this reference.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: 5.07 p.m.)—I regret that the Australian Democrats cannot support the establishment of this select committee. In my view, it is not based on the motives that have been articulated here. I think it is a tactic dressed up with a newfound concern for consultation, and I do not think it will serve a useful purpose.

PARA.TAB: I want to talk a bit about the process that this motion seeks to set up. I ask members of the opposition whether, in cases where there is division in the community, they are prepared to give this opportunity to comment on every piece of legislation to which amendments have been passed by the Senate? Are they prepared to do that? For example, may I seek their foreshadowed agreement that we can do that for consumer groups and environmental groups over Hilmer competition policy? What about the implementation of APEC and GATT?

TALK.START.PARA: —This is major, groundbreaking legislation.

—Hilmer and competition policy is not? It will have no effect on community groups at all? People who have been speaking up about this obviously have no right to be heard because they are probably just from some little nondescript community group! What about the implementation of APEC and GATT?
—We'll refer it to a committee.

—I am not talking about referring a matter to a committee. I am talking about referring a matter to a committee, having 30 hours debate in the Senate, then finding that some members in the community still do not like the amendments. Will opposition senators guarantee this Senate that we can set up this process for every piece of legislation about which some members of the community say that there is division in the community? That is the proposal that the opposition is setting up here.

PARA.TAB: I have some concerns about the long-term effects of privatisation on people. May I revisit some of the pieces of legislation that we have had in here and go back and look at the amendments? Maybe that will happen when we get up to the Qantas Sale Amendment Bill or the ANL Guarantee Bill. May I call all the unionists who have a particular point of view? That is the process that the opposition is setting up here. Is the opposition going to guarantee right of access to this process to other Australians on other important pieces of legislation?

The second question I want to ask is: what constitutes exhaustive consultation? Does exhaustive consultation mean, as we heard in the native title debate, that every indigenous person in Australia has to know that the bill and the amendments exist and has to say, `I do not feel that I am disadvantaged by these'? Is that what the opposition means by exhaustive consultation? What are the qualities that add up to exhaustive consultation in its view? If one citizen, after having had this committee, says, `We do not want this bill,' what does the opposition then recommend? If one citizen says to us, `Hilmer and competition policies are a bad idea; we have listened to everything you've said,' what do we do?
