If a citizen says, `I could not get my voice heard by those people in Canberra on this,' what do we do about that? These are some of the questions that the opposition's process sets up.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can I get a list of references the Democrats have sent to committees?

—Senator Campbell can get a list of references the Democrats have made. I do not resile from Democrat references. I am speaking to this bill. We try to be judicious and selective about our use of Senate select committees. The opposition nominates 31 January as the report-back date. The third question I want to ask is: realistically, with the ABC inquiry occurring in December as well, how does the opposition honestly think the committee could conduct hearings and report sufficiently by 31 January?
—It's going to be very hard. Would you like an extension?
—You would be happy to move an extension, Senator Campbell—to the year 2010. That's what all this is about.
—That's what the opposition really wants.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Calvert)—Order! There are too many interjections from both sides.

TALK.START.PARA: —If we made it any longer, you would say we were delaying it.
—I just wonder about the choice of the date of 31 January.
—I told you about that.

—Yes. I heard it is the first sitting date, but in the intervening period there is the ABC committee—Senator Chamarette is on that—to deal with. Some people would like to have two weeks for a Christmas break. As far as I know, many members of the opposition travel in the New Year break. I am wondering why the opposition thinks it is realistically possible to do justice to the amount of consultation that it proposed—
—Do you want to make it a later date? Are you saying we shouldn't do it at all then?

—It is the opposition's date, not mine. I am asking the opposition to justify why it has chosen this date. I will tell honourable senators why I think it is this date. Glenn Milne's column in today's Australian states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the most senior figures in the party . . . are still intent on getting Downer to Christmas, when the natural holiday break should give him some clear air in which to try and recover.

PARA.TAB: None of these senior figures is absolutely convinced that Downer is salvageable—

TALK.START.PARA: —You really are part of the Labor Party, aren't you?
—Why don't you go and sit on that side?
—Can I not put a little of somebody else's comment into the debate? Nothing to do with this, huh? I quote:

SPEECH.PARA: After Christmas—if he gets there—he will be on his own.

I am simply suggesting—and Senator Newman did not hear me say this before—that I think the timing and the reason for employing this tactic are purely political. I do not believe the motives articulated about consultation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you believe it shouldn't happen?
—No, I do not think it should happen.
—Move an extension.

—I do not think it should happen; so I am not going to move an extension based on a principle I do not agree with. A fourth point I would like to raise is the one raised by Senator Ellison. He said that the very act of setting up a Senate select committee still constitutes a failure to pass. He also said he does not happen to agree with this. The point I would make is that he knows very well that this is a much less clear way—he said he did not agree with it. I bet it is the sort of thing he would challenge and it is nowhere near as neat as the alternative process.
—It is not open to challenge. You cannot challenge it.
—Senator Campbell could find a way, I'm sure. What the opposition does in the meantime is buy a little time.
—We are not buying any time. I just told you.
—But the opposition still avoids taking a vote. That is what it is about. It is avoiding taking a vote because we do not have to do anything till 31 January.
—We could do all sorts of things.

—The opposition could do all sorts of things but what it has chosen to do is set up a Senate select committee to report back on 31 January and we do nothing else in the meantime. It has chosen to avoid taking a vote. The opposition can dress it up however it wishes but that is what it has done.
—I cannot believe you are that silly.
—We are talking about tactics, are we not?
—You started out by saying we are avoiding it, and there is a strong argument that we are not.
—We will see. The opposition is buying time. I just do not think it can be dressed up in any other way. Why did you not vote for the bill, Senator Campbell?
—Because they would throw it back in a week's time.
—What does that matter to you?
—It does not progress the whole process one iota.
—Which is what you really want, is it not?
—You don't want to vote.

—The opposition does not want to have a final vote. Some of the press speculation pointed to Mrs Gallus saying that the opposition would look at it the very next time it came back to the Senate with a view to possibly reversing its position. That is what the opposition wants to buy time for, to avoid the last step in that process. If those principles, which we heard members of the opposition speak about eloquently and passionately for 27 hours, are really so important to them, if their new-found commitment to the principle of self-determination of Aboriginal people can be sustained and can endure over their commitment to the principle of avoiding an early election, why do they not just stick to those principles?
—You have a mortgage on those principles, have you?

—They are good principles. Why do those opposite not stick to them? Why do they not have the courage of their convictions and take the consequences, which is what comes with casting votes in this place?

—I would like to respond to some of the statements that have been made and also to speak in support of the setting up of this committee. I disagree very strongly with Senator Kernot's accusation that this is a delaying tactic on the part of the opposition. I concur with the opposition's statement that, if it were, there would be a longer time frame. I would also be delighted to support a longer time frame because it would allow for consultation. However, I think it is important that it not be able to be called a delaying tactic, and a date has been set that will allow the government to proceed without delay. Therefore, it is a very constructive motion.

PARA.TAB: It is also perfectly appropriate to be putting this committee proposal prior to the third reading vote. It is the only appropriate point at which to put a proposal for a committee that is going to give effect to Senator Evans's comments regarding the effects of the amendments to the bill as debated in the Senate on the workability of the bill. It would be too late if we put it at any other time. It has to be prior to the third reading.

It is appropriate that it be prior to the third reading vote because, if the third reading vote were to go ahead and the bill were to be rejected in its entirety, it would be far too late to think about setting up a committee to ascertain whether that was an appropriate move in response to the government's unwillingness to look at any of the amendments in a serious and sensible way. It is also appropriate to consider this committee proposal prior to voting on pressing the request because in that way the request can be included in the analysis of the Senate debate by the committee and by Aboriginal groups in the community as to whether its impact has rendered the government's bill unworkable—and that is the government's term, not mine—or not.

I believe that the need for consultation is clear. It was clear at the time of the native title legislation debate that insufficient consultation had gone on throughout the community in Australia regarding the impact of the Native Title Act. It was even conceded by the government that consultation should take place. However, when it was suggested by the Greens that it would be appropriate to refer the bill to the community and to have more time for committee consideration so that Aboriginal people within the community could be consulted, the government scurried around and got its legal and constitutional committee to do three days of hearings in Brisbane, Darwin and Perth as a way of preventing a delay to the bill. That is the consultation that Senator Evans referred to when he talked about `after all the consultation entailed in the Native Title Act'. He sounded so sincere and genuine about that three days of public hearings.

I remember well the words of the government: `Don't worry. If we get this legislation up, if we get the native title legislation passed, we will consult widely and properly before the land fund section is set up.' Now what do we hear? `Because we had such adequate'—and again I use government terminology, not my own—`consultation at the time of the native title debate, we do not need any more now.' At least I am glad not to hear the government say, `Don't worry. We will have plenty of consultation prior to the social justice package.' I am afraid that, on the record of this government, that would have to be laughed out of the chamber.

So we were promised consultation for later on down the track in many flourishing words by the government, but it has not eventuated. The Aboriginal community did not understand the government's legislation about this land fund, the ATSIC Indigenous Land Corporation bill, when it was presented. Even some of the people who made the so-called agreements with the government did not see the legislation in its final form or have any idea of the amount of money which—and there is consensus across the Aboriginal community in Australia about this—is not sufficient to address the purpose of the bill. Nobody was aware of the framing of this legislation and the way in which it would incorporate in such a deceitful manner the pretence of being a $1.4 billion fund when in reality it delivers only $24 million a year extra forever to Aboriginal people. Over 10 years they will never receive more than $450 million.

TALK.START.PARA: —Says who?
—That is exactly the amount delivered by this bill. If you read this bill, that is the draw-down.
—What nonsense.

—It is the only expropriation. The Aboriginal people will never see that $1.4 billion fund. If they were going to, the minister would need to rewrite the legislation. The bill has not been properly understood in the Aboriginal community. The Greens wrote a thousand letters. When we received the final form of this legislation, we wrote to every single person who had written to us at the time of the native title debate either urging us to support the bill or urging us to vote against it. We gave them the details of this land fund bill. We gave them our concerns and our amendments. We wrote to all the ATSIC regional councillors with the details of the bill and with our concerns and amendments and we have received letters and phone calls back. We have received a thick file of support for our amendments. We have received five letters that support the government's legislation.

PARA.TAB: Some of those positive letters we have received have also been sent to the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), to Senator Evans and to Senator Kernot. I know because I just sat here a minute ago taking out the duplicate copies that had been sent to the Prime Minister and other interested senators about it. We know that the Aboriginal community did not know enough about this legislation. They had no idea that the opposition and the Greens and Senator Harradine in the chamber would support sufficient amendments that they could feel more comfortable about the bill.

As we are talking about consultation—I am sorry that Senator Evans is not in the chamber—Senator Evans assured us that consultation has continued. I had a question for him. I wanted to ask Senator Evans: with whom did he discuss the government's position on the seven Senate amendments that he considered unworkable prior to your speech in the Senate on 16 November? We had a diatribe from the minister about the seven deadly sins—not about the other 50 amendments but simply about the seven which the government considered unworkable. I ask him: whom did he consult about that? I believe that the task of this committee is a perfectly legitimate task which follows Senator Evans's speech in the Senate about the six amendments and the one request which he considers render the government's legislation unworkable. That needs to be proved. It needs to be taken to consultation. It is utterly appropriate that a committee be set up to do so.

If the government is really concerned about the workability of this legislation, why is it unwilling to support a committee which will canvass those amendments and that request and seek to improve the legislation for those whom the government avows are the potential beneficiaries of this land fund?

Senator Evans says that the government wants the bill passed. That was a very touching part of his speech, I felt. But he was not quite accurate. The government wants the bill passed unamended, as presented in the House of Representatives. It has shown no commitment whatsoever to passing the bill because it has failed on two counts. It knew right from the beginning, even before the bill entered the House of Representatives, that if it had addressed the miserable quantum of the amount that it was dealing with in its legislation it could have had the two other votes from the Greens that it has not been able to get. If it had been able to address that quantum, not to 10 times the level as proposed, which the Greens put up as an amendment and which was rejected, but in any form whatsoever, it could have had the support of the Greens.

What about $3 million? It would not even raise by $3 million a year the amount that it had allocated for administration. Then it shamefully admits that it does not want to cap the administration funding. So it will not make it extra on the acquisition of management. It does not want to restrict it. It does not mind how much it eats into the paltry amount that it is setting aside. So for a start the government has not demonstrated any political will whatsoever to have this legislation passed. All it needed to do was address the concerns of the Greens, who in philosophy support the rhetoric of the Prime Minister—which I might add the bill does not.

Secondly, if it did not want to do that, it was on a very good wicket if it had simply treated the opposition with less disrespect and contempt at the point at which the bill reached the House of Representatives. It was the Greens' position at that point—and we made it public—that the amendments put forward by the opposition were compatible with the legislation as put forward by the government. I must congratulate the government at this point. If all this agonising debate between the House of Representatives and the Senate has been either a deliberate or even an unconscious attempt by the government to obtain a bipartisan stance of the two major parties on Aboriginal affairs, it has succeeded. Congratulations to the government. By its legislation it has presented something which the opposition, the Liberal and National parties, are much closer to passing than the Greens are. The government knows that.

So, if the government did not want to increase the amount by one skerrick because of its reverence for the budget deficit, which would be minimally put out by 10 times the amount the government has allocated to Aboriginal people, if it were so reverent towards the budget deficit that it could not look to the Greens for support, it has got it there in the amendments that were presented and worked on in a very conscientious and open form in the debate in the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you saying that for $3 million more a year you will pass the rest of the bill unamended? That is the first I have heard that.

—What I am saying is that the credibility of this government hangs on its $3 million. If it is not prepared to move $3 million extra on this fund, it is not prepared to move anything. It is very important that its credibility should be on the public record, and it so adequately demonstrated it. Tell that to the Aboriginal people. Tell the Aboriginal people they come from spaceships if they want more than $21 million a year. Tell the Aboriginal people of this country that $21 million a year extra, eaten into by administration funding, is going to meet the needs of the dispossessed over the last 200 years. If the government tells them that, then I will be happy to accept the same criticism that it applies to them.

PARA.TAB: The reality is that there is very close to a bipartisan stance on the passage of this bill. I do not support it, because I think it is a disgraceful bill. To use the words of Senator Evans when he was speaking to the point of order, I think that Senator Evans became a perpetrator for his government of a disgraceful and dishonest act when he brought this bill before the chamber. The government has been guilty of a dishonest tactic by presenting a bill and then refusing to accept the democratic voice of the bicameral system. It has refused to accept any amendments; it has made it patently obvious that it will not.

If we had had a really honest vote at the third reading, how would the government voted? We have already heard Senator Evans's speech when he closed the debate and we passed the request across to the House of Representatives. He indicated that the amended form in the Senate was not adequate and not appropriate. I wonder whether Senator Evans was going to vote at the third reading stage to support the passage of the bill, including the amendments of the Senate. If he were, he would be supporting the amended bill. What hypocrisy! If he is prepared to support the amended bill, he should be able to see that it is perfectly appropriate that, when his government in the other place rejects those amendments, we should go to a committee process and we should assess who is right—the Senate or the House of Representatives.

This debate has improved the bill. We know that because the opposition and the Greens have been speaking for Aboriginal people in the amendments we have made. We do not say for a moment that the government has not also been speaking for Aboriginal people. The point we are making is that the government's legislation does not speak for all concerns and to all people. Referring the legislation to a committee would be an opportunity to address the government's neglect of those people who feel they have not had a voice in the process. They all, even those who support the government's position, deserve a hearing and a committee would provide that to them. For that reason, the Greens support the motion moved by the opposition to set up a committee to look at this very important matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —There have been statements made by Senator Evans—they were followed up by, I think, Senator Kernot—raising a question about the motives of the opposition in moving this amendment. These were based on a perceived fear that there was an attempt by the opposition to defer this matter so that it could not become a trigger for a double dissolution. Anybody with an ounce of commonsense or anybody with any knowledge of the constitution would have known that failing to pass the bill could set the time clock running. This has been commented upon by Senator Ellison. Of course members of the opposition would have known that. They did not come down in the last constitutional shower.

PARA.TAB: But, in any event, so what? The time clock would start ticking now. There is already another piece of legislation whose time clock is ticking away nicely—the migration bill that was defeated by the Senate with a combined vote of the opposition, the Democrats, the Greens and me. Senators will remember that that bill was defeated on 9 November. If the government wants a double dissolution trigger so badly, it can bring that back to us at the end of February. We will then no doubt reject it, because that bill is a violation of three very important principles.

First of all, that bill is a violation of the principle of certainty before the law. I might just remind the Senate of what the bill did. It was an attempt by the government to overturn a decision by the court that certain Cambodian refugees were illegally detained by the government. The judge said that they were illegally detained. The bill says that they were not illegally detained by the government. That offends against the principle of certainty before the law. It offends against the principle that the government should not be above the law and it offends against the principle of civil liberties—whether these people be yellow or black or white.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's also got nothing to do with this bill.

—It certainly has something to do with the argument advanced by Senator Evans as to the motives of the opposition. That all falls to the ground. So let us just look at the genuine concern that was expressed by Senator Kernot that maybe this was introducing a new process. If there were amendments made by the Senate and by the parliament to particular laws before those laws are finally enacted—in other words, before the third reading takes place—perhaps this sets a precedent for doing it in those particular cases.

PARA.TAB: This measure is about providing a modicum of justice and a modicum of acknowledgment that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people have been dispossessed. Dispossessed! This is a unique piece of legislation because it gives the parliament a unique opportunity to do something about it. We want to get it right. That is why we spent so much time in this chamber. As Senator Chamarette has said, the government did not undertake the depth of consultation that it should have. How can it simply reject the request? There has been no real explanation for that. As I understand it, there has been no consultation in depth by the government before it decided to reject that. As I said, it was done in a cavalier approach in the House of Representatives.

I am conscious of the fact that a lot of these amendments were carried by a bare majority of the chamber. But that is why it is even more important to vote for the proposition now put by Senator Campbell with reference to the views of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples. What is the government afraid of with this particular reference? The reference seeks to find out whether, taken as a whole, the amendments and request achieve the aim of making the bill a more effective instrument to assist those Aboriginal persons and Torres Strait Islanders who will be unable to assert native title rights and interests to acquire land and manage it effectively. I would certainly like to hear what these groups and individuals are saying about that.

As I indicated, this is a unique opportunity for the parliament to do something about dispossession. We have to get it right. It is no good for the government to say, `No, these seven major amendments are totally unacceptable.' How does it know they are totally unacceptable in general to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people? Let the consultations take place and give the people an opportunity to say whether or not the amended bill, taken as a whole, is acceptable.

I could go on at considerable length. I feel quite strongly about this matter. I fear that, had our requests been pressed, the government would have just ditched the legislation. That is what I understand the government was prepared to do—ditch it, even with the amendments that it had agreed to. That is not acceptable behaviour by a responsible government in a matter of such importance as this which deals with the question of the dispossession of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders. I think this is a further opportunity and I congratulate Senator Campbell for raising it and for moving for referral to a committee. I do not believe it was politically motivated. As I said, that was a straw man that was first put up by Senator Evans and it has been shot to pieces.

The clock is ticking on the migration legislation. If the government brings it back at the end of February and it is rejected by the Senate, it can hold an election. It could hold that election on 8 April if it wanted to. The government knows that as well as I do, as well as anyone does who knows a bit about the constitution. It could even hold an election on 1 April. I think that is the earliest date on which it could hold it. Looking at this objectively, I feel that it is a positive proposal and I am going to support it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to address the issue of the need for consultation. I have listened to this debate; I have been here for the whole of it. I have listened to the coalition, the Greens and Senator Harradine talk about the need for consultation. I am afraid I am very cynical at this point, particularly as I have listened to the debate. I say to those honourable senators: you can consult all you like and with whomever you decide to consult. At the end of that consultation you will still have to choose between the groups whom you consult, when you discover that the positions that they already hold have simply been consolidated and reinforced by the consultation. There will be very little difference. You will have the same information as you already have. You will just give the Aboriginal people the opportunity to be at one another's throats and to be more divided than they are now. You are not going to bring any further consolidation of the Aboriginal community through this. You will simply bring further division. That is what is going to happen.

—I say to Senator Panizza that I have been consulting with Aboriginal groups for over 30 years—on the fringes of rural towns, in rural areas and in tribal areas. I have been responsible for consultation with Aboriginal groups for that long. I know that there is no such thing as a monolithic entity known as Aboriginal people. It does not exist. Aboriginal people are just as divided as is the white community. They have political groupings; they have tribal groupings; they have groupings on every basis that one can imagine.

PARA.TAB: In the end, having consulted with them, do you really believe that that consultation will provide further clarity? I believe that you do not really know much about Aboriginal and Islander politics if you think that consultation will deliver some kind of consensus. When you say that you want to tell the Aboriginal people, I wonder whether you understand that they do not in fact exist as an entity. The statement was made by Senator Chamarette that the government does not speak for all Aboriginal people. I have never heard the government suggest that it ever did. But let me say to honourable senators that there is not even a group of Aboriginal people anywhere which speaks for all Aboriginal people. It is a stupid proposition.

I wonder whether the Greens are going to tell those Aborigines whom they have consulted, who have told them what they want to hear, that the end result of all of this process that we have gone through is that the land fund money is going to be delivered through ATSIC—which, in the end, is the very group that most of those people whom you have consulted hate with a great hatred. So you are really going to deliver to those people the very thing that they do not want. I wonder whether in the consultations you will tell them that that is actually what you are delivering to them. On 31 January 1995, when the report is presented to this parliament, the division in the Aboriginal community and the issues will still not be resolved. The groups will be in the same position and you will still have to vote.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought that was a very effective contribution to this debate because it has well and truly nailed to the mast the nonsense that I have just listened to. I know that there is not a lot of joy in opposition ranks these days. Everyone knows that. It is in the papers almost every day. I know that the opposition is hopelessly divided on a whole lot of human issues, such as the racial vilification legislation, the privacy legislation and this issue. The world knows, because the shadow minister for Aboriginal affairs, Mrs Gallus, said it, that the opposition was reconsidering its position on all of this and was looking favourably at the prospect, when this went to the House of Representatives, of reconsidering its position on the government amendments. We know that once again—and it is not the first time—the shadow minister for Aboriginal affairs got dumped by her own party room. That is what all of this is about. This has got a lot to do with leadership and with helping Alexander Downer limp through the Christmas break until 1995. I would love to give whatever help I can to help Alexander limp into 1995. That is what a lot of this has to do with.

PARA.TAB: The fact is that the shadow minister for Aboriginal affairs, who has indicated publicly on a number of occasions sentiments with which many people on the government side would agree, has been rolled again in her party room. This is simply a delaying tactic. There is not a lot of joy in the opposition these days. Gulling the Western Australian Greens is one of the few elements of pleasure left to members of the opposition these days. What a nonsense it is in terms of that pious hope from Senator Chamarette justifying the passage of this opposition proposal which once again the Greens are supporting. I might add that they not only support it but have expressed great concern about the terrible things the government was saying about the opposition, which Senator Chamarette wanted to defend the opposition from. I do not know what the gestation period is of the union between the Greens and the federal opposition but it would certainly be interesting to see the result of it.

What a piece of laughable nonsense it is to listen to concerns about lack of consultation with the Aboriginal community—once again, the pan-Aboriginal community of Australia, which does not exist—and about all of this being resolved by the end of January 1995. It is now the end of November 1994. What a piece of nonsense!

I do not get as much time these days as I used to once to spend with people whom I have spent the last 30 years of my life growing up with—that is, the thousands of Aboriginal people who live in essentially the Top End of the Northern Territory; I do not even see much of Central Australia these days—but I have never seen Senator Chamarette out there, and they have never seen her either. I know who her advisers are.

This piece of nonsense that she has put up—the Hansard record will indicate it—that the reason we have to have this select committee is that `the government's bill does not speak to all concerns and for all people' might be the go in Greenland or wherever it is, as I have said before, that Senator Chamarette comes from. But it is a nonsense to suggest—to even hold out the prospect—that the establishment of a select committee till the end of this century will produce a piece of legislation that will speak `to all concerns and to all people'.

I know that that is the sort of world Senator Chamarette lives in, and I admire her for living in it, but it is not the real world. I will just take a couple of issues, one of which is in this amendment, on which people I know feel very strongly. Tracker Tilmouth, whom I have known for most of his life and one of the effective—

TALK.START.PARA: —He agrees with us.

—What Tracker Tilmouth said publicly about this legislation as amended was that it started off as being a reasonable dog. Tracker said, in his own particular manner, that the Aboriginal community might have liked to have seen it with a new collar on—a little bit more money perhaps, which of course everybody always wants, or a nice new lead—but it was in reasonable shape, and now that dog is so sick as a result of the opposition's amendments supported by the Greens that the easiest thing, and the most merciful thing, to do would be to take this legislation out and shoot it.

PARA.TAB: Does Senator Chamarette think that at the end of this select committee process a result will be produced that will `speak for all concerns and for all people' and will change that view represented by Tracker Tilmouth? No, it will not. The Aboriginal people in the Northern Territory know perfectly well what some of these amendments are designed to do: to disadvantage them. That will be the result of it.At this stage, I do not think we should mince words any longer in here—and I have certainly heard a lot of pious claptrap uttered during this debate. The federal opposition has certainly raised insincerity to new heights.

Let us have a look at one of the seven deadly sins that Senator Gareth Evans rightly referred to: the question of dispossession. Does anyone have any doubt as to whom that is designed to discriminate against? I do not, and neither do the people in the Northern Territory whom it will discriminate against. This particular proposal talks about people who will be unable to assert native title rights. The only native title rights that have been determined to this point in time are of those people who own the island of Mer in the Torres Strait. That is the only case that has been determined.

But what do we know about native rights, or what can we assume from the judgment of the High Court may well be the case, particularly in northern Australia? Native title rights may well be found by a court not to actually involve proprietorial rights over land. It may well be—and it is for a court to determine at some future time—that the coexistence argument which is mounted, that the caveats that exist in Western Australian and Northern Territory legislation on leases that provide for the use but not the ownership of land, may well be found to be valid.

Is Senator Chamarette suggesting—not that the opposition would care, so I address the concern to her—that an Aboriginal person or group who actually successfully manage to assert their native title rights should then be disbarred or discriminated against in terms of a bias written into the act; that because they have native title rights they should not then have the opportunity to actually own some land? I would not like to think that, but that is what a great many Aboriginal people in the Northern Territory whom I know think—and they are the only Aboriginal people that I have ever presumed to advance an opinion on behalf of.That is certainly the view they will have of this.

All I am suggesting is that it is not as simple as Senator Chamarette might think. I do not think the people who may get native title rights significantly less than proprietorial rights, and that may well be the case—in fact is likely to be the case in some circumstances—should be disbarred.

What then is the task posed for the organisation that is going to administer this—the impossible task of having on each and every occasion to make a value judgment about dispossession before land can be acquired? What an impossible task Senator Chamarette and the opposition have set for that organisation. People would spend the rest of their lives in court with arguments every inch of the way. Even in the Northern Territory—in the Top End of Australia where certainly among traditional Aboriginal people the question of land ownership generally is more clearly defined than anywhere else in Australia—debates, discussions, brawls, arguments and fights have been going on for years inside the land councils about traditional ownership, about who is on the list and who is not on the list. In the Northern Territory—a part of Australia where many Aboriginal people in fact maintain a significantly traditional lifestyle and where living Aboriginal people have encyclopaedic knowledge about relationships with other Aboriginal people and the ownership of land—we still have those problems.

I know what will happen in practice. It might be an esoteric academic exercise for some of the people who have participated in this debate, but over the years I have sat through land council hearings and heard separate groups of Aboriginal people represented by separate fleets of lawyers argue about who is telling the truth about dispossession or not. To set up such a proposal for the whole of Australia would a very difficult proposition indeed.

How could the government ever support that? There are thousands of Aboriginal people of the Northern Territory, like Tracker Tilmouth, who know that this is designed by the lobbyists who have Senator Chamarette's ear—and I know who they are—to discriminate in favour of them and against Aboriginal people elsewhere. Does Senator Chamarette think that they will ever agree at the end of this process at the end of January to this amendment, if we accept it—and it is one that Senator Chamarette and the opposition have asserted is central to their concerns, and one the government has asserted is central to its concerns—and say, `That's fine now; we'll just abandon the positions that we held on this up to this point in time. Now it's the end of January so we'll agree to this opposition amendment.' They never will.

Where would we end up at the end of 31 January next year? We would be in no better position than we are now. Does Senator Chamarette suggest, in terms of the question that was posed about what constitutes consultation, that she is not going to be able to find one, 100 or, let me say, 1,000 people at the end of this process who can claim legitimately not to have been consulted? I will go out and find them for her next week, next year or into the next century.

I know thousands of Aboriginal people who, to this point in time and to this day, still know as little about the detail of the ATSIC legislation as they knew the day it was passed in parliament. Why should they be any better informed? They know as little about it as the good citizens of Parap, Nightcliff, Fannie Bay, Larrakeyah or of any of the non-Aboriginal communities in Darwin know about most of the legislation that affects their lives on a daily basis—that is, nothing. What a piece of utter nonsense! If we engage in the kind of consultative process that Senator Chamarette, in her dream world, is talking about engaging in, we will take this process into the next century and will still not cover the ground.

As I say, I personally know one of the parts of Australia where we will find Aboriginal people thicker on the ground than we will, unfortunately, in many other parts of Australia where Senator Chamarette's foot has not yet trodden. She has never been there, ever. That is not a criticism. She does not have the time to go either. She will never be able to carry out the kind of consultation she is talking about, so she should stop putting it up as a

SPEECH.PARA: pious excuse to delay this legislation any longer. It is a false argument. It is an argument that should fall to the ground. The only joy in life that opposition members get these days is gulling the Western Australian Greens. They must have a horse laugh at the end of every day here in parliament.

PARA.TAB: This measure is designed to take care of the internal party room problems of the federal coalition. It is designed not to force this legislation to a vote. It is all about not needing to have a vote on this legislation until this lot can stagger into next year in the sort of shape that it is in at the moment.

In conclusion—the Hansard will make interesting reading afterwards—Senator Chamarette asserted wrongly, as she admitted herself in debate this afternoon, an astonishing proposition which I had not heard before. If the government should simply agree to cover the administrative costs by providing an additional $3 million—on top of the $26 million of additional money that Senator Chamarette has worked out that this would provide—the Greens would have supported the legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, she did not.

—I know that she corrected it. But, at the end of the day, she had to admit that that was a piece of nonsense. That proposition was never put to the government. The fact is that this motion will pass. There is no need to add to the 30 hours of debate that is concluding—
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I claim to have been misrepresented. For those who were listening, I can assure the chamber—
—Wait your turn like everyone else.
—All right. I give notice that I will do that. I briefly want to correct the record.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Calvert)—When Senator Collins has finished, you can make your point.

TALK.START.PARA: —She can do what the rest of us have to do. I will simply conclude by saying that this will come to a vote. It is publicly obvious that the opposition's support for the further delaying tactics to do with this legislation has everything to do with the internal problems it has and its desire to never see this legislation pass this parliament. We know that.

PARA.TAB: I do not attribute those motives to the Greens, because I know that they come at it from a different direction which does not exist in this world. I regret to say to Senator Chamarette once again that, knowing the Aboriginal people she has not talked to or been anywhere near in her life—and one could call them legion—they understand the full import of what she is saying. They understand that the things she is supporting that will twist this bill in favour of the people who have her ear are just bad luck for the people who do not have her ear.

If Senator Chamarette is seriously suggesting that at the end of the day she will have less division—which is one of the pious platitudes which has been put forward by her side and the opposition in this chamber this afternoon—forget it. The amendments are so fundamentally against the interests of many Aboriginal people in this country that she will never get their support for them. Her pious hope that this process will produce a bill that speaks for all concerned and all people is a piece of nonsense.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will speak briefly to standing order 191, which is that I have been either misquoted or misunderstood. I would prefer to give the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Collins) the benefit of the doubt and say that he has been very lax in listening to my words. At no point have I said anything about what the effect of the $3 million request would be on the Greens except to say that we wanted to see the government's response to it to test the government's credibility.

PARA.TAB: The minister knows that on all the points of the public record where we refer to the amount I have said that it is woefully inadequate. While he was heckling and making jibes at me, there was no intent on my part to answer him. The only answer I gave was simply to point out that the reason for the request was a very clear one: I supported the request for $3 million more to quarantine the administrative costs away from the acquisition and management aspects of the fund in order to test the government's credibility and to put on the public record its political will as to how much it cared about the Aboriginal people who were supposed to be the avowed beneficiaries of the funds. I wish to correct that misstatement by Senator Collins of something I have said.

No doubt a lot more rhetoric has been thrown at me which I totally deny, but I will not waste the Senate's time going over it. I want the public record to be quite clear that the Greens have never stated that they would consider a measly $3 million more to sweep away their concerns that this should really be $1 billion, which is 10 times what the government has been prepared to allocate to it. That is our position and the amendment we put. I want to know how far the government is prepared to go in addressing the concerns of all Aboriginal people around the country. Senator Collins used the term `new collar for the dog' that—
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Calvert)—Order! Senator Chamarette, I think you have made your point.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have I made my point?
—Yes.
—Thank you.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Campbell's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Motion, as amended, agreed to.
Consideration resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —The committee is considering the Student Assistance (Budget Matters) Amendment Bill 1994 and the request for an amendment moved by Senator Woodley. The question before the chair is that the request for the amendment moved by Senator Woodley be agreed to. (Quorum formed)

—In my speech earlier today I indicated that I believed there were farm families who would not benefit from the health care card amendment but who would benefit from a 100 per cent discount of farm assets under the Austudy assets test. This is the information that Senator Boswell and others were seeking and I think this will enable him to vote now for our amendment. I am now in a position to give the committee some more detailed information as to just who these families are. Contrary to concerns raised before, they are by no means high income earning families.

PARA.TAB: As I understand it, the income test on the health care card is such that a family with one child can earn up to about $19,400 a year and still qualify for the card, while a family with two children can earn up to about $21,200. These limits are sudden death thresholds, meaning that if a family earns $1 over these amounts, it receives no health care benefit at all.

The income test on Austudy, however, is more generous. The threshold for full rate Austudy is $21,300, but the claimant has a gradual withdrawal rate of $1 for every $4 of income over this threshold. Further, the Austudy income test is based on what is known as adjusted family income, which allows additional concessions for any other dependent children. This means that any farming family who, if not for the assets test, would qualify for part rate Austudy payment, will benefit from my 100 per cent discount amendment but will gain nothing from the health care card amendment.

Let me give an example. A family with two children on an income of, say, $25,000 would not qualify for a health care card and, as such, would have its assets included in the Austudy assets test. Therefore, that family would probably be excluded from Austudy. If our 100 per cent discount amendment were accepted, however, this same family would qualify for a part payment of Austudy of around $100 per fortnight if the child was living at home or $190 per fortnight if the child was living away from home. So all of those farm families with incomes between $21,000 and $45,000 would benefit from my amendment by receiving a part rate payment of Austudy. These families would gain nothing, however, from the health care card amendment.

Let us not forget that the only reason these people are not currently getting Austudy is their farm assets. Most city folk with incomes between $21,000 and $45,000 are already receiving part Austudy payments. In other words, there is a differential again between city and farm families. To provide true equity for our farm families, both the health care card amendment and my amendment providing a 100 per cent discount for farm assets under the Austudy assets test should be supported.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services)

DEBATE.TITLE: HIGHER EDUCATION FUNDING LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1994

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not wish to take up a great deal of the committee's time dealing with this matter. The government clearly opposes the opposition's amendment, which has the support of the Democrats and I think probably the independents as I am getting the nod that we are going down. We are getting that sinking feeling. We strongly oppose the amendment that has been moved by the opposition as outlined in detail by Senator Hill. I do not intend to speak for long because in my concluding remarks at the second reading debate stage I dealt with some of the claims relating to this matter. The comments I made earlier cover the debate that has ensued in the committee stage, so I will not speak any further on the matter.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the clause stand as printed.
Question so resolved in the negative.
The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Colston)—The question now is that the bill, as amended, be agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier, during the second reading stage, when I raised the question of the definition of the cessation of full-time education, neither the parliamentary secretary's contribution nor any other contribution was able to shed any light on that definition. I would like the parliamentary secretary to tell me whether there is a definition in this particular proposition which is consistent with other definitions, such as those for Austudy or those for Australian taxation. It is important, because the student is left with the onus of determining when full-time education has ceased. The opinion of the student may or may not be consistent with the opinion of the Taxation Office and it may or may not be consistent with the opinion of the institution at which the study is being done.
—I apologise to Senator Bell but, because of the noise in the chamber, I ask him to commence his question again.

—I simply want a definition of the cessation of full-time education. Is it consistent with the definitions in Austudy, Australian tax, and the other definitions that students have to subject themselves to? I would have thought that, if a definition had been handy, my question would have been easily answered. It seems to me that fundamental to the whole notion which underpins this piece of legislation is the definition of the cessation of full-time education. Is there such a definition in this legislation? If not, which definition will be accepted? Is it a definition which is consistent with the definition of the Australian Taxation Office or with the definition which is provided under Austudy?

PARA.TAB: This matter is very important, because the onus is upon the students concerned to fill out a form to say when they ceased full-time education. Some of these people may be seeking to enter full-time employment without having made a permanent decision to cease full-time education. We know that, in general, university students finish their study, for all practical purposes, in November. Many of them attempt to gain work in December, but they may change their minds and resume full-time education the next year. Nobody can be absolutely certain that they have passed their exams and fulfilled all the requirements.

There are other definitions. I want to know whether there is a definition here which is consistent with the other definitions, because it is the other definitions which impinge upon the students' activities anyway. The definitions of the tax office have a great deal to do with what is proposed here. Where is the government on this question of a definition?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no definition in the legislation because we do not believe one is needed. If a definition were to be drawn on, it would be the tax office definition.

—That presents the students with some degree of difficulty. The student is not necessarily proving what is the tax office's definition. The student has probably been in receipt of Austudy and has been operating under the auspices of those offices. It is quite silly of the government to expect a student to be able to fill out a form and answer the question, `When did you cease full-time education?'. The student is entitled to say, `What do you mean?' If no advice is forthcoming from the parliamentary secretary at this moment, that leaves some degree of uncertainty about the whole bill. I really think the advisers should exercise the mind of the parliamentary secretary to deliver us a definition here.
—It's a fundamental omission.

—I agree with Senator Watson, who says that it is a fundamental omission. How can a person be expected to comply with this new law of the nation if the parliamentary secretary himself is uncertain as to the fundamental basis upon which it rests?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —We would argue that it is pretty self-evident when a person ceases full-time study: when they are no longer enrolled in full-time study. It is easily checked, it is easy to verify. People are either enrolled in full-time study or they are not.

—That is a very good start. If you are not enrolled, you are not enrolled in full-time education. The student then has to consider the following: `I may not be enrolled in December and I may not enrol in January, expecting that my results will be all good. But I may re-enrol in February.' If the student is fortunate enough to gain employment in December and January, during what I have previously described as the carnival period in Australia—which is very good for employment of recent graduates in terms of catering and entertainment—will the tax office take the HECS pro rata payments out of those earnings at that time on the assumption that the student is going to pass? How many assumptions can it make and get right? In the past, how many people have assumed that they will pass and been wrong?

PARA.TAB: The government has again illustrated how far away from reality it has progressed. The answer from the parliamentary secretary about enrolment is a part answer, it is a good start. But, again, it ignores what really happens out there. I suggest a little bit more work be done there and that perhaps a refinement of that definition would be helpful to all concerned.
