DEBATE.TITLE: STUDENT ASSISTANCE (YOUTH TRAINING ALLOWANCE) AMENDMENT BILL 1994STUDENT ASSISTANCE (YOUTH TRAINING ALLOWANCE--TRANSITIONAL PROVISIONS AND CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 7 November, on motion by Senator Crowley:
That these bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Troeth Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have before us today the Student Assistance (Youth Training Allowance) Amendment Bill 1994. I would like to briefly summarise some key aspects of this bill and comment on them as I go through. Essentially, the main bill is designed to establish the income support component of the youth training initiative. This provides for the payment of the youth training allowance to young unemployed people under the age of 18 and replaces the jobsearch allowance.

PARA.TAB: I note that this 267-page bill was introduced into the House with very little time for analysis. I do not think it reflects very well on this government that such an important bill should have been thrown into the parliament with limited time for consideration in the other place. However, it is somewhat of a compliment that the government should have picked up the coalition's concept of a training wage on which we campaigned very strongly at the last election.

In the coalition, we believe it is very important that young people get on-the-job training and opportunities for experience and skill acquisition. It is also appropriate that people without experience or training should not be paid at the same level as someone with many more years in a career. However, where we are critical of this government is that it provides for training programs but has done little or nothing to ensure that there are jobs at the end of all these training programs.

I reiterate the questions asked by Dr David Kemp in the other place regarding training. What kind of training will these young people be receiving? Will this training be appropriate to their needs? Will there be a connection between these training programs and the real life job market? Furthermore, what is the use of young people receiving training without the labour market reforms that are necessary to give business the incentive to employ more people? Young people in Australia today are cynical enough about the political process without needing to receive more platitudes.

Youth organisations were extremely critical of the government's white paper. An article in the Canberra Times on 16 May 1994 reported that a summit of youth organisations in Canberra which met to discuss the white paper concluded that the `policy statement is not going to deliver the jobs that the government had promised'. They said the training program was meaningless without job creation. I would have to agree with that. The Australian Youth Policy and Action Coalition was critical of a lack of job creation initiatives and the government's concept of case management, among other things.

These training programs will act as a smokescreen for the real numbers of unemployed youth in the community. The government will claim that it has reduced the unemployment figures when all it has done is fiddle the figures to make it appear that there are fewer people on dole queues. If the government does not want to hear these criticisms from the coalition, let me reiterate my earlier comments by quoting the National Union of Students welfare officer, Edwina Hanlon, who said that graduate unemployment was a growing concern because the biggest group of unemployed people was the 22- to 24-year-olds. Ms Hanlon said that these people were being trained and educated but were not getting jobs at the end of the line. So that does not hold out much hope for 16- and 17-year-olds who go into training programs.
An article in the Australian of 5 May 1994, headed `Teenagers' cynicism reaches danger level', stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Youth workers fear widespread youth unemployment has bred a generation of cynics and caused social and economic problems that will haunt the nation for decades . . . According to the chairman of the Australian Youth Policy and Action Coalition, Mr Paul Turley, young Australians showed `an understandable but dangerous level of cynicism.'

Academics are also numbered among critics of the government's dismissive attitude towards our young people. The same article reports that Mr John Freeland, senior lecturer in social work and social policy at the University of Sydney, said that the country would be paying for the effects of youth unemployment for 40 years. Mr Freeland said:
If you leave up to 20% of your young people feeling cynical and hopeless and resentful of society you could have long term social problems and you could have long term economic costs.

He warned that the young unemployed were at risk of failing to make a successful transition to secure employment and of spending their lives on the margins of society. For some, this would mean homelessness, petty crime, prostitution and substance abuse. For Mr Turley, the solution was not simply to provide more training, as this bill sets out to do, but to create more work, which the government has not done.

PARA.TAB: Young people have been demoralised by the high unemployment rate in this country. The lack of opportunities and the lack of vision have had devastating effects on many of our youth and contributed to a real sense of hopelessness for many. The UNICEF report of 1994 called The Progress of Nations stated that Australia has the sixth highest youth suicide rate of the industrialised countries. Analysis published in the Australian Medical Journal and reported in the Age newspaper on 7 February 1994 has revealed that young Victorian men living in areas of high unemployment are more likely to commit suicide than those in regions where the jobless rate is lower.

Again, Professor John Tiller of the department of psychiatry of the University of Melbourne was reported in the Australian of 7 February this year as saying that regional data associating the suicide rate to geographical distribution was available only for recent times, so it was not possible to track the trends over a decade. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: We're saying that certain high areas of unemployment are associated with high suicide rates.

Other research has also found that alarming numbers of Victorian teenagers are deliberately hurting themselves in ways that could cause serious injury or death. Obviously other factors are associated with suicide and suicidal tendencies. I am cognisant of the importance of not making black and white statements when, in many instances, there are a whole host of other reasons that lead young people to be suicidal. However, giving young people job opportunities and futures to look forward to, rather than years on dole queues, would take away from some of the other stresses in young people's lives.

PARA.TAB: A number of proposals in this bill raise questions about the overlap between functions of different departments. I am concerned that they may cause some confusion to people on the scheme. There are already a multiplicity of youth support schemes that are becoming increasingly complex for people to understand. Those most in need are more likely to give up on the bureaucratic nightmare that they have to deal with. I instance some of these overlaps and complex areas.

The Department of Employment, Education and Training will be responsible for the policy and administration relating to the youth training initiative, including the youth training allowance. It will also conduct the activity tests for youth training allowance recipients. On the other hand, youth training allowance clients will deal directly with the Department of Social Security on payment matters and the Department of Social Security will have the power to collect relevant information.

The administration and policy of the youth training allowance will reside with DEET, and DSS will continue to undertake proof of identity, residence and other eligibility checks related to the youth training allowance and the youth homeless allowance. DEET will continue to undertake all assessments relating to the Austudy and the student homeless rate of payment. It will also provide guidelines and delegational powers to the Department of Social Security.

I will admit that there has been some streamlining of some criteria, and we would support this. For example, the eligibility criteria for qualifying for the homeless rate of the youth training allowance will be the same as that of Austudy, and greater commonality will be established between the parental and personal income and assets test for the youth training allowance and Austudy.

However, in relation to the other changes, it has been suggested that there is no need for this bill and that the Social Security Act should have been amended. It has been stated by some critics that this process is particularly wasteful in that it creates nothing new but merely shuffles over a scheme to another department at some cost and some procedure. I refer to comments by the Welfare Rights Centre:

SPEECH.PARA: The enactment of the current Bill would lead to even more complexity and accessibility problems. This is particularly the case given the client group who because of their age—
that is, 16 to 17 years of age—

already have great problems of access. Their advisers are more likely to have the social security act and guidelines. Now they will have to refer to another piece of legislation, which in most respects repeats the Social Security Act. However, they will never be sure where the differences exist—and, with the passage of time (and legislation), inconsistencies will invariably emerge.
I refer also to the discussion paper issued by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Community Affairs inquiry into aspects of youth homelessness, which said:

DEET's infrastructure would appear to require substantial improvement in order to be able to offer a comparable service to that undertaken by the Department of Social Security in this area. This leads to the question as to why a duplicate income security administrative structure should exist in the Department of Employment, Education and Training when this already operated in the Department of Social Security.

Given the experience with Austudy, this criticism may have some validity. This bill puts great pressure on ensuring that relations are at a very efficient level between the Department of Social Security and the Department of Employment, Education and Training. I endorse Dr Kemp's comments that we would not want to see loopholes and gaps developing through which people can fall that have occurred in the past when more than one department was involved in the administration of such schemes.

PARA.TAB: The government's amendment to this bill proposed, as the result of an inquiry by the House of Representatives standing committee that I have just mentioned, to amalgamate the Student Assistance Review Tribunal with the Social Security Appeals Tribunal. The committee was strongly critical of the Student Assistance Review Tribunal, which is for students who believe the Department of Employment, Education and Training has made a wrong decision in relation to their Austudy payments, as compared to the Social Security Appeals Tribunal, which is for people who believe that the DSS has made a wrong decision in relation to their social security payments.

The Student Assistance Review Tribunal is not widely known by clients. It is relatively inaccessible from rural areas and it takes much longer to hear appeals, but I suggest to the government that serious consideration should be given to the appropriateness of this appeals mechanism in terms of its resources, its responsiveness and its administrative expertise. The House of Representatives committee added:

SPEECH.PARA: We are aware that the appeals process should be integrally related to the legislative basis of payment. The confusion about the legislation and policy residing in one department, Employment, Education and Training, yet administered and operated through delegation to another (the Department of Social Security), adds another dimension to the unsatisfactory nature of these new arrangements.

There have been complaints by the National Union of Students about this proposal. I understand that the National Union of Students is not adamantly opposed to the legislation or the amalgamation but has a number of concerns about the detail of the changes. Those concerns are that the proposed change does not provide for student representation on the new tribunal, which it believes is vital, that the new tribunal will have Department of Employment, Education and Training officers as full members of the tribunal, which it believes could lead to a conflict of interest, and that overpayment decisions under the Student Assistance Act will be reviewable by the Social Security Appeals Tribunal on the same basis as Social Security Act overpayment decisions, with the exception that the provision for waiving debts which are not cost-effective to recover will only apply to debts under $50 and not to debts under $200, which is the case for debts under the Social Security Act.

PARA.TAB: I would now like to consider the initiatives for case management contained in this legislation, which is part of the youth training initiative. Although it is not specifically covered under this bill, I would like to note a number of concerns with the scheme. It is appalling that 82,000 people are still waiting to be case managed, which is an enormous number of people in fairly dire straits who are not receiving the attention in the form of case managers that they were promised. It is completely unfair that the expectations of the unemployed would be raised in this way beyond what is being delivered. These figures indicate that there is absolutely no guarantee that everyone unemployed for 13 weeks will get a case manager. The whole case management scheme is likely to prove to be very expensive and very inefficient. There is likely to be confusion for youth training allowance recipients between having a case management activity agreement and a youth training activity agreement.

There are other concerns regarding case management which I will not go into detail about here but suffice it to mention that these concerns are about the amount of time each case manager actually gets to spend with his or her client and whether or not each client will have the undivided attention of his or her case manager as well as the way clients are notified as to whether there is an interview opportunity or not.

This bill was referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training for inquiry. It was decided by the majority of the committee not to undertake hearings into the bill. Senator Tierney and myself recorded a dissenting report on behalf of the coalition as we believed it would have been beneficial for the bill to have been referred to the committee for further evidence to have been taken. The Australian Youth Policy and Action Coalition supported the coalition's view on this matter and said it would have welcomed an opportunity to comment on the youth training allowance. It further commented:

SPEECH.PARA: Since the unveiling of Working Nation in May 1994, there has been no parliamentary hearing or other similar forum to solicit public comment on the numerous initiatives contained in the White Paper.

It is disappointing that the government has not felt it necessary to investigate public concerns with this bill. As I said at the start of my speech, not only the substantive part of this bill but also the government amendments were very late in coming to the chamber. But the coalition has no wish to delay the passing of this bill in view of the benefits offered to young people seriously seeking employment. So we will not be opposing this bill. However, I believe that the comments I have made serve to highlight the problems associated with it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The white paper changes—what is known as the Working Nation statement—have been hailed as a miracle cure for unemployment and education training needs in this country. That is all very well and good but there are a few unanswered questions and more outstanding problems with the package of bills before the Senate. We will be dealing with them in the form of the youth training allowance and employment services legislation. I mentioned in a press release recently that there has been little discussion and analysis of these changes. Senator Troeth I must agree with very strongly—I congratulate her for the way she expressed it—in that the government seems to think that it is good enough to just state that there was an extensive period of consultation leading up to the white paper. It is worse than the government starting to believe its own publicity; it is a case of the publicity being put there in place of any reality.

PARA.TAB: Where have the opportunities been for young people and students, for the welfare and lobby groups to air their concerns and ask questions and to modify the intentions of the government? I have not seen them and the people who represent and work with young people concerned by this legislation have not seen them either. The Democrats endeavoured to provide such an opportunity by inviting groups such as ACOSS, APEC, NUS and the Welfare Rights Centre to let us know the impacts of these changes. Last Monday we had a round table conference to which we invited those groups. It was enlightening and effective. We listened to their concerns. Our amendments and the questions that I would ask of this bill reflect their suggestions as well as our concerns on a policy basis.

I stress that the biggest concern that these organisations have with this piece of legislation is the fact that there has been little time for debate, questioning and representation of the reality to the government. It was with a great deal of disappointment that I saw the government so eager to call off the idea of a committee hearing. A Friday hearing with a few minutes for each group and very little opportunity to question was less than adequate. The attitude of the government was, `We have spoken to somebody from NUS and it is all fixed up now.' I think we will find that it is anything but all fixed up now. We have had a few government amendments and we have had some suggestions taken on the run, but we have not seen an open and thorough consideration of this very important initiative.

The youth training initiative, of which the youth training allowance is an integral part, is in some ways an exciting and innovative scheme. The bill in front of us does set out a noble objective; it seeks to replace the jobsearch allowance with a youth training allowance. In a recent youth options paper it was described as a means of providing work, good pay and job security for young people. The government's focus is on helping young unemployed people by providing a training strategy and education `pathways'—a wonderful new word, that; I am sure everybody understands what it means. The idea is that, if people follow a certain track and do all the right things, the golden light or great moment of enlightenment will descend upon them.

There are no guarantees. Despite talk of activity agreements and negotiation, there does not seem to be any kind of reciprocal arrangement, any assurance that, once young Australians have gone along that pathway, jumped through the requisite hoops, behaved themselves and done all that is required, they will get a job. Where is the job? Where is the obligation from the government's side? What guarantee does a young person have? This is why we see so much cynicism from young people. We have seen people who have gone through school, done what they were supposed to do, look over their shoulder and find a government which blames them.

In the previous legislation, which I spent so much time in the last hour or so debating, it was those people who had done all the right things who were being blamed for some sort of debt that the government had. Here again the obligation of the government, its side of the bargain, is being weaseled away from. We do not see enough equivalent responsibility being accepted by the government. In this bill the onus is on young people to comply, to do their bit, and if they fail to do so they are punished. In my party, the Democrats, we accept that there must be some strings attached to the provision of income support or financial benefits in our society, but we do not accept that there is one rule for young people and another rule or set of obligations for the government. That is our reaction to that sort of approach and the mentality behind it.

Leaving that aside for the moment, there are some outstanding questions. We ask sincerely: what happens to those young people who cannot find a job at the end of the education and training pathways that are provided? Where do they turn to then? How are they defined or described? I think a big part of the problem is that we are so derogatory of the people who do the right thing but find at the end of the day that society has not done its side of the bargain for them.

The other question we are left to ask—and I again agree with Senator Troeth—is why there is such a level of duplication of the Social Security Act. What is this we are dealing with here? Is it social security, employment, education or training? If the government is so concerned to redefine these young people, to categorise them differently, to reassemble its paradigm, then it would do a lot better than to just give part of the Social Security Act another name. We acknowledge that, as the Welfare Rights Centre has pointed out, everything contained in this bill that relates to the proposed youth training allowance activity agreement process and requirements is currently available under the jobsearch allowance activity agreement process and requirements. So why cart it around and give it a different name? I think it was 260 or 270 pages—

TALK.START.PARA: —It was 267.

—Thank you. It was 267 pages of repetitious bureaucracy talk. Why do this to people? Is this a scheme to provide employment for the government printer or something? There does not seem to be a rationale for it at all.

PARA.TAB: We are most concerned about the level of duplication and replication in this bill. I ask the government quite sincerely why it seeks to contain these changes within new legislation under DEET? Why does it not seek to use current legislative mechanisms already available to the government under the DSS? The answer I have heard is, `It is a different philosophical approach. We have to establish a different set of parameters.' We can accept that as a philosophical statement, but the reality—I keep talking about the reality—is that it is another pile of paper that does not do anything that the old pile of paper could not do.

It is all very well to have a focus on education and training, but we would like to think that there was a focus on jobs as well. The government can call it what it likes; it can put a label on it. It can relabel a section of the DSS act if it wants to. It is the government; it can tell people that it is no longer a complete DSS act, that it is all about jobs and training and incorporates those aspects of that legislation. It would not then be seen as transparently labelling something for the sake of getting a new act of parliament; it would be seen as actually making the existing act work better.

This difference in focus really does not necessitate a different piece of legislation. The existing provisions in the Social Security Act could accommodate the reforms. It is very important both for the coalition and for the Democrats that that point of view is expressed strongly and that the minister is challenged to provide some sort of excuse as to why this is so necessary.

We will be seeking to amend two sections of this bill. They relate primarily to definitions, but not only to definitions. It is not only the definitions that concern us. We will seek to change the definition of independence for a young person by decreasing the waiting period from 26 to 18 weeks. We do not understand the government's motives in regard to this piece of legislation. In 1992 the government reduced the waiting period from 26 to 18 weeks because it was considered a more appropriate and fair time period. Why then has the government decided now to postpone the waiting period to 26 weeks? In the document A national employment and training plan for young Australians—some senators may remember that document; it was launched after the PM's youth summit in 1992—the Prime Minister said:
In response to problems raised by a number of delegates at the National meeting, the Government is announcing today initiatives to support and simplify—

SPEECH.PARA: remember that word `simplify'-
income support arrangements for unemployed young people.

Included in those initiatives was the reduction from 26 to 18 weeks in the time required for income support recipients under 18 to have lived away from home before becoming eligible for the higher independent rate of payment. Now we are going back the other way. That is what the government does—it consults with young people, changes things and a couple of years later sneaks back its own set-up without consultation. So the youth summit was a worthless exercise. We have had this contradiction now. Anything to do with youth is brought before parliament. Young people are not consulted and the government welshed on the original arrangement.

PARA.TAB: No wonder young people are cynical. No wonder they laugh up their sleeves at the government. In the Democrats' youth poll we found an extremely high percentage of young people who would not even bother to vote for anybody here, because they do not trust any of us. When the government has a youth summit it agrees to give young people an amendment which will affect them slightly, but as soon as their backs are turned and as soon as it is quiet, it takes it away.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Sen J.J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening I wish to relate my comments to the decision of the Channel 9 television network to screen the program Death on Request at 8.30 p.m. last Thursday, 24 November. The program dealt with the controversial subject of euthanasia. The Dutch documentary followed from, the beginning to the end, an elderly and ill man's decision to terminate his life, with the support of his wife and doctor. Moreover, for the first time on Australian television, an intensely intimate and detailed death scene was shown. Death was brought about by the doctor administering a lethal injection to the frail patient.

PARA.TAB: Channel 9 executive, Mr Len Downs, conceded on radio that the showing of the death scene in its most complete form was a first for Australian television. Therefore, by Mr Downs's own admission, it is a powerful show that has pushed the boundaries of television censorship to their outer limits.

My concern is as much against the clear breach of the commercial television industry code of practice and the Broadcasting Services Act 1992 as it is against the principle that the program sought to portray. I make this claim on three grounds. Firstly, the program was wrongly rated M. Rather, it was deserving of the higher classification of MA—for mature adults. Material classified M, for mature audiences, is recommended for viewing by persons aged 15 years and over. The M classification of Death on Request breaches the commercial television industry code of practice. In relation to suicide, that code of practice states that suicide must not be depicted favourably and methods of suicide must not be depicted in realistic detail. On any analysis, the program shows the assisted suicide in realistic detail and on any analysis it is depicted favourably. Certainly, no alternative argument to euthanasia was given television time.

Yet even the M classification did not satisfy the Nine Network chief classification officer, Mr Richard Lyle. Responding to my correspondence on behalf of Channel 9 owner Mr Kerry Packer, Mr Lyle, in a letter dated 24 November, claimed that it could be played even earlier, in a PG time slot of 7.30 p.m. I bring to the attention of the Senate the gravity of Mr Lyle's comments. The PG classification under the voluntary code of practice clearly states in regard to suicide:

SPEECH.PARA: The depiction of suicide or attempted suicide must be inexplicit and discreet and must not be presented as a means of achieving a desired result or as an appropriate response to stress, depression or other problems.

Thankfully, Mr Lyle is bound by some law, by way of the Broadcasting Act; otherwise Death on Request would have sunk to the lowly rating of PG, to be shown at 7.30 p.m. I believe Mr Lyle is employed to apply the law, not to make it up. I question Mr Lyle's competence to be a judge of community standards. I believe his position is no longer tenable because of his abandonment of the accepted code of practice.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, the program was wrongly time slotted. It is only 12 months since the television industry made commitments to a very concerned Prime Minister to adhere to a new code of practice, in particular, the time slotting of adult shows after 9.30 p.m. I quote what the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) said on the ABC AM program on Friday, 6 November 1992:

SPEECH.PARA: Adult only movies, I think, should be telecast no earlier than 9.30 on an evening, so at least children have got some chance of being protected from it. I just don't think that children or young people in particular, who haven't had enough years to sort of settle their thoughts about these subjects, who have themselves probably never seen, the majority or most have never seen a violent thing happen or killing, to see it as it is now being depicted in sort of what you would call an everyday circumstance of depiction of modern television, well it's too much for a culture to keep absorbing.

So the television networks have clearly cast aside their glossy commitments they made to the parliament and to the Prime Minister some 12 months ago regarding the slotting of programs. The parliament can no longer trust the word of a television executive when it comes to self-rating or self time slotting of obviously controversial themes like Death on Request. Television stations do not have a licence to subject prime-time family audiences to intrusive and highly personalised footage of the suicide of a human being.

PARA.TAB: Thirdly, and probably the worst breach of all, was the neglect of the promotions of Death on Request. The code of practice is clear about promotions giving adequate prior warning to viewers. Instead of warning viewers, the promotions had virtually boasted about the program's content. In particular, a WIN television press release dressed up the program in controversy and gave no warnings of the intimate death scene to follow. Based on the program's negligent promotions, a viewer, in particular, an elderly person, could be led unsuspectingly to the program's real life death scene and be subsequently traumatised. The programmers have obviously lost sight of the massive influence which the documentary would have on the elderly, the seriously ill and the emotionally unstable.

The showing of Death on Request last Thursday is the clearest indication yet that television executives have lost touch with community opinion and standards. I refer to a poll taken by the Herald-Sun published on Friday, 25 November that showed 54 per cent of people believed that Channel 9 should not have televised the documentary. I am sure a greater number of people would agree, at the very least, that the program should not have been shown in the time slot of 8.30 p.m. Therefore, the television industry has soiled its own nest.

A self-regulatory code of practice is no longer an option for a parliament that seeks to be the touchstone of community standards. Television rating should now be placed in the same category as movies, videos and video games and come under the jurisdiction of the Film Censorship Board and its appeal body, the Film and Literature Board of Review. After all, the classifications of M and MA are the same definitions as used by these bodies.

To this end, I will be petitioning the responsible minister, the Attorney-General, Mr Lavarch, and the responsible Senate committee on community standards to consider this matter with the aim of tightening control over loose television executives and their in-house censors. As a matter of course complaints have already been forwarded to the Australian Broadcasting Authority for action. To leave the matter undisputed would be to give television censors the right to send our very fragile standards on a ride into the outer limits.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to address an issue that was raised today, and of course we ran out of time in taking note of questions without notice and answers given to them. I particularly want to deal with the Port Hinchinbrook development project. I obtained a large number of documents under the freedom of information legislation which cast some very interesting light on the whole debate which has been going on.

PARA.TAB: One of the issues which has been raised is that of the mangrove removal, and particularly this comment by Premier Goss: `Senator Faulkner said he took his action because of his concern about the effect of mangrove removal on the seagrass beds in the World Heritage area. No such concern has been mentioned by anyone during the 10 months of detailed consultation during which the issue of mangrove clearing was specifically discussed.'

A question was asked today about whom one should believe. Unfortunately, the Premier of Queensland is becoming less and less believable in this debate. I will quote from a number of documents—obviously, I cannot quote from all of them—which bear specifically on the issue of mangrove removal. For instance, a letter to Mr K. J. Down, Head of the Office of the Coordinator-General, dated 9 June 1994, from the Director-General of the DPI in Queensland, stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The maintenance of the large mature mangroves along the foreshore should be considered as providing an environmental feature, enhancing the proposed development. Experience with other coastal developments indicates that removal of mangroves does not necessarily alleviate the problem of insect pests but often leads to a shift in the type of insect pest. Mangroves also provide foreshore stability and contribute to local and regional fisheries productivity.
It is highly possible that seagrass meadows could be damaged by dredging work and associated turbidity.
Seagrasses are vital to the local dugong population. Ensuring their protection should be a minimum requirement.

That is one letter in which the Premier's own departments discussed the issue of mangroves. I have another memo obtained under freedom of information. It is again to John Down from his own department. It is headed `Port Hinchinbrook—mangrove issues'. There are a couple of pages on mangroves. The document states:

At a meeting on 28 February 1994, attended by representatives of DEH and DPI to discuss the report prepared by Cardno & Davies, officers of both departments indicated that they will recommend retention of the mature foreshore mangroves.

Surely this is a highly significant comment and goes against the Premier's claim that no-one raised the issue of mangroves. Of course, we know that many people outside of the departments did raise the issue—including scientists, conservation groups and Mr Goss's own staff.

PARA.TAB: I also have a facsimile message to Jan Bimrose of the Office of the Coordinator-General, this time under the heading `the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority', dated 5 August 1994. Across the letter is written `urgent'—I presume written by the recipient of the letter. It comes from Mike Bugler, Assistant Director, Environmental Impact Management. This particular document again refers to the mangroves. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Effects of the mangrove removal operation at the beach replenishment site.

It is quite possible that (as with the dredging operation) the mangrove removal process (not described in any of the documentation I have seen) could create a substantial turbidity plume and greatly increased sedimentation rates in adjacent areas.

This whole letter discusses in quite a lot of detail the issue of mangroves. I am afraid that Mr Goss has been badly informed. I imagine that really is the explanation. He says that no concern had been raised by anyone. There is the concern of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority, the concern of people within the Office of the Coordinator-General, and the concern of the Department of Primary Industries with the issue of mangrove removal.

PARA.TAB: Further, among the documents which I received there were a number from Mr Williams himself. I probably will not have time to read the whole of these letters, but again I will comment from them and seek to table them at a later time when I have had time to distribute them. It is also useful, by reading from the letter, to indicate the kind of pressure that Mr Williams applied in seeking to have his proposals granted. In a letter to the Cardwell Shire Council, dated 13 September 1994, Mr Williams wrote:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . it is now only your Council that is preventing the project from proceeding.

If we cannot reconcile the outstanding matters on an amicable and commonsense basis then I intend to proceed in accordance with my existing and valid approvals which will increase the potential guest population of the project to a figure in excess of 2,200.
Publicly your Council will have to bear the responsibility for this and for delivering to the people of Cardwell a project which is vastly inferior to that which my company has submitted.
As a last attempt to bring sanity to the situation I will draft a letter to all Council members which, if not considered to be acceptable, will double as a press release.
A facsimile message from the Office of the Coordinator-General—again from Mr Down—to Mr Geoff Walsh, Senior Private Secretary, Office of the Prime Minister, states:
Dear Mr Walsh

Please find attached a copy of a facsimile message received in this Office today from Mr Keith Williams. The contents of the fax are an example of the extreme pressure we are under. Earlier today I had a telephone conversation with Mr Williams in which he told me he was about to instruct his solicitors to proceed against various Ministers and Senior Executive Officers of the State.

That message is dated 29 September 1994. Obviously, the state government felt that it was being pressured. It is interesting that the permits were issued the next day. In a further letter to Mr Down of the Office of the Coordinator-General, Mr Williams writes:
Understandably I have run out of patience and I have had a gut full of waiting for phone calls that seldom eventuate.
Unless I receive ancillary permits . . . and a definite time and date for approval I see no alternative but to take whatever action is appropriate to protecting the value of my assets.

My proposed "expose everything" media campaign will no doubt include an open offer to the Government to buy the site for public purposes. This amounts to an invitation to the Government to put up or shut up.
I have already issued instructions to my solicitor to prepare the basis of my case against the Queensland Government and specified individuals.
This morning Robin Potter advised that my best avenue of recourse would be against the Federal Government—

The Senate can understand the concern I have about the kind of pressure applied particularly to the state government and the Cardwell Shire Council by Mr Williams. It illustrates the kind of way in which this man operates and underlines again the concern that I have about this development, about the whole way in which it has proceeded and certainly about the Premier's claim that there was never any mention of the mangrove removal. The whole thing has been a mess from beginning to finish. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a couple of confessions to make to the Senate. I have had an addiction—an addiction to sweets and lollies for a number of years. This addiction started when, as a small boy in the small country town of Boonah, I used to go to the local grocery store to get the groceries for the family and always bought threepence worth of lollies. My favourites were hard jubes. I became addicted to them at that stage in life.

PARA.TAB: I lost track of them during my teenage years. But in my early adulthood I discovered some sweets called Marella jubes that were like the old lollies I used to have. They had a very intense fruit flavour. They were very hard and made very good chewing. I have bought a lot of these sweets over the last few years, becoming somewhat addicted to them.

A couple of years ago, I noticed that the sweets had become softer. They were hard, but not as hard they used to be. This annoyed me. I stopped buying them for a little while, but the flavours took me back to them. So I have put up with what I thought was an inferior quality sweet. I recently thought to myself, `That is not good enough. I am going to write to the company, Nestle Confectionery Ltd, and tell its representatives that they have changed their recipe and that I do not like it. I will suggest that they go back to the hard jubes.' I did accordingly write to the company.
This morning, I received a response from the company. Part of it says this:

SPEECH.PARA: You are correct when you noted that we did, indeed, change our formulation several years ago. The Marella Jubes that you were familiar with were made to a Rowntree (U.K.) recipe, and required several ingredients imported from the U.S. and U.K. In 1991, we developed several recipes using only Australian ingredients, and settled on one after Consumer taste tests. The result was a product which tasted the same, but which, alas, was a little softer.

First, I want to congratulate Nestle Confectionery Ltd for taking this action. It is good to see companies based in Australia making sure that their products are made from entirely Australian produce. As a person who has made my living out of the sugar industry all of my life and who still lives in a sugar community, I am very pleased to see that a company which uses such a lot of sugar not only uses Australian sugar, which I am sure it always did, but also now uses entirely Australian products in the making of its sweets.

PARA.TAB: I suppose that on that basis, and because this is the reason for the change in the recipe, I will have to accept the Nestle Confectionery Ltd new recipes and my Marella jubes being a little softer. The letter that I quoted from went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: Since the changeover, sales have remained healthy, and we can only assume that most of our consumers have accepted the slightly softer Marella.
So be it. The final paragraph of the letter is the second confession I have to make to the Senate. It says:
I am sure that you will be able to develop a taste for the new recipe, and have included several packs of Marella jubes to help you along.
With that, the company kindly set me this rather exciting looking parcel of Marella jubes, which I have been staring at rather enviously all day.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pass them around.

—Senator Sherry says, `Pass them around.' I feel a little embarrassed in these days of disclosure and the registration of senators' interests, particularly when in some other parliaments of the world people are being accused of accepting bribes to do certain things. I am a bit worried about that, so I have come to the conclusion that I will not accept the Marella jubes. Fortunately, I am probably in the financial position where I can buy my own in any case. What I will do with these Marella jubes which Nestle Confectionery Ltd has very kindly sent to me is donate them to a charity which benefits children.

PARA.TAB: I have had a good think about which charity I might select. Many deserving charities around Australia support children, particularly disadvantaged children. I have decided that I will make a donation of the Nestle company gift to the Lower Burdekin branch of the Endeavour Foundation. Madam Acting Deputy President, you may be aware that the Endeavour Foundation was formerly called the Subnormal Children's Welfare Association. I think it is an association in Queensland only. However, there are similar associations in other parts of Australia. It is a voluntary organisation which does magnificent work with intellectually disabled people—not only children—of all ages.

The Lower Burdekin branch, which is the branch in my home town of Ayr, has a number of facilities, including a four-bedroom residence at 18 Cox Street, Ayr called `Carinya'. It has another residential place called the Arthur Coburn Residential situated at Groper Creek Road, Home Hill. Eight residents are provided with accommodation in a secure environment there. The Activity Therapy Centre of the Endeavour Foundation in Ayr teaches 17 people social, recreational and life skills. The Clive William Taylor Farm at Home Hill provides employment for 12 intellectually disabled people. I well remember that farm. I am very pleased to say that my legal firm in Ayr was instrumental in getting a cane assignment for that farm many years ago.

I am also very proud and honoured that the Lower Burdekin branch of the Endeavour Foundation invited me to be patron of its branch. I am very happy and honoured to have accepted that invitation. I will make these Marella jubes available to the foundation the next time that I am in Ayr. Having purged my soul with those two confessions, I think we can now finish the Senate for tonight.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: International Convention on the Rights of the Child

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 20 December 1993:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the fact that Australia ratified the International Convention on the Rights of the Child on 17 December 1990 and it entered into force on 16 January 1991, and given that Australia was required to submit a report of compliance with the convention 2 years after it came into effect and this has still not been completed some 10 months later, even though the total staff allocation of the department for the formulation of the Australian report amounts to one person for 2 days a week:
(1) Do the current mechanisms in place for the formulation of the report, including staffing, represent an adequate allocation of resources and priority to this important project;
(2) When will Australia submit its report of compliance on the International Convention on the Rights of the Child to the United Nations;

(3) What action will be taken to ensure that all Australian States comply with our obligations under the Convention on the Rights of the Child, in particular, is the Minister prepared to override legislation in Western Australia, Victoria and South Australia which contravenes the provisions of the International Convention on the Rights of the Child.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The adequacy of existing resources for compliance with Australia's reporting requirements is currently under review and money has been allocated in 1994-1995 to set up a Report Writing Unit in my Department. Resources set aside for this are as follows:
(2) The report is close to being finalised and will be forwarded to the Committee on the Rights of the Child as soon as approvals have been gained from the relevant Ministers.

(3) The normal consultative processes for international conventions was followed in the case of the Convention on the Rights of the Child. The Commonwealth consulted the State and Territory Governments throughout the drafting stages of the Convention (which took ten years) and State Government representatives participated in the Australian delegation to the United Nations Working Group which drafted the Convention. States and Territories were further consulted on the question of Australia's signature of the Convention and, prior to ratification, State and Territory governments confirmed that their laws already enabled Australia to meet all the obligations imposed by the Convention (other than one which requires child and adult criminal offenders to be imprisoned separately, for which Australia made a reservation on the basis of geographic and demographic circumstances).

The issues raised by the WA Juvenile Crimes (Serious and Repeat Offenders) Sentencing Act 1992 (which has now lapsed) and the Victorian Crimes (Amendment) Bill 1993 and the Sentencing (Amendment) Bill 1993, were the subject of correspondence between my predecessor, myself and my State counterparts. That correspondence highlighted the Commonwealth Government's concerns, which were disputed by the States, that this legislation had the potential to, and may in fact, infringe our international human rights obligations, in particular those under the Convention on the Rights of the Child.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 1 June 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Can the Australian Government withdraw from or denounce as a matter of law the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights.
(2) Is there any mechanism whereby the Federal Government could allow for the Covenant not to apply to any specific State of the Commonwealth.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Covenant does not contain any express provision relating to denunciation or withdrawal.
Article 56(1) of the Vienna Convention on the Law of Treaties, to which Australia is a party, provides that, in such circumstances, a treaty is not subject to denunciation or withdrawal where:
(a) it is established that the parties intended to admit the possibility of denunciation or withdrawal; or
(b) a right of denunciation or withdrawal may be influenced by the nature of treaty.

There is nothing in the travaux to the Covenant to suggest that either of the circumstances referred to in paragraphs (a) and (b) is met in relation to the Covenant. Moreover, by contrast with the Covenant, it is noted that the First Optional Protocol to the ICCPR, which was negotiated simultaneously with the Covenant, expressly provides for a right of withdrawal.
(2) No. Senators should also note that the Covenant has no direct impact on Australian law as it has not been enacted into law by the Parliament.

PARA.TAB: (1) What is the total amount of Australia Council funding which has or will be provided to the Tasmanian Island magazine for the 1989-90, 1990-91, 1991-92, 1992-93, 1993-94 and 1994-95 financial years.
(2) In relation to the financial years referred to in (1) what other funding has been provided to the Island magazine from areas within the Minister's portfolio.
(3) What audit procedures have been in place to ensure that the funds allocated to the Island magazine have been used in accordance with the grants guidelines.
(4) Has Island magazine met the required standards of financial management practices in relation to its receipt of grants; if not, what steps have been taken to rectify this.
(5) Has the Minister received advice of possible maladministration within Island magazine and can an undertaking be given to investigate any such claims.
(6) What remedies are available to the Government where it can be proven that Australia Council grants have been expended in an improper manner.

(7) Would the department provide assistance to an Australia Council recipient in pursuing a former employee who may be guilty of unauthorised expenditure; if so, what assistance could be provided under such circumstances.
(8) What, if any, Australia Council grants have been made to the following persons: (a) Dr Cassandra Pybus; (b) Ms Margaret Scott; (c) Mr Andrew Sant; and (d) Mr Richard Flanagan.
(9) Is the Minister aware that computer records belonging to the Australia Council grant recipient Island magazine may have been maliciously destroyed.
(10) Will the Minister give an undertaking to investigate such allegations and advise of the outcome.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

TAB.TAB: 1994-95—nil to date

PARA.TAB: An application under the name of Island magazine for a series of literary tours throughout Tasmania was received in March 1994 by the Literature Board from the then editor, Dr Cassandra Pybus. A grant of $5,000 was approved at the Board's May meeting on the condition that a new incorporated body was established to be the grant recipient. Advice has been received by the Board that an organisation called Literary Promotions Incorporated has now been registered under the Tasmanian Associations Incorporation Act 1984 and this organisation has been recorded by the Board as a recipient.
(2) None.

The Council may subsequently ask for further explanation and access to a recipient's financial records. If there is not satisfactory acquittal of the grant, the Council may ask for repayment of the grant.
(4) The Australia Council has advised the Minister that required standards have been met.

(5), (9) & (10) The Australia Council has advised the Minister that it is aware of a media release put out by the Managing Committee of Island magazine in June 1994 regarding destruction of computer records belonging to the magazine. The Australia Council advises that allegations in this release are the subject of a writ in the Supreme Court of Tasmania.

The Australia Council further advised that the Managing Committee has advised that certain records have been located and that reporting materials subsequently supplied by the Managing Committee indicate that it is in possession of relevant financial records.

(6) If it can be proven that Australia Council grants have been expended in an improper manner, the Australia Council can ask for a) repayment of the unacquitted grant or b) refuse to pay out any further amounts to the client (even if a subsequent application for funding has been approved).

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Resources, upon notice, on 31 August 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is an application by Queensland Hardwood Resources Pty Ltd (QHR) for a licence to export 140 000 tonnes of woodchips produced from sawmill waste in south-east Queensland currently being examined by the department.
(2) How many cubic metres of sawlog timber are needed to produce 140 000 tonnes of woodchips produced from sawmill waste.
(3) Who are the beneficial owners of the QHR consortium.

(4) Can confirmation be given that: (a) QHR will not be permitted to utilise trees and other native vegetation unsuitable for sawmilling; (b) no trees which would otherwise be uneconomic to harvest will be harvested as a result of the extra revenue provided by the QHR licence; (c) no other timber will be added to the waste to be utilised by QHR in order to bring the woodchips up to the minimum standard normally accepted by Japanese buyers; (d) the existence of an export woodchip operation in south-east Queensland will not encourage additional private land clearance in the region; (e) no additional approvals will be issued to allow timber to be sold for woodchip export from private land; (f) before any such licence is issued to QHR, the matter will be referred to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner) to conduct a formal public environment review of the application; and (g) any application by QHR to vary the proposed licence to include timber from sources other than sawmill waste would be subject to a full environment impact assessment.

(5) Does the Minister agree that extension of woodchip licences to Queensland, where none currently exists, sends the wrong signals to an industry which the Government has agreed to phase out in the year 2000.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Resources has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes.

(2) There is no means of determining exactly how much sawmill waste will be produced prior to milling. However, the Environmental Impact Statement recently completed and publicly released by Sawmillers Exports Pty Ltd, an exporter of woodchips sourced from sawmill waste in northern New South Wales, provides an indication of the utilisation of a typical sawlog from the region. Based on this assessment we could expect one cubic metre of sawlog to yield 0.40 tonnes of sawn timber, 0.45 tonnes of woodchips, 0.25 tonnes of sawdust and 0.10 tonnes of other waste. On this basis it is likely that about 311 000 cubic metres of sawlog timber would produce 140 000 tonnes of woodchips and about 124 000 tonnes of sawn timber.
(3) QHR is a newly formed joint venture company owned by two long established sawmilling companies, Queensland Sawmills Pty Ltd of Brisbane and Hyne and Son Pty Ltd of Maryborough.

(4) (a)(b)(c) & (d) QHR are currently seeking a licence to export woodchips produced from the wastes from sawlog milling. This licence application is under consideration. Any issues relating to sourcing of material from other than sawmilling wastes would depend upon a proposal being received.

(4) (e)(f) & (g) There has been no application for operations on private lands to supply QHR. If an application to export woodchips from sources other than sawmill residues is received it will be considered with due regard being given to Minister for Resources' responsibilities under Commonwealth legislation.

(5) No. In 1991 the Commonwealth and States expressed their preference for phasing out woodchip exports from native forests by 2000 in favour of processing of the resource in Australia. After 2000 the export of woodchips that are surplus to domestic requirements would be considered on a case by case basis. In the National Forest Policy Statement the Commonwealth stated that where a regional forest agreement is in operation it will consider extending export approvals for unprocessed wood beyond the current annual renewal cycle.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 20 September 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has the Government changed its policy in relation to Burma; if so: (a) what are the changes; (b) what are the new directions that will impact upon decisions in the future; and (c) when did the changes come into effect.
(2) What is the Government's view of `constructive engagement' which is the policy of the Asian nations towards Burma.

(3) Does the Government believe that the policy of `constructive engagement' has been successful in: (a) moves toward freeing Aung San Suu Kyi; (b) improving the human rights record of Burma's ruling junta; and (c) improving the economic situation for Burmese minorities.

(4) What was meant by the Minister's comments, reported on page 29 of the Far Eastern Economic Review of 25 August 1994 that `The notion of making some kind of better progress through dialogue, through communication, rather than through brick walls is one that has some merits. I am having to eat my words and I hope I don't get indigestion as a result'.
(5) Which countries support the policy of `constructive engagement' towards Burma.
(6) (a) What is the policy of the European Union towards Burma; and (b) is the European Union considering changing its policy; if so, how is it considering changing it.
(7) Have the European Union begun talks with the State Law and Order Restoration Council (SLORC) in Burma; if so, with what intention.
(8) (a) Has the Australian Government or any government or parliamentary representative begun talks with the SLORC in Burma; if so, with what intention; and (b) what was the nature of the discussion.
(9) What is the total number of political prisoners detained by the Burma Government in 1994.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The fundamentals of Australia's policy in relation to Myanmar have not changed. We maintain the suspension of official bilateral development assistance, the ban on defence exports and the suspension of defence visits from Australia, and our policy to neither encourage nor discourage trade. We also continue to use our best endeavours, in dialogue with the SLORC, in multilateral forums, and in discussion with other countries, notably those in the region, to encourage political reform and respect for human rights in Myanmar. At the ASEAN Post Ministerial Conference in Bangkok in July, three themes which underpin our approach to Myanmar attracted general support: any progress in Myanmar would be more likely to be achieved through dialogue and engagement by the international community, rather than through confrontation and isolation; "benchmarks" were a useful means of gauging movement; and there should be a relationship between concessions to the SLORC and progress in Myanmar. I identified possible benchmarks as:
the unconditional release of Aung San Suu Kyi;
the commencement of a serious dialogue with Aung San Suu Kyi about the political and constitutional evolution of the country;
access to political prisoners by the International Committee of the Red Cross, UN Special Rapporteur and other outsiders;
a review and reduction of sentences imposed for political activity;
significant progress in the proposed dialogue between the SLORC and the UN;
a clear timetable for the constitutional process, with delegates able to participate more freely;
agreement by the SLORC to the inclusion of transitional provisions in the new constitution permitting further constitutional development;
the provision of legal guarantees for the rights of the ethnic minorities;
the cessation of forced labour and porterage beyond what are traditional practices; and
the repeal of censorship and state protection legislation.

(2) The `constructive engagement' policy of the ASEAN countries seeks to integrate Myanmar into regional and broader international processes as a way of exerting a positive influence on human rights and political reform. Australia has strongly encouraged ASEAN countries to use their contacts with Myanmar to send clear signals about respect for human rights and early movement towards a more participative political system in Myanmar and not to grant further `rewards' to Myanmar until significant further progress has been made on the benchmarks. There is evidence that ASEAN governments are aware of their potential influence and that they have been exercising it, a process that we have encouraged.

(3) I would not wish to comment on the content or effectiveness of the Myanmar policy of our ASEAN neighbours, which have the sovereign right to conduct their own external affairs as they see fit. It seems, however, that international opinion does have some influence on the SLORC's approach, and that ASEAN countries have a particular significance in this regard. Recent events in Myanmar give some cause for hope for further positive steps in Myanmar's political evolution. In particular, the meetings between the SLORC and Aung San Suu Kyi on 20 September and 28 October could lead to the commencement of a dialogue of substance on political reform and national reconciliation, which the Australian Government has been advocating for some time. I took the opportunity to encourage this dialogue in my meeting with Myanmar Foreign Minister U Ohn Gyaw in New York in early October.

(4) I meant that pursuing a dialogue with the SLORC, and applying the `benchmarks' approach, could be more effective than isolating and ostracising Myanmar in encouraging political reform and improving the human rights situation in that country.
(5) The ASEAN countries characterise their policy as `constructive engagement' with Myanmar. I am not aware of any other countries which describe their policy in these specific terms.

(6) As a reflection of its concern about the situation in Myanmar, the European Union (EU) suspended all bilateral aid programs; discontinued or limited aid through multilateral bodies; cut defence links, and applied a total ban on arms sales. The EU actively participates in international efforts to press the Myanmar authorities to improve their human rights performance and to institute democratic and economic reforms. My understanding of current EU policy is that any fundamental change in its relations with Myanmar is unlikely in the absence of significant progress in a number of areas, including in such areas as respect for human rights and political reforms.

(7) I am not aware of any EU initiative for talks with the SLORC in Myanmar, although EU member countries with Embassies in Myanmar no doubt maintain contact with the SLORC. Moreover, the EU, represented by Germany, France and Greece, met with Myanmar Foreign Minister U Ohn Gyaw recently in New York to commence a process of `critical dialogue' with the SLORC. I understand that the purpose of the dialogue is to ensure that the SLORC appreciates that the resumption of normal relations between the EU and Myanmar is dependent on improvements in their human rights performance, and progress towards political liberalisation and national reconciliation.

(8) Our Embassy in Yangon maintains a continuing dialogue with the SLORC, including on human rights and the need to expedite political reform. I have had meetings with Foreign Minister U Ohn Gyaw, including in Bangkok in July and again at the UN General Assembly in New York in October to sustain the dialogue. However, there has been no specific new Australian Government initiative to begin talks in Myanmar with the SLORC. Senator Hill visited Myanmar in July in a private capacity.

(9) It is difficult to specify with precision the number of political prisoners currently in detention in Myanmar. 2,111 political detainees have been released since 1992 under SLORC declaration 11/92, but we believe that many remain in custody.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications and the Arts, upon notice, on 21 September 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) What is the reason that residents of Binalong Bay in Tasmania are unable to receive Special Broadcasting Service (SBS) television programs.
(2) What different technical requirements exist that might make it possible to relay Australian Broadcasting Corporation programs but not SBS programs.
(3) What other population centres of Tasmania are without the benefits of SBS reception.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) There is a high demand for SBS services from communities across Australia. As limited resources are available to extend SBS television to all areas which have expressed an interest in receiving it, SBS television extensions must be considered on a phased basis.

SBS television in Tasmania is provided to communities within the coverage area of the main transmitting stations at Mount Wellington in the South and Mount Barrow in Northern Tasmania which pick up the SBS signal from the Optus satellite. The SBS signal from Mount Barrow covers an area from Wynyard in the West to Tomahawk in the north-east and to below Campbell Town in the South.

Translators or retransmitting devices are installed within the main transmitting station coverage area to ensure good reception in places where the topography hinders an incoming signal. Binalong Bay is well outside the Mount Barrow SBS television coverage area. Additional transmission facilities would be required to provide SBS television in the Binalong Bay area. Funding for such facilities would need to be considered against the competing claims from other areas in Australia that do not receive SBS television.

(2) I am unaware of any technical obstacle to providing transmission of SBS television to Binalong Bay. The extension of SBS television would require the installation of transmission facilities and unlike pre-existing ABC services would represent a new service, requiring separate Budget consideration.

(3) There are a number of towns in Tasmania which do not receive SBS television. I have separately provided the honourable senator with copies of maps prepared by the National Transmission Agency which show SBS television coverage areas from the Mount Wellington and Mount Barrow transmitting stations.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 13 October 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) What are the protocols and regulations in regard to the taking on and discharge of ballast water for Naval vessels, including submarines.
(2) Are these being followed for vessels visiting, or operating out of, HMAS Stirling in Western Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) & (2) RAN surface and submarine vessels operating out of HMAS Stirling, and all other Australian ports, are required to comply with the regulations outlined in the Maritime Command Orders, which, with regard to ballasting, are derived from the MARPOL Convention. Further, it is a Royal Australian Navy Environmental objective `to prevent infestations by marine pest organisms through the inappropriate disposal of ballast waters.' Additionally, foreign naval vessels arriving from overseas are required to declare if the ship has exchanged ballast water during the voyage, and if it has logbook certification of time and coordinates when reballasting took place; or, if the vessel is part of a compliance arrangement for ballast water control accepted by Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service.

Although naval ships are able to ballast water into segregated ballast tanks, they will only do so when either bunkerage or cargo tanks are low. The only occasion for this is in open ocean operations when it may be done as fuel stocks are depleted. There is no reason to embark or discharge salt water ballast in harbour. Ballast water embarked by naval vessels outside Australian waters is discharged prior to entering Australian waters. It needs to be emphasised that naval vessels do not ballast as a matter of course; in fact, ballasting is a relatively rare occurrence.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 17 October 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) (a) What are the revised conditions for using atrazine; and (b) when, and how will they take effect.
(2) How is information about these revised conditions being disseminated to users.
(3) What mechanism is to be put in place to monitor and enforce the revised conditions of use.
(4) Why is atrazine considered `essential' to the establishment of eucalypt plantations, and what alternatives have been considered.

(5) Is the Minister aware that the Tasmanian Registrar of Pesticides has asked Tasmanian councils to use their remaining stocks of atrazine by December 1995; if so, how is this consistent with concerns about residues affecting water supplies.
(6) What is the composition, and what are the terms of reference and reporting protocols in place for the taskforce established to assess the impact of the use of atrazine.
(7) Will this taskforce be utilising the information, expertise and resources of the Waterwatch network and other water monitoring groups; if not, why not.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The revised conditions for using atrazine were notified in NRA Gazette of 6 September 1994. Product registrants have been contacted and advised that label changes to reflect these conditions are to be made at the next label reprint or by no later than 1 December 1995. Some industries, in particular the forestry industry, are working to put the revised conditions in place as soon as possible. The conditions are similar to those adopted in the USA.

(2) The revised conditions are being advised to users by the label changes and Gazettal notification. In addition Forestry Tasmania has prepared and issued the following documents to ensure correct application of atrazine: Pesticides Application Manual, A Policy on Weed Management in Plantations; and Code of Practice on the Use of Weedicides on State Forests.
(3) The monitoring and enforcing of the revised conditions of use for atrazine will be undertaken by Tasmania in accordance with the findings of the taskforce detailed under point (6).

(4) Atrazine is considered essential to the establishment of eucalypt plantations because there are no cost effective alternatives. The examination of alternatives is one of the tasks of the taskforce detailed under point (6).
(5) No advice has been provided by the Tasmanian Registrar.

(6) The taskforce comprises the National Registration Authority for Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals (NRA), National Health and Medical Research Council, Primary Industries-SA, CSIRO Water Resources, CSIRO Soils, Conservation and Land Management-WA, a Tasmanian environmental consultant, Tasmanian Forests, APM Forests, North Forest Products, and Ciba Australia.
The taskforce will examine the management and use of herbicides in forestry, especially atrazine, and report to the NRA and the States. Its tasks include:
establishing a standard system for chemical testing and water monitoring procedures for atrazine in ground and surface water;
ensuring that use patterns are compatible with national health and water quality standards;
reviewing the effectiveness and efficiency of the new restrictions and use patterns for atrazine in forestry;
establishing a national code for chemical use for the forestry sector;
evaluating alternative weed management systems suitable for forestry.
(7) The taskforce will consider all available information, including information from the Waterwatch network.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 19 October 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Please provide an outline of the defensive driver training course run for DASFLEET, Marketing and Sales Section, at a cost of $25 800.
(2) How many participants undertook this course.
(3) How long does the course take to complete.
(4) What other costs were associated with this course.
(5) What qualifications did the drivers emerge with from this course.
(6) Was it just DASFLEET employees that undertook the course, if so, what designations of employees undertook the course; if not, what people undertook the course.
(7) How many other courses of this type have been run.
(8) What has been the cost of these courses.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) DASFLEET co-ordinated ten one day driver training courses for its customers, i.e. Commonwealth Government departments and agencies, at a cost of $25 800. PARA.TAB: The names of the 23 companies and their locations are as follows:
